description:
Spring Container Planting Workshop, Grow Your Own Kai - In Containers From Your Own Compost

Want to grow your own fresh kai but only have a balcony, patio, or courtyard? This hands-on workshop will show you how to grow spring vegetables and herbs in containers - a flexible, low-cost way to turn even the smallest space into a productive garden. Following on from our winter edition, this is the second workshop in our seasonal container growing series, with a focus on getting your spring garden thriving using your own compost.

This workshop will cover:
- What to grow in spring, including leafy greens, herbs, and root vegetables
- How to set up containers - choosing the right size, drainage, potting mix, and using your own compost or bokashi soil
- Feeding your plants with DIY fertilisers, spotting nutrient gaps, and refreshing tired soil
- Creating ideal growing conditions with sunlight, watering tips, wind protection, and natural pest control
- Keeping your garden productive by harvesting, replanting, and rotating crops throughout the season

Please bring your own container(s) - buckets, storage bins, flexi tubs, or old drawers all welcome. We will show you how to safely repurpose them.

Spaces are limited, book now to get growing this Spring!
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Storytelling On Stage, Do you love storytelling shows like The Moth? Come join the growing art of live storytelling. Learn how to find ideas from your life, craft a compelling narrative, and deliver your story in a confident and entertaining way.

Description
Live storytelling is an artform unto itself, requiring different skills and techniques from standup comedy or prose writing. In this four-part workshop, you’ll learn:

- Creative writing exercises and daily practices to to find meaningful stories from your life
- Tools for crafting a compelling personal narrative
- Techniques to build suspense, drama, and humour into your stories
- Stagecraft and performance skills to heighten and polish your delivery

By the end of the class you'll have
- One or more polished 5-10 minute stories to showcase on stage
- Dozens of ideas to expand upon for future stories
- Writing practices to improve your life as a creative
- Less stage fright and more confidence as a speaker

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Tea & Tales Book Club, Enjoy some lively book discussion with like-minded people over a cuppa. We'll share what we're reading at the moment - everything from poems, excerpts and anecdotes - and look at what's new in our library collections.
This book club meets at the Lower Ground tables in the Johnsonville Library on the first Friday of the month.
Nau mai rā tatou katoa | Everybody is welcome
label: Hobbies & Interests

description:
Sweat Reflect & Connect with Carolyn Patchell, Sweat – get those endorphins going!
Reflect – review our movements!
Connect – spend time with our classmates!
Sessions:
All Day 10.15am to 4pm $55
Morning 10.15am to 1pm $30
Afternoon 1.15pm to 4pm $30
Our day will start with a 30-minute Dance Fitness session that will include warm-ups but no cool down as we’ll head straight into a Tips and Tuition session. We’ll break down movements, go over cues and choreography, and look at how to increase or decrease intensity (or manage any injuries we might be carrying). We’ll take a break together and some healthy snacks will be provided along with hot drinks. We’ll then head into another Dance Fitness session where you can put your newfound knowledge to use (or just have some fun and party like it’s Friday night)! After a stretch and cooldown, we’ll do a bit of a wrap up over lunch (bring your own) and spend some time relaxing and chatting. Hot drinks will be available, or you can pop out if you need a barista made flat white!
If you’re not staying for the full day, we’ll say farewell after lunch and the rest of us will prepare to greet those coming in for the afternoon session.
The afternoon will start with a Strong Fit session which will contain elements of our Thursday night class. We’ll then move straight into a Tips and Tuition session which will look at all elements of our Strength Based Combo class. This will include form, technique, options, and how to maximise your weekly workouts. We’ll then take a break with some healthy (and easily digested) snacks before we power into a final Strong Fit session. Following the session, we’ll have a decent stretch and take the time to review what we’ve learned, chat amongst ourselves, and say farewell before our day concludes at 4pm.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Book Group: The Prophet by Kahlil Gibran, Do you keep meaning to read more of the great classics of literature? At Wellington Classic Literature Group we read novels that have stood the test of time, whether they were written in 1780, 1880 or even 1980. The group has been running for more than a decade and we have a great bunch of regulars as well as readers that come along for particular books or simply when it suits. We meet on the first Tuesday of the month.

Our November book, and first work of poetry, is Kahlil Gibran's The Prophet (1923). Born in Lebanon in 1883 and later emigrating to the United States, Kahlil Gibran bridged East and West. His writings, poetry and art explore themes of love, spirituality and humanity.

The Prophet, his classic work of prose poetry, has been translated into more than 100 languages and is one of the best-selling books of all time. It has never gone out of print.

Project Gutenberg link for those e-reading:
https://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/58585

VENUE
We meet in the ‘Games Room’, The Library bar's private area overlooking Courtenay Place. After you enter the bar, head to your right (up the step) and through a smaller space with booths to the large carpeted space beyond.
label: Hobbies & Interests

description:
Wearable Stories: Bolo Tie & Sheriff Badge Making with Keri-Mei Zagrobelna, Wearable Stories: Bolo Tie & Sheriff Badge Making with Keri-Mei Zagrobelna
In this hands-on workshop, participants will transform upcycled drink cans into unique wearable pieces — bolo ties or sheriff badges — inspired by Keri-Mei Zagrobelna's work in the exhibition Flaming Star. Using accessible, low-tech techniques, you’ll explore design, embossing, and enamel painting to create a piece you can take home and wear with pride.

Register at

What You’ll Learn:

The cultural background and kaupapa behind bolo ties and sheriff badges.

How to design and plan a wearable artwork.

Techniques for prepping and embossing tin.

How to transfer a design to metal and finish it with enamel paint.

Simple methods to attach your design to a bolo tie or badge backing.

What’s Provided:
All materials, including prepped tin from recycled drink cans, tools, paints, and bolo tie/badge fittings.

What to Bring:
An open mind, a steady hand, and any personal imagery or patterns you’d like to incorporate into your design.

Who This Workshop is For:
No experience necessary — perfect for beginners and those wanting to try creative metalwork in an accessible, fun way.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Jazz Festival: Emy and the Car Crash, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Hailing from the mega-city of Fielding, intergalactically renowned musician, Car Crash Emy is back!


After gracing the prestigious stage of The Stomach during her Palmy-wide tour with teenage heavy metal band, Pagan Love Song, Emy is switching genre again.


Join her as she covers super-niche underground artists, such as Ella Fitzgerald and Nina Simone.
label: Festivals

description:
StudyTime NCEA Revision Workshops, The upcoming October school holidays are a golden opportunity. While rest is important, these two weeks can also be used wisely to build momentum, fill knowledge gaps, and reduce stress heading into exam leave.
That’s where our holiday workshops come in. After a hiatus, Inspiration Education, in collaboration with StudyTime, is running NCEA Level 2 and 3 revision workshops from 1-3 October at Wellington Girls’ College.
Each session is two hours long and covers an entire external/topic, giving students the chance to:
Go over all the key content they’ll need for the exam
Learn exactly what the exam will be testing
Pick up strategies for tackling the harder Merit and Excellence questions
Receive a workbook to use in the session and keep for revision afterwards
Ask questions and get support from experienced tutors who’ve been through it all before
Why Attend?
These workshops are designed to:
Fill any gaps in knowledge
Build exam confidence
Kickstart motivation heading into Term 4
Spaces are limited and workshops often sell out quickly. Register now to secure your spot and head into exams feeling prepared, confident, and ready to succeed.

description:
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1, This course is for beginners who have no prior knowledge of te reo Māori or Māori culture. (NZ Citizens and residents pay $109 with ID, all others pay $199).

Description
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

• Have a basic understanding of the Māori spiritual and natural worlds (mana atua, mana whenua), and our important connections to them
• Identify the sounds of Māori letters and pronounce letter combinations using correct intonation and stress patterns
• Confidently greet people, introduce yourself and communicate basic personal information in an informal context
• Identify and respond to phrases in the classroom including basic commands/instructions
• Confidently describe the day/date, time, and the weather

NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. label: Festivals

description:
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 2, For those who have completed Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1 recently or have equivalent knowledge. [Please see the Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1 course description for an indication of what is covered]. Course fees: If you are a NZ citizen or hold a NZ Resident/Permanent Resident Visa the course fee is $99 (evidence of eligibility required). If you are here on a Work Visa/Working Holiday Visa the course fee is $189.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Discuss our responsibilities as a bi-cultural nation under ‘Te Tiriti o Waitangi’ and identify underlying Māori values such as: whanaungatanga, pepehā and tikanga
- Discuss the significance of whakapapa as a fundamental Māori world view and confidently describe your family and relationships through this lens
- Form simple sentences to describe parts of your face and body
- Discuss protocol on the marae
- Recognise the importance and use of karakia and be able to recite one correctly
- Recognise the cultural values inherent within different whakataukī (proverbs) and kīwaha (idioms) and be able to correctly recite one of each

Prerequisites
For those who have completed an Introductory 1 course, or equivalent. Note: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and for statistical purposes, some additional information is required as part of the enrolment process.


A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo ID when you attend.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Let's go LEGO®: Minecraft Special | Tawa Library, Let’s build – let’s explore – let’s create! Come along to the library to create your ultimate Minecraft world out of LEGO®!
Use our extensive LEGO® collection to bring your favourite game off the screen and into the library!
For tamariki aged 5+ with their caregivers.
label: Family Friendly

description:
Textured Rings - Welcome Spring!, Make your own personalised ring - a gift for yourself or someone special! :-)

Learn the basic technique first in copper or brass, and then craft your final piece in silver!

Over this taster class, you’ll be guided through the process of heating and texturing metal, cutting and shaping with traditional jewellery tools. Use feathers, leaves, or fabrics to create a unique texture for a beautiful ring!

Learn to measure your finger, cut metal to length and texture it without rolling mill, hammers and punches. Then use a jewellers torch, sandpaper and polishing, and your beautiful new ring will be ready to wear.

This 3-hour class is ideal for beginners, groups of friends and visitors to the city.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, a sterling silver ring strip and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals are available for purchase in the studio.

Kids aged 12 (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but any person under the age of 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Meet the Moa, Come meet Nunu, the friendly moa puppet! Nunu will be roaming the garden during two special sessions: 11:00–11:45am and 12:15–1:00pm. Feed him some leaves, give him a cuddle, and enjoy this fun, interactive experience bringing Wellington’s prehistoric past to life.
Nunu will be roaming around the Collections, this is the top section around the Visitors Centre and overt he canopy walkway to below the lookout. You can pick up an Ōtari Native Botanic Garden brochure and map at any entrance.
This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

Prince Percy is hopelessly charming (emphasis on hopeless), the Queen is busy approving new royal wave techniques (it’s very hard work being a Queen!), the step-sisters are causing chaos in couture, and Buttons has big dreams!

Will true friendship win over fairy-tale romance? Will Buttons dreams come true? And who is behind the kingdom’s mysterious gossip vlog? Packed with music, mischief, and magical mayhem, this is Cinderella with a twist, a tune, and a whole lot of sparkle! Step into a spellbinding world of wonder where dreams shimmer, magic floats on the breeze, and anything is possible… but only until the clock strikes twelve!

description:
Wellington Foraging Workshop 30th August 2025, Join expert forager Felicity Joy of Wild Botanica for a Wild Edible Weeds Foraging Workshop in the beautiful community gardens of Mount Victoria, Wellington.
This inspiring experience will open your eyes to the abundance of edible wild plants growing right under your nose.
We’ll unlock the secrets of foraging, connecting with the land, and turning humble "weeds" into delicious, nourishing food. You’ll gain confidence in identifying common edible plants, learn their botanical names, and understand their medicinal and nutritional benefits. We’ll also explore ethical foraging practices, how to spot toxic lookalikes, and share simple, practical ways to incorporate wild foods into your daily meals.
This isn’t just about food—it’s about sustainability, resilience, and reconnecting with the environment in a meaningful way. You'll leave with a deeper appreciation for the land, new skills to support local food security, and the knowledge to make your own simple meals from wild ingredients.
Class sizes are limited, so book early to secure your spot.
For more details and bookings, visit
www.wildbotanica.co.nz
follow @wild.botanica.nz on social media.
For questions, email felicity@wildbotanica.co.nz.
Join my email newsletter to hear about upcoming foraging workshops: https://www.wildbotanica.co.nz/pages/newsletter

description:
Victorian Photography Workshop with Brian Scadden, Victorian Photography Workshop with Brian Scadden
DATE: Sunday Sept 28
TIME: 9:30am-1:30pm
LOCATION: Cobblestones Museum, Greytown
AGES: Over 18
COST: $135 per person. Max 5 people.
Come and have a go at wet-plate collodion photography, using authentic materials to produce your own heirloom image as were made 170 years ago. This almost lost art produces one-of-a-kind images on tin or glass plates, which you create and have an image you’ve crafted to take away.

Brian Scadden will be your instructor for this workshop. Brain has been passionate about photography for over 40 years, beginning his career at the National Film Unit in the 1970s before joining Park Road Post Production as Head of Laboratory, Head of Picture, and Restoration Manager. His work in film sparked an interest in early photographic techniques, prompting him to master wet-plate collodion photography. In 2006, he was invited to assist leading wet-plate experts in the USA and has since taught many New Zealanders this challenging process. Jane, who attended Brian’s workshop in 2014, later married him in 2019 and completed a photographic project in Carterton in 2016.
Although Brian retired in 2015, he returned for short-term assignments at Park Road Post and part-time work at Archive NZ, supporting film archiving until mid-2023. Both Brian and Jane continue to shoot with 35mm and 120mm film using vintage cameras from their collection.

NOTE: Link for booking tickets coming soon.

www.greytownarttown.com

description:
Wearable Stories: Bolo Tie & Sheriff Badge Making with Keri-Mei Zagrobelna, Wearable Stories: Bolo Tie & Sheriff Badge Making with Keri-Mei Zagrobelna
In this hands-on workshop, participants will transform upcycled drink cans into unique wearable pieces — bolo ties or sheriff badges — inspired by Keri-Mei Zagrobelna's work in the exhibition Flaming Star. Using accessible, low-tech techniques, you’ll explore design, embossing, and enamel painting to create a piece you can take home and wear with pride.

Register at

What You’ll Learn:

The cultural background and kaupapa behind bolo ties and sheriff badges.

How to design and plan a wearable artwork.

Techniques for prepping and embossing tin.

How to transfer a design to metal and finish it with enamel paint.

Simple methods to attach your design to a bolo tie or badge backing.

What’s Provided:
All materials, including prepped tin from recycled drink cans, tools, paints, and bolo tie/badge fittings.

What to Bring:
An open mind, a steady hand, and any personal imagery or patterns you’d like to incorporate into your design.

Who This Workshop is For:
No experience necessary — perfect for beginners and those wanting to try creative metalwork in an accessible, fun way.

description:
Sweat Reflect & Connect with Carolyn Patchell, Sweat – get those endorphins going!
Reflect – review our movements!
Connect – spend time with our classmates!
Sessions:
All Day 10.15am to 4pm $55
Morning 10.15am to 1pm $30
Afternoon 1.15pm to 4pm $30
Our day will start with a 30-minute Dance Fitness session that will include warm-ups but no cool down as we’ll head straight into a Tips and Tuition session. We’ll break down movements, go over cues and choreography, and look at how to increase or decrease intensity (or manage any injuries we might be carrying). We’ll take a break together and some healthy snacks will be provided along with hot drinks. We’ll then head into another Dance Fitness session where you can put your newfound knowledge to use (or just have some fun and party like it’s Friday night)! After a stretch and cooldown, we’ll do a bit of a wrap up over lunch (bring your own) and spend some time relaxing and chatting. Hot drinks will be available, or you can pop out if you need a barista made flat white!
If you’re not staying for the full day, we’ll say farewell after lunch and the rest of us will prepare to greet those coming in for the afternoon session.
The afternoon will start with a Strong Fit session which will contain elements of our Thursday night class. We’ll then move straight into a Tips and Tuition session which will look at all elements of our Strength Based Combo class. This will include form, technique, options, and how to maximise your weekly workouts. We’ll then take a break with some healthy (and easily digested) snacks before we power into a final Strong Fit session. Following the session, we’ll have a decent stretch and take the time to review what we’ve learned, chat amongst ourselves, and say farewell before our day concludes at 4pm.

description:
Women's MINDSET Self-Defence Workshop - Wellington, Women's MINDSET Self-Defence Workshop - Wellington
Our women's workshop is probably the most intense, comprehensive, enjoyable & hands-on self-defence syllabus in New Zealand & Australia.

About this Event

The workshop is rated R13 so only those aged 13 and above can attend due to the content taught. There are a limited amount of spaces available so book early.

Don't let the price deceive you; we're firm believers that every woman and family deserves the opportunity to participate in workshops like this without having to break the bank.

So, what sort of things can you expect to learn at this workshop?

You learn the vital parts of the body - parts of the body that are vulnerable & easy to attack.
Learn how to block an attack confidently.
Learn how to defend yourself against slaps, punches, pushes & grabs.
Learn to defend yourself against headlocks, hair grabbing, and wrist grabs.
Learn how to defend yourself against chokeholds, and bear hugs.
Learn how to defend yourself on the ground.
Learn effective rape defence techniques.
Learn how to use your hands, legs, knees & elbows as weapons.
Learn to defend yourself against many other types of attacks with confidence.

Plus, lots, lots more. (depending on the time allowed & the participant's progression)
What we teach is how to deal with the worst-case scenario, when the awareness, avoidance and de-escalation have failed, it all turns physical, there's no obvious way to escape & you must fight back.

"... a massive shout out to Charlie Riley for all the amazing work he does. Charlie, you are a champion among champions. Thank you. Ladies, if you loved #reebokunleashed or if you missed out, please check out Charlie and find a course near you."
Zoe Bell - Hollywood Stunt Woman, Actress & Producer

This is the sixteenth year that we've been running our women's workshop for the community in New Zealand and this is the second year in Australia. All you need to take with you is a positive attitude, comfortable clothing, a drinks bottle & towel plus something to eat during the breaks. Please note that the workshop takes people out of their comfort zone & can be both physically & mentally demanding at times if unsure seek your doctor's advice before undertaking any form of physical training or have a word with the instructor.

For more details contact Charlie (MINDSET Self Defence & Close Quarters Combat) at:
Email: | Mobile: +61 451 900 676

description:
West Auckland Mathematics Leadership Community 2025, Are you the maths lead in your school? Do you feel equipped to lead the roll out of the new mathematics and statistics curriculum? Would you like to be part of a group of like-minded leads?
Register to join our Mathematics Leadership Community (MLC) and build your mathematics and statistics knowledge and leadership skills.
These MLC’s have been supporting mathematics leaders and teachers for over 18 years and we are excited to offer you the opportunity to be part of this network in 2025, which is shaping up to be a pivotal year in mathematics education.

Through engaging with current research and best practice, these meetings will enable leaders and teachers to:
stay up to date with changes and implement Te Mātaiaho, Mathematics and Statistics Curriculum
build capability in leading mathematics and statistics within and across their school
investigate effective pedagogy and strategies for teaching and assessing mathematics and statistics
connect and network with other leaders and teachers.

Testimonials from 2024
“These days have been invaluable in supporting me to lead whole school maths review with our teachers.”

“It has given me more knowledge and confidence when leading my own meetings, knowing I have research and work behind me when I lead.”

“I love the resources and the connections that develop through these meetings.”

“This year the mahi we have done around the curriculum refresh has been instrumental in beginning our school’s development of our localised curriculum.”

20th March, 9.15am - 2.45pm
6th June, 9.15am - 2.45pm
14th August, 9.15am - 2.45pm
6th November, 9.15am - 2.45pm

$350 for a 2025 Membership (+gst and booking fees)
$100 for 1 meeting (+gst and booking fees)
*Each ticket purchased gives entry for two attendees from 1 school*

For any Kāhui Ako interested in this series, please contact us at info@cognitioneducation.com.

description:
You Spot It You Got It: Unpacking cultural conditioning and turning the mirror inwards, Talanoa Tai Learning is a new collection of learning experiences. They're designed to help you build your cultural responsiveness and improve your ability to engage meaningfully with Pacific communities. Talanoa is a Pacific style of deep dialogue, with a focus on how we connect to each other and strengthen relationships, while still being able to share honest and effective insights. If you want to strengthen your capability in this space, to create transformational change, and to enhance your relationships with people from different communities - this workshop is your chance to grow.
What will I gain from You Spot It, You Got It?
In You Spot It, You Got It, you will deepen self-awareness by being encouraged to recognise some of your own conditioning and impacts of this in your daily life/practices. When we are not conscious of the things that might not sit right within us then we unknowingly or knowingly project them onto others. What we reject, we project. By examining patterns and recognising our conditioning, then we can truly understand how we can live in more conscious ways. This Talanoa Tai learning experience offers space for talanoa, tools and exercises to facilitate introspection and personal growth by turning the mirror inwards.
This is a 3.5 hour in-person learning experience. The day will start with a mihi whakatau to welcome you into the space.
Who is this workshop for?
These learning experiences are for both Paciﬁc professionals and those from other communities. You don’t need to have prior knowledge or experience in this area - we’ll meet you where you are and provide a welcoming, supportive environment for you to learn.
Cultural responsiveness is for everyone. Whether you’re in social work, education, government, community sectors or beyond, these learning experiences have been designed to help everyone build their skills. If you think this professional development might be right for you, it is!
Cost
When work is busy and budgets are tight, cultural responsiveness can often take a backseat. But this is an aﬀordable investment that will help you address the challenges that so many of us share, like how to build engagement and trust, and avoid relationship missteps. It’s not a buzzword; it’s a vital skill if you want to better meet the needs of the people you serve. Price: $170 (inc GST) per person, including morning tea.
Facilitator
Our team’s extensive research and experience feed into these sessions, with a focus on interactive activities and practical, real-life examples. Our team has decades of experience across a range of ﬁelds, in particular social development, education, and research. We have worked with organisations and businesses across the Paciﬁc, and our engagement with diﬀerent Paciﬁc languages, cultures, and communities means we oﬀer robust, informed perspectives. Fa’aeafale’upolu (Polu) Samuelu is the facilitator of this Talanoa Tai Learning experience.

description:
Art and AI: Brit Bunkley in Conversation with Megan Dunn, Art and AI: Brit Bunkley in Conversation with Megan Dunn
Artist and filmmaker Brit Bunkley discusses the pragmatics and politics of making art with AI. Join us for a discussion in the Gallery, with insights into the making of his latest work Archive, commissioned for Messengers.

--

Brit Bunkley is a New Zealand-based artist and videographer whose practice spans sculpture, installation, and digital media. A recipient of the US National Endowment for the Arts fellowship, two NY state grants, and the Rome Prize Fellowship, his work explores the intersection of physical and virtual spaces, often blending surreal imagery with themes of history, politics, and environmental concerns. He has exhibited at the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa and internationally at Rencontres Internationales Paris/Berlin, FILE São Paulo (including 2025), and the Athens Digital Arts Festival. Recent exhibitions include Visions in the Nunnery, London (2022), Cybersculpture 2024 at Collège des Bernardins, Paris, and The Torrance Art Museum, LA (2025). In 2024, he won Best Art | Experimental Video/Film at the New York City Independent Film Festival. His work continues to evolve, embracing new technologies and alternative methodologies to challenge perceptions of reality and imagination.

Learn more here > https://citygallery.org.nz/events/art-and-ai-brit-bunkley-in-conversation-with-megan-dunn/

IMAGE Brit Bunkley, still from Archive, single channel video, 2025

description:
Bodgies to Bogans, Bodgies to Bogans
This Festival event runs from the 18th October to the 9th November 2025.


'Bodgies to Bogans' tells the story of the juvenile delinquencies and teenager rebellion of the 1950s to the Bogans of the 1980s.

Whether you were listening to rock and roll, riding motorcycles and drinking milk shakes at milk bars in the 50s or growing a mullet and thrashing out the leathers to heavy metal in the 80s, this exhibition documents the history of youth culture in Upper Hutt, and New Zealand.

Curated and developed by Whirinaki Whare Taonga.
Proudly supported by The Rimutaka Trust.
Open 10am–4pm, seven days a week.


Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/bodgies-to-bogans/

description:
CF's PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA, On the 9th of October it will sadly be 9 years since our little sister Wilhelmina died of a particularly aggressive form of breast cancer just 3 weeks short of her 50th birthday and a week before her eldest of 4 girls' 16th birthday, which we bought forward a week so she could be there to celebrate it. She took her last breath at 6.06pm the next day while our father (RIP) and I held her hands and my brother played his guitar at her feet.. with Charles Humphreys at her head and our Mum and her girls looking on, and while Rafael and Sjaak held the fort and kicked off Sunday Salsa at The Cross.. in my absence.
***
PLEASE JOIN US DRESSED IN AS MUCH PINK AS POSSIBLE IN CUBA MALL ON FRIDAY 1 NOVEMBER @ 6PM - THE DAY BEFORE OUR SISTER'S ("MINA'") WOULD HAVE BEEN 58TH BIRTHDAY - TO CELEBRATE LIFE IN PINK
LA VITA IN ROSA
LEVEN IN ROZE
LA VIDA EN ROSA
LA VIE EN ROSE
ORA I ROTO I TE MAWHERO
AND TO RAISE AS MUCH AS WE CAN FOR BCFNZ.
***
CUBAN☆FUSION - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists' famous Cuba Street Salsa Party is going PINK this November for a very good cause - The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ.
What better place to dance Salsa than in the street, Cuba Street to be exact.
Don't worry if you don't know how to dance, we'll teach you!
Dress Code: PINK!
Help us raise awareness and funds for a very good cause and have a good time at the same time.. the Cuban way.. dancing the night away under the stars!
Suggested Koha/Donation: $5

description:
Bride Of The Year 2025, For 55 years, Wairarapa Bride of the Year has been a mainstay in the events calendar in the region. The event returns to the Wairarapa Events Centre for 2025, where brides who were married between 1 July and 30 June and were married in the Wairarapa, and/or have lived or are living in the Wairarapa, and/or whose spouse has lived in the Wairarapa, will get the chance to relive the magic of their big day, donning their gowns again, all while raising much needed funds for Te Awhina Plunket Wairarapa.

This event is unique in its focus on Wairarapa’s flourishing wedding industry. It is a great opportunity for couples planning their own weddings to look for inspiration from other local couples, for friends and families of brides to reminisce on the weddings. It is also an excellent opportunity to support Wairarapa Plunket and the service they provide to our community.

In 2024, the funds raised through Bride of the Year went towards purchasing equipment for use for Plunket rooms across Wairarapa along with purchase .

A ticket to Bride of the Year provides you with a night of glamour and celebration of love, all while supporting Wairarapa Plunket and the service they provide to our community.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Book Reading: Noho Tahi 和平共處 by Noho Tahi Collective, We're thrilled to host this event to celebrate Noho Tahi | 和平共處 by Noho Tahi Collective, with 5ever Books.
Noho Tahi | 和平共處 is the inaugural residency project for The Dan and Una Chan & Laywood and Joyce Chan Residency at Wai-te-ata Press. The Residency’s focus is on “projects that enhance understandings of and engagement with Chinese Aotearoa, whether historical, social or cultural.
Speakers on the night are: Etienne Wain 黃義天 , Juhyeon 주현, brenda wang, Brecon Dobbie 布雷肯.
This multimedia collection reflects on noho tahi | 和平共處, peaceful co-existence between cultures — an emerging invitation for Hainamana/NZ Chinese communities to reorient ourselves towards Tangata Whenua in ways that uphold Tikanga Māori, Te Tiriti o Waitangi, and the diversities and complexities within Hainamanatanga (Chinese ways of being in Aotearoa).
Nau mai, haere mai! 入嚟坐!
label: Community & Culture

description:
An Evening for Palestine, Please come along to a fundraiser evening to benefit The UN's Occupied Palestinian Territory Humanitarian (OPT) Fund. The fund supports NGO's and UN partner organisations on the frontline of the humanitarian crisis in Gaza - more information here UN Crisis Relief.
It's an opportunity to give back and to share kai, and spend time with community. We have immense privilege in Aotearoa, and cooking and sharing food is a way that feels important (to me) as a way to bring people together for a good cause, in the face of what often feels like endless global and local injustice, oppression and catastrophe.
All ticket sales from this fundraiser will go to the OPT Fund, to support the people most in need when they need it.
Included in the ticket sales are:
a three course family style meal (menu released closer to the date, vegetarian and vegan option)
tunes from some of Wellington's local musicians
discounted beverages on the bar (with sales going directly to the Fund)
Doors open 5:30, music from 6, dinner from 7.
We're currently sourcing donations from local sponsors to make the event possible. If you would like to participate, get in touch.
Please note there is a flight of stairs to Bedlam and it is unfortunantly not wheelchair accessible.

description:
Bodgies to Bogans, Bodgies to Bogans
This Festival event runs from the 18th October to the 9th November 2025.


'Bodgies to Bogans' tells the story of the juvenile delinquencies and teenager rebellion of the 1950s to the Bogans of the 1980s.

Whether you were listening to rock and roll, riding motorcycles and drinking milk shakes at milk bars in the 50s or growing a mullet and thrashing out the leathers to heavy metal in the 80s, this exhibition documents the history of youth culture in Upper Hutt, and New Zealand.

Curated and developed by Whirinaki Whare Taonga.
Proudly supported by The Rimutaka Trust.
Open 10am–4pm, seven days a week.


Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/bodgies-to-bogans/


Health & Safety:
Staff will be onsite at all times on the front desk to assist in emergency situations.

description:
CUBAN☆FUSION's Annualish PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA, CUBAN☆FUSION's Annualish PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA
On the 9th of October it will sadly be 9 years since our little sister Wilhelmina died of a particularly aggressive form of breast cancer just 3 weeks short of her 50th birthday and a week before her eldest of 4 girls' 16th birthday, which we bought forward a week so she could be there to celebrate it. She took her last breath at 6.06pm the next day while our father (RIP) and I held her hands and my brother played his guitar at her feet.. with Charles Humphreys at her head and our Mum and her girls looking on, and while Rafael and Sjaak held the fort and kicked off Sunday Salsa at The Cross.. in my absence.

***

PLEASE JOIN US DRESSED IN AS MUCH PINK AS POSSIBLE IN CUBA MALL ON FRIDAY 1 NOVEMBER @ 6PM - THE DAY BEFORE OUR SISTER'S ("MINA'") WOULD HAVE BEEN 58TH BIRTHDAY - TO CELEBRATE LIFE IN PINK 🩷 LA VITA IN ROSA 🩷 LEVEN IN ROZE 🩷 LA VIDA EN ROSA 🩷 LA VIE EN ROSE 🩷 ORA I ROTO I TE MAWHERO 🩷 AND TO RAISE AS MUCH AS WE CAN FOR BCFNZ.

***

CUBAN☆FUSION - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists' famous Cuba Street Salsa Party is going PINK this November for a very good cause - The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ.

What better place to dance Salsa than in the street, Cuba Street to be exact.

Don't worry if you don't know how to dance, we'll teach you!

Dress Code: PINK!

Help us raise awareness and funds for a very good cause and have a good time at the same time.. the Cuban way.. dancing the night away under the stars!

Suggested Koha/Donation: $5

Aiming to fund-raise $1,000 this year.. that's only 200 people @ $5 dancing Salsa in Cuba Street all PINKed up. We can do it!

EFTPOS available - 1.1% surcharge applies.

Alternatively, (or if you can't make it to the event, but would like to contribute) you can also donate on-line to our dedicated Pink Party account:

02-0343-0003801-007

ALL donations will go directly to The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ to help them in their mission to educate and find better cures.

Please give generously.

LOCATION: You will find us in "La Plaza" - the open space between the Bucket Fountain and the Left Bank Lane in Cuba Mall.

NB: This event is weather dependent. Decision to relocate or postpone will be made by 4pm at the latest on the day.

RAIN DATE: TBC

***

This event annualish (thanks to COVID) is dedicated to the memory of CUBAN☆FUSION's Co-Founder Rosina van der Aa's little sister Wilhelmina van der Aa, who died three weeks short of her 50th birthday on 9 October 2016 of very aggressive secondary breast cancer leaving behind four gorgeous girls and one loving husband.

description:
Cafe Fund Raiser Event for SPCA with Puppy Cuddles, Hi, I’m Daniela, proud owner of Greta Point Cafe in Evans Bay and a passionate animal lover! I’m thrilled to announce a special SPCA fundraiser at my cafe on Saturday, 30 August 2025 to support animals in need.

Join us for a fun-filled day featuring :
**Special bakery treats for dogs and humans alike,
**Puppy cuddles (10am- 2pm) from puppies currently living at the SPCA shelter
** Opportunities to donate to the SPCA.

In the lead-up to the event, we’re also collecting donations like pet food, blankets, and other supplies—feel free to drop them off at Greta Point Cafe, and we’ll deliver them to the SPCA on the day.

This fundraiser is a tribute to the memory of my beloved dog, who I got from SPCA when I first moved to Wellington and is also a way to help animals still waiting for their forever homes.

Let’s come together to make this fundraiser a success and give animals the love and care they deserve!

description:
Creative Futures: Arts, Economy and System Shifts, Join celebrated artist and cultural leader Teremoana Rapley MNZM for a powerful wānanga exploring the role of creativity in shaping local economies and systems. From local identity and wellbeing to economic growth and policy influence, this workshop invites artists, community leaders, and changemakers to reimagine the power of the arts in our region.
Through kōrero and shared storytelling, we’ll unpack how artistic practice can drive systems change and strengthen Lower Hutt's inclusive, culturally rich creative economy, one that reflects indigenous and local voices of communities across Te Awa Kairangi.
Teremoana Rapley MNZM is a pioneering artist, broadcaster, and cultural leader whose work spans music, television, and indigenous creative advocacy. Of Kiribati, Rarotonga, Aitutaki, Mangaia, Cuba, Jamaica, and Suriname descent, she first rose to prominence with Upper Hutt Posse and Moana & the Moahunters. Her practice is rooted in indigenous storytelling, systems change, and mentoring, often acting as a “Matriarchitect” to uplift others. With accolades including the Pacific Music Awards Lifetime Achievement Award and induction into the Aotearoa Music Hall of Fame, Rapley continues to shape Aotearoa’s creative landscape through collaboration, education, and community engagement.
In partnership with Toi Rauwhārangi College of Creative Arts, Massey University.
Light refreshments provided.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Community Evening Trimester 2 2025, About Ignite:
Ignite Consultants is a student-run charitable organisation that provides free and creative advice to charities and social organisations across Aotearoa. All of our consultants are passionate and talented student-volunteers who are driven by their desire to foster social change. Our vision is to help organisations to maximise their impact through harnessing the fresh perspectives of university students. 
We run two project cycles per year which coincide with the university semesters, each lasting for a duration of 9 weeks. Each team consists of a local charity, 5-6 students, a project manager (a person who has been through the Ignite Consultants experience before) and a professional mentor who has experience in consulting and/or the industry the organisation works in. 
About the Event:
Ignite's Community Evening is a special occasion where our consultants share what they have learnt, created and experienced over the past nine weeks. This event is an opportunity to learn about the remarkable charities we have collaborated with this semester, to enjoy delicious food and to extend our heartfelt thanks to all our supporters. 
This semester, attendees will get to hear presentations from the teams who have worked with WELLfed, Take10, Orange Sky, PACE and The Charitable Recycling Trust. 
To join us virtually, please click on the link below:
label: Community & Culture

description:
Cocktail Night 2025, VicCom Presents... Cocktail Night 2025 🥂
While we sadly won’t be hosting the Commerce Ball this year, we’re not leaving you without a reason to dress up! VicCom is excited to invite you to an elegant evening at The Library Bar on Courtenay Place, for a night of cocktails, food, music, and a great time.
This is your chance to gather with friends, enjoy a lively atmosphere, and make memories in one of Wellington’s most iconic cocktail lounges. Whether you were planning to attend the Ball or are simply looking for a fun night out, Cocktail Night is the perfect excuse to get dressed up and raise a glass with us. 🥂
🌟 Your Ticket Includes: 🌟
Entry to The Library’s private function space 🍷
A complimentary drink on arrival 🍹
Delicious food served throughout the night 🍴
🎟️ Tickets
$20 — VicCom Member (please enter your student ID as a Discount Code)
$30 — Non-VicCom Member
📅 Event Details
Date: Friday 19th September, 2025
Time: 7:00pm until late
Venue: Lovebite, The Library Bar
Address: 2 Forresters Lane, Te Aro, Wellington
❓ FAQs
Q: Do I need to dress up?
A: Not necessarily, but we'd love it if you did! We're not going to let that dress rental go to waste...
Q: I already bought a Commerce Ball ticket. What now?
A: You’ll receive a full refund for your Ball ticket and a complimentary Cocktail Night ticket automatically. You will have received an email with instructions on how to secure your free ticket.
Q: Do I need to be 18 to attend?
A: Yes. This is an R18 event, so you must be born on or before 19/09/2007.

description:
DRAG BINGO with Selina Simone! @DLS, Darling, This is not your grandma's Bingo! this is DRAG BINGO with local drag artist, ya dad's favorite, sinner & showgirl, SELINA SIMONE!
Brace yourself for an evening dripping with glamour, sparkle, and a whole lot of cheek as you soak in the skyline of Wellington's most unique rooftop hideaway
DIRTY LITTLE SECRET!
Slip into something fabulous, grab your favorite drink, and get ready for an extravagant night of DRAG BINGO! We've got cocktails that'll make you blush, and more laughs than you can shake a feather boa at!
Expect live drag performances to make your heart race, dad jokes that'll have you in stitches, and beats from our fabulous local DJs that'll keep you moving all night long! Book your table for 7.00pm, balls dropping 7.30 at the latest!
Event Highlights:
Hold onto your wigs, honey, because it's FREE to enter! And we have well over $200 worth of PRIZES to be won! including our grand prize... $100.00 BAR VOUCHER! odds not in your favour? we have SPOT PRIZES up for grabs, so sexy naughty and fun I'm not allowed to mention them on this media platform!
Oh, and speaking of keeping things alive, why not order a bit of me with the "Selina Simone" cocktail? Curious about how I taste? One sip, and you'll be hooked! Check out our epic kai offers as well!
Get your gang together, you've got to book a table to secure your spot! let's turn this night into a campy, sexy extravaganza!
Reserve your table for 7:00 pm, bookings are hot, so snatch yours now through the link below (or the ticket link on this page) https://dirtylittlesecret.co.nz/events/drag-bingo/ Limited Walk-In's on the night
xx
Immerse yourself in enchanting breathtaking views that will elevate your experience. From the glittering city lights to the stars above, DIRTY LITTLE SECRET is Wellington's most unique rooftop bar, offering a setting as sensational as the entertainment!
But wait, the fun doesn't stop there! Our sensational DJ will be spinning tunes from around 9/9:30 pm 'til late. Let's keep the dance floor sizzling and the party vibes alive!
For our guests with specific accessibility needs, we have elevator access to ensure everyone can join in on the fun. However, as some tables are on raised bits of flooring, we encourage those with accessibility requirements to reach out to us directly. Your comfort is our priority, and we're here to make sure your night is as fabulous as can be!
LGBTQIA+ Friendly: Our staff and security at Dirty Little Secret are not just friendly; they're fabulous! Trained to meet the needs of all our diverse patrons, ensuring a safe, and welcoming space for everyone xx
TRIGGER WARNINGS: This is an R18 event! Expect strong language, good vibes, and thotty danger and legs so smooth they'll sweep you off your feet!—100% guaranteed! xx

description:
Orongorongo Monthly Trip - Family Shiny, Spaces still avaliable
This is a "Family Shiny" trip into the Orongorongo Station. Non members are welcome to join us but must register to obtain details of start time and location.
There is a land access fee of $20 for this trip. Non members also pay a $20 "day member" fee, this is payable to the trip leader on the day.
Vehicles must have a low ratio gearbox, not be a 4wd car, station wagon or van and must have a roll cage if a soft top.
No Dogs Allowed.
Note spaces are limited
If you want to know more about how to join our club then go to our website. https://ccvcwellington.wildapricot.org/page-1580083.
Like our page to find out about upcoming trips for the public

description:
Diabetes NZ Wellington Youth: Annual Quiz Night 2025!, Kicking off Diabetes Action Month - come join us for this annual favourite! It's a quiz night full of fun, entertainment, laughs and knowledge abound.
As the main fundraiser for DNZ Wellington Youth, all money raised on the night goes towards our Live Brave Mana Ora youth programme, offering advocacy, newly diagnosed resources, events, camps and support to our Youth living with Type 1 in the Wellington Region.
As well as raffles and spot prizes, there will be entertainment and other games to play on the night, plus the opportunity to buy answers for those less studious - so start digging behind the couch for that loose change!
A huge thank you to 1841 for continuing to host such a brilliant evening for us. We can't wait to see you and your team there.

description:
DRAG BINGO with Selina Simone! @DLS, Darling, This is not your grandma's Bingo! this is DRAG BINGO with local drag artist, ya dad's favorite, sinner & showgirl, SELINA SIMONE!
Brace yourself for an evening dripping with glamour, sparkle, and a whole lot of cheek as you soak in the skyline of Wellington's most unique rooftop hideaway
DIRTY LITTLE SECRET!
Slip into something fabulous, grab your favorite drink, and get ready for an extravagant night of DRAG BINGO! We've got cocktails that'll make you blush, and more laughs than you can shake a feather boa at!
Expect live drag performances to make your heart race, dad jokes that'll have you in stitches, and beats from our fabulous local DJs that'll keep you moving all night long! Book your table for 7.00pm, balls dropping 7.30 at the latest!
Event Highlights:
Hold onto your wigs, honey, because it's FREE to enter! And we have well over $200 worth of PRIZES to be won! including our grand prize... $100.00 BAR VOUCHER! odds not in your favour? we have SPOT PRIZES up for grabs, so sexy naughty and fun I'm not allowed to mention them on this media platform!
Oh, and speaking of keeping things alive, why not order a bit of me with the "Selina Simone" cocktail? Curious about how I taste? One sip, and you'll be hooked! Check out our epic kai offers as well!
Get your gang together, you've got to book a table to secure your spot! let's turn this night into a campy, sexy extravaganza!
Reserve your table for 7:00 pm, bookings are hot, so snatch yours now through the link below (or the ticket link on this page) https://dirtylittlesecret.co.nz/events/drag-bingo/ Limited Walk-In's on the night
xx
Immerse yourself in enchanting breathtaking views that will elevate your experience. From the glittering city lights to the stars above, DIRTY LITTLE SECRET is Wellington's most unique rooftop bar, offering a setting as sensational as the entertainment!
But wait, the fun doesn't stop there! Our sensational DJ will be spinning tunes from around 9/9:30 pm 'til late. Let's keep the dance floor sizzling and the party vibes alive!
For our guests with specific accessibility needs, we have elevator access to ensure everyone can join in on the fun. However, as some tables are on raised bits of flooring, we encourage those with accessibility requirements to reach out to us directly. Your comfort is our priority, and we're here to make sure your night is as fabulous as can be!
LGBTQIA+ Friendly: Our staff and security at Dirty Little Secret are not just friendly; they're fabulous! Trained to meet the needs of all our diverse patrons, ensuring a safe, and welcoming space for everyone xx
TRIGGER WARNINGS: This is an R18 event! Expect strong language, good vibes, and thotty danger and legs so smooth they'll sweep you off your feet!—100% guaranteed! xx

description:
Echoes of Home - A Musical Journey Across Time, (Ticket Required)
Tuesday , 2 September 2025
Doors open: 4:30 PM | Performance begins: 5:15 PM sharp
Hunter Council Chamber, Hunter Building, Kelburn Parade, Wellington
Free Entry | All Welcome
In celebration of 80 years of Vietnam’s National Day (2/9), join us for a powerful evening of music, memory, and connection.
Through traditional and contemporary Vietnamese songs, Echoes of Home takes you on a heartfelt journey — honouring the past, embracing the present, and looking to the future. Performed by a diverse group of community members, this special event celebrates identity, culture, and the spirit of resilience.
What to expect:
• A beautifully curated musical programme honouring Vietnam’s story
• Performances of folk and modern Vietnamese music
• Dance, piano, harp, pipa, guitar, and more
• Multilingual storytelling to connect all audiences
• A welcoming, cross-cultural experience for all backgrounds
Please note: Doors close at 5:15 PM for the stage programme. No entry will be permitted during performances.
With thanks to our generous supporters:
MAY Coffee Crew • Hell Pizza • First National Real Estate Collective • Bellagio Cafe & Spa • Fabulash Brows & Beauty • Hutt City FM • Hi Tea • Golden Pine Trading Ltd • Saigon Xin Chao • Hutt City FM 106.7!
Hosted by Viet Hub NZ — rooted in culture, powered by community.
Follow this page for more updates

description:
ENM/Poly Speed Dating, Are you looking to meet like-minded people who embrace polyamory? Join us for an exciting evening of Poly Speed Dating! This event is for those who practice or are interested in consensual non-monogamy, offering a safe and inclusive environment to connect and potentially spark new friendships/relationships.

Price includes a drink and delicious food at the break!

We will have a private function space for this event.

When you arrive you will get a name label and your complimentary first drink, and will have time to settle in and mingle a little.

You will be Speed Dating with around 10 people over the course of the evening. You will have 7 minutes to chat to each person.
You then decide if you want to meet your Speed Dates again and tick interested on your form if you do. Only if the feeling is mutual will we email you each other’s contact details.

There will be an intermission where platters of food will be served, and you can buy yourself another drink if you like.

description:
Plimmerton Rotary Garden Tour 2025, Join us for a Springtime treat- a tour of ten gardens around the Pauatahanui Harbour.

The gardens are varied, from bijou suburban hideaways to a lifestyle block, and from an 1860s cottage garden to a modern design gem. They are testaments to the care and creativity of their owners.

Included is the iconic Heritage Rose Garden beside St Alban’s church in Pauatahanui, which features legacy and modern rose varieties around the burial ground.

Gardeners will be inspired by the experience - it will be an unforgettable day out.

Times - Gardens are open from 9.30 am to 4.30 pm on both days, except for the Pauatahanui Rose Garden/Burial Ground, which will be closed on Sunday morning until 1 pm.

Garden competition – A prize voted for by entrants for the “Best Garden” for Consultancy Services has been offered by Distinctive Home and Landscapes Limited to the value of $600. Other spot prizes will be drawn at the end of each day for entrants.

Ticket holders:


Note that when ticketing, select the Zone to start at: Camborne, Paremata/Aotea, Whitby, or Pauatahanui.

Preplan your garden tour from the map provided when tickets are issued, and have the plan available on the day.

Note that every effort is made to ensure gardens are as safe as practicable. All gardens are entered at visitors’ risk.

must obtain the garden owner's consent if you wish to take cuttings.

Note that the event will occur wet or fine, pets are not allowed, and no ticket refunds will be available.


This is a Plimmerton Rotary fundraiser for community benefit, and net proceeds will be shared by:


Gillies McIndoe Foundation, founded by Dr Swee Tan, benefits research work in developing accessible life-changing treatment options for brain cancer, vascular birthmarks and keloid scars through the use of affordable repurposed medications. https://www.gmri.org.nz/

“HAROLD” - North Wellington Life Education Trust - visits primary schools with an intriguing mobile classroom, furthering the Education of unique Life Skills for primary school children in the Porirua Johnsonville regions. northwellington@lifeed.org.nz


A special thanks to Titahi Bay Horticultural Society for their early support.

description:
Friends Quiz @ 1852, Wellington, Friends Quiz @ 1852, Wellington
Your job may be a joke, you're probably broke, your love is likely D.O.A., but we've got something to cheer you up.... for Gee Quiz is at it again, this time bringing Friends trivia to Wellington's favourite establishment, 1852, on Saturday 4th October!

In what will be a frivolity-filled Friends fest, you and your team will face off against other Friends fanatics over five furious big screen rounds to battle for top spot and a flurry of fabulous prizes!! In true Gee Quiz fashion, we'll also have fantastically-fun bonus games and the dreaded Alphabetical round, where your team will frantically answer 26 fast-fire questions as the time tick downs.

A team ticket (up to 6 players) is $90 ($15 per head for team of six), so get out of second gear and book your ticket today!!

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Festival: Our Fair Ladies (April 2025), Our Fair Ladies Tour
Embark on a captivating journey through the history buried in Karori Cemetery with our tour showcasing the remarkable lives of Wellington's women.
This tour offers a unique opportunity to celebrate the resilience, creativity and empowerment of women at a time when a woman couldn't have a bank account in her own name.  You'll hear the stories of women who had a range of interesting occupations. 
Be inspired by the incredible impact of these women's lives in early Wellington.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by 9am by email and on our Facebook page.

Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
We will meet before the tour at the Shelter (listed as Historic chapel on the map)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Week: Tragedies Tour, Come and hear stories of those who met sad, shocking and untimely ends. This tour traverses some of the older parts of the story where historic headstones mark the stories of lives lost too soon: accidents, murder, misadventure and those who fell by their own hand.
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day 1 hour before the tour starts by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 2 hours long.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
If you have purchased tickets for other people can you please pass our tour information on to them as well.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - Gallows Tour (Dec 2025), Crime, Justice, and the Final Walk.
Delve into the complex history of capital punishment in Wellington with this thought-provoking tour through Karori Cemetery. Gallows shines a light on the people behind the process. Discover their roles in shaping justice, the cases that defined their careers, and the human stories behind a system of ultimate consequence.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.

Guitar - Next Step, Follow on from the beginners' course and learn barre chords, more complex strumming styles and simple finger picking.

Bring your own acoustic guitar.

By the end of the course, you'll have built on the skills learned in the Beginners’ course and will be able to:
- Play additional chords, including E and Am shape barre chords
- Demonstrate new strumming patterns
- Demonstrate basic fingerpicking techniques
- Confidently play more songs which use the chords and strums learned
- Build up the F chord to 5 strings
- Move common chord shapes up the fretboard

Bring your own acoustic guitar.

8 weeks
Presented by Will Allardice.

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery: National Monuments (Dec 2025), The two main stops on the tour are the Cemeteries’ two national Monuments – the Tangiwai disaster and Prime Minister Peter Fraser.  We will review what happened at Tangiwai and especially the bravery of the trains crew and in addition, what the court of inquiry found about the safety of the bridge. 
Peter Fraser is generally regarded as one of NZ’s best Prime Ministers of the 20th century, and we explore his initiatives in public health and education and also his leadership during WW2.
These are just two of the several stops we will make.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
This tour requires reasonable physical fitness and sadly is not suited for those with limited mobility. 
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you 1 hour before the tour start time by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

description:
From Pemberley to Pipitea: Celebrating Jane Austen's 250th Birthday, From Pemberley to Pipitea: Celebrating Jane Austen's 250th Birthday
Marking 250 years since Austen’s birth this romp through her irreverent Juvenilia is spliced with deliciously pompous gems from Aotearoa’s earliest newspapers.

From the drawing rooms of Georgian England to the dusty streets of Victorian Wellington – the pretensions of polite society never change.

To mark 250 years since the birth of Jane Austen, her wildly funny Juvenilia is brought to life, including The Beautifull Cassandra, The History of England, Love and Friendship – and more.

Between Austen’s sharpest barbs you’ll hear genuine gems from New Zealand’s early newspapers, courtesy of Papers Past: gossip, pomposity, early etiquette advice, and scandalous society mishaps.

The result? A sparkling, one hour romp proving that the absurdities of status, marriage and manners travel across oceans, continents and centuries.

Performed as a series of readings with lightning character swaps, sly narration, and just a hint of scandal, this is Austen as you’ve never heard her: young, bold, and perfectly at home in 19th century Wellington!


Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: $25
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/from-pemberley-to-pipitea-celebrating-jane-austens-250th-birthday/


Health & Safety
Please contact the event host for health & safety information.

description:
Futuna Lecture Series 2025: Francis Kéré, The Futuna Lecture Series commenced in 2011 and has been one of the main annual events on the NZ Architectural calendar for the last 14 years. It is the Futuna Chapel Trust’s major fundraiser each year and attracts a large audience of architects, architectural designers, technicians, architecture and design students and interested members of the public. The Trust exists solely on koha/donations as well as financial support from selected sponsors and donors.
Our sponsors, Dulux NZ, APL, Plytech, Warren Trust and the Auckland, Christchurch and Wellington NZIA branches have continued their support for the Futuna Lecture Series 2025.
This year the Trust welcomes three new sponsors being Roofing Industries Limited, AGP and Big River Panels. The additional support of these new sponsors is very much appreciated and ensures that the Futuna Chapel Trust can continue to attract speakers to NZ of a similar calibre to that of the 2025 Futuna Lecture, Francis Kéré.
The Trust takes this opportunity to thank Metalcraft Roofing for their support of the Futuna Lecture Series from 2012 - 2024.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work and well as that of the Kéré Foundation.
The Trust will donate 20% of the ticket income to the Kéré Foundation to support the work of Francis Kéré in Gando, Burkina Faso.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. Please register using the ticket types of $10, $15, $25 or $30 GST inclusive. Booking fees are in addition to the ticket prices.
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when purchasing Architect tickets
label: Community & Culture

description:
Sound Bath Experience: Ngā Wā o te Tau, Sound Bath Experience: Ngā Wā o te Tau

Experience Sound Bath Experience: Ngā Wā o te Tau, a journey through the seasons inspired by the natural rhythms of Aotearoa. “Ngā Wā o te Tau” means “The Seasons,” and this sound bath, guided by Smita and Peter with the rich tones of taonga pūoro and waiata, invites reflection on the cycles of nature and our connection to the world around us.

This immersion takes you from winter’s stillness, through spring’s blossoms, summer’s warmth, and autumn’s release, attuning to the changing energies of each season. Unique sounds encourage reflection, connection, and inner calm, while gentle karakia and mindful intention weave the journey together, creating a meditative space to pause and breathe.

After the sound bath, enjoy a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert included in your ticket — a wholesome way to close the evening in good company.

Meet your hosts & musicians, Smita & Peter, Smita (Ngāi Te Rangi) was born and raised in Aotearoa. From a young age she was drawn to music as a means for reflection and self-expression. During her music studies at university, she was introduced to taonga pūoro, and this sparked a personal journey of reconnection to te ao Māori and her own whakapapa. Following university, she lived in an ashram for several years where she was introduced to the wonderful practice of bhakti yoga. She now lives with her husband in the Wellington region, where they regularly participate in kirtan (mantra music meditation) at Bhakti Lounge.

Peter is Pākehā, with grandparents from England and Ireland, and has been on a four-year journey learning the art of taonga pūoro — the traditional Māori musical instruments of Aotearoa. Guided by the wisdom and generosity of expert makers and players, he has learned both to craft and to play these unique instruments. For Peter, taonga pūoro offer a way to connect deeply with sound, story, and the natural world, and he is excited to share their voices as part of this sound bath experience.

What’s on the menu?
Jackfruit Rendang

Satay Seitan Skewer

Gado Gado salad with peanut sauce

Rice

Banana cake with caramel sauce

Hot "chocolate"
label: Religion & Spirituality

description:
Guided tour of the historic Bolton Street Cemetery - Tiptoe Through the Tombstones, Guided tour of the historic Bolton Street Cemetery - Tiptoe Through the Tombstones
Explore historic Bolton Street Cemetery in central Wellington (just off The Terrace) with experienced guides. Hear entertaining and surprising stories with Tiptoe Through the Tombstones.

Tiptoe Through the Tombstones, starting at the Seddon memorial on Sundays at 2.00pm. A fascinating tour of Wellington's early history. The stories go far beyond well-known names from history, giving glimpses of ordinary people who made their home here.

Seize this opportunity to learn more about NZ’s oldest town cemetery and the lives of some of its many and varied occupants, people who lived in nineteenth-century Wellington. Hear wonderful stories from our colonial past as well as a reminder of the disruption caused by the construction of Wellington's Urban Motorway. Settlers and Māori were buried in this beautiful heritage cemetery, and their headstones can give us intriguing information.

All Sunday tours leave from the Kinross Street entrance to the Cemetery. The tours finish at the little museum in lower Bolton Street, just off the Terrace.

Children 12 & under: free (no ticket required).

Well-behaved dogs on leads welcome.


Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: $10
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/guided-tour-of-the-historic-bolton-street-cemetery/


Health & Safety:
Follow the directions of your tour guide, and stay on paths. Old headstones and railings around graves can be unstable.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.
label: Community & Culture

description:
International Day of the Girl - 2025, You are Invited to our inaugural International Day of the Girl Fundraising to celebrate the work of Heartprint Cambodia.

The AquaPura Project is raising funds for a new Safe Water installation, and an Emergency Rapid Response Kit for Heartprint in Cambodia.
Heartprint is wholly aligned with AquaPura's mission to educate and provide technical training for girls to be safe water system installers and maintenance leads, so they are provided an opportunity to succeed in a male-dominated industry of essential water provision services.

The theme of International Day of the Girl Child 2025 is:
"The Girl I Am, the Change I Lead: Girls on the Frontline of Crisis". 

This theme was developed in consultation with girls' organisations, UN partners, and girls themselves.

This theme emphasise the leadership potential of girls and their role in driving positive change, particularly in the face of crisis. 

The International Day of the Girl, observed annually on 11th October, aims to highlight the challenges girls face globally, and promote their rights and empowerment. 

The 2025 theme specifically acknowledges the unique experiences and contributions of girls during times of crisis, recognising them as agents of change. 

This fundraiser will be led by Girls, who deeply understand the importance of delivering Safe Water for Every Child.
Heartprint is a not for profit organisation committed to improving living standards of underprivileged families in Cambodia. Heartprint takes a holistic approach to charity by building the Heartprint Community Centre. They are able to provide the support that looks at the whole family structure, not just the basic living needs, but also addressing their overall physical, emotional, social, and spiritual wellbeing.

SCHEDULE: Sat 4 October InPerson Venue
10-12pm: Room 2
*Event Video Presentation
*Emergency Response Kit Display
*Fundraising Table
(Collect Signed Limited Edition Marlborough and Aotearoa NZ photobooks)
1 - 3 pm: Room 1
*Event Video Presentation
*Emergency Response Kit Display
*Fundraising Table:
(Collect Signed Limited Edition Marlborough and Aotearoa NZ photobooks)

description:
It’s Vall Walk time again (nearly)!!, It’s Vall Walk time again (nearly)!!
HALLO FOLKS!!

Yep, that's right!! It's Vall Walk Time again (... well, not for a wee while yet ...)

This time I'm giving plenty of notice, because there's a chance my doggy-dad, Jack, might be able to come along (and Aria, and his peoples!) ... I HOPE!!

And because I LIKE it here, AND because it's gonna be a BEEYUTIFUL day (I just KNOW it!!), AND because the Tide is going to be LOW (or so calculates Buddy Dad, so we'll see if THAT turns out to be true), let’s go to the Beach at Queen Elizabeth Park!!

AND let's have a BBQ PICNIC too, cos it's SPRING time, and it's BOUND to be fine and warm!! YUMAY!!

Let's meet in the car park just inside the Mackay Crossing entrance to the Park. We'll head down to the beach from there! Bring your picnic and BBQ thingies too!! Buddy dad will bring our small portable BBQ and will cook things for you too. And don't forget about the small fee I charge to be your Official Taster!! (Snicker!!)

So, we’ll see you there!! WOOHOO!! I can hardly wait!!

And let's aim for a record turn out, because I KNOW there's lots of you Vall's out there, including a few newbies, just hanging out for some F-U-N, and blowing off some winter cob-webs!!

description: Body Reset Movement Classes, Improve your movement - improve your life - improve your sport. The Feldenkrais Method® uses slow, precise movements with mindfulness to re-progam your nervous system. Remedy the poor postural habits of injury, misuse or time, and discover or re-discover greater ease and possibilities of movement. Friendly class every Tuesday at 5:30pm (with individual sessions by appointment). First class free then koha, suggested $20 waged, $10 unwaged. Kind regards, Conrad, Feldenkrais Practitioner, 021 843 467 or www.bodyreset.nz.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
John Campbell’s Destiny Church Investigation: Part 2 Under His Command, John Campbell investigated Destiny Church in a five-part documentary screened in April this year.
Join us to watch Part 2 of John Campbell’s Destiny Church investigation. John Campbell highlights some consistent themes of Brian Tamaki's Destiny Church: far-right prejudices, manifest anger, and hatred.
In Auckland on 21 June, Destiny Church organised a march to take "a bold public stand for Christian values, Kiwi identity and the future of this nation".
On Saturday, 13 September, Brian Tamaki attended the London “Unite the Kingdom” protest organised by far-right political activist Tommy Robinson that claimed to celebrate 'free speech', but also contained chants of hate, racist conspiracy theories, and Christian nationalist slogans. Among disturbing scenes, some people in the crowd ripped up a flag that read 'Secular Humanism'. To them, the very idea that people of all backgrounds and beliefs can live together with equality and respect is something to fear and destroy. For decades, the far right in the USA has painted humanism as a bogeyman, blaming it for liberal values, the rights of women, and the rights of LGBT people. It shows that those who thrive on fear are deliberately targeting the very values that underpin human rights and human dignity. Humanism is not a fringe or ‘woke’ idea. It is about fairness. It is about reason. It is about believing in the good that people are capable of when they are free to live their lives without fear or prejudice. These protests, which Brian Tamaki is supporting, are a show of force from those who wish to undo progress, to divide communities, and to undermine cherished freedoms.
We have a growing concern for secular values in our community. We cannot be silent. It is essential to keep compassion alive in public life and politics. After watching the documentary, we will discuss our concerns and how we might respond.
Time: Oct 6, 2025 06:30 PM Auckland, Wellington
Join Zoom Meeting
https://us02web.zoom.us/j/88183700512...
