description:
Kapiti Crop Swap WAIKANAE, Kapiti Crop Swap WAIKANAE
THIS INVITE IS FOR THE WAIKANAE SWAP😁🌱
Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!
1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4pm)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)
To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.
The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.
This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:
2-2.15pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.
2.15-2.45pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
2.45-3pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.
The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month in Raumati and the last Saturday of every month in Waikanae.
Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.
2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - Tragedies Tour (Jan 2026), Come and hear stories of those who met sad, shocking and untimely ends. This tour traverses some of the older parts of the story where historic headstones mark the stories of lives lost too soon: accidents, murder, misadventure and those who fell by their own hand.
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day 1 hour before the tour starts by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 2 hours long.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
If you have purchased tickets for other people can you please pass our tour information on to them as well.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Futuna Lecture Series 2025: Francis Kéré, The Futuna Lecture Series commenced in 2011 and has been one of the main annual events on the NZ Architectural calendar for the last 14 years. It is the Futuna Chapel Trust’s major fundraiser each year and attracts a large audience of architects, architectural designers, technicians, architecture and design students and interested members of the public. The Trust exists solely on koha/donations as well as financial support from selected sponsors and donors.
Our sponsors, Dulux NZ, APL, Plytech, Warren Trust and the Auckland, Christchurch and Wellington NZIA branches have continued their support for the Futuna Lecture Series 2025.
This year the Trust welcomes three new sponsors being Roofing Industries Limited, AGP and Big River Panels. The additional support of these new sponsors is very much appreciated and ensures that the Futuna Chapel Trust can continue to attract speakers to NZ of a similar calibre to that of the 2025 Futuna Lecture, Francis Kéré.
The Trust takes this opportunity to thank Metalcraft Roofing for their support of the Futuna Lecture Series from 2012 - 2024.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work and well as that of the Kéré Foundation.
The Trust will donate 20% of the ticket income to the Kéré Foundation to support the work of Francis Kéré in Gando, Burkina Faso.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. Please register using the ticket types of $10, $15, $25 or $30 GST inclusive. Booking fees are in addition to the ticket prices.
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when purchasing Architect tickets
label: Community & Culture

description:
Kids Rock 4 Palestine, Kids Rock For Palestine
One Day. One Stage. One Cause.
This event is organised by kids in Pōneke to raise funds for kids in Palestine.
Join us for a one-day-only music fundraiser where young voices take centre stage to amplify hope and raise money for children in Palestine.
This isn’t just a concert, it’s a movement. Under-18 musicians, solo artists, and bands (some joined by over-18 allies) are coming together to rock out with purpose, showing that music knows no borders and compassion has no age limit.
These young performers are using their talents to stand in solidarity with kids just like them who are living through unimaginable circumstances.
Organiser Eddie 12: "We see children in Palestine who are being bombed and shot and are starving. We kids want to help. So that is what we are doing."
There will be stalls and crafting available for kids attending - Please come and support so we can raise money for Gaza's families.
100% of proceeds go directly to emergency aid and child-focused relief in Palestine - Convoys of Good and Kiwi Trust for Palestinian Childrens Relief.
Witness the next generation of artists and activists sharing the stage and raising their voices. Please support them with your attendance. Show them young people can make a difference.
Be part of an event where music becomes action, and community becomes change.
Do you want to volunteer to help? Email aotearoa2gaza@gmail.com
ALL UNDER 18s MUST ATTEND WITH A PARENT OR GUARDIAN.

description:
Kāpiti Crop Swap RAUMATI, Kāpiti Crop Swap RAUMATI
This invite is for Crop Swap in Raumati 🌱

Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!

1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)

To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.

The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.

This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:

1-1.30pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.

1.30-2.00pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
• We are an inclusive group and all members and sectors of our community are welcome.

2.00-2.30pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.

The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month.

Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.

2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Kelburn Community Garden Working Bee - Last Sunday of the Month, Kelburn Community Garden Working Bee - Last Sunday of the Month
Join Kelburn Community Garden and Seeds to Feeds on the last Sunday of every month at 11am for a volunteer working bee.

Tasks may include weeding, spreading mulch, and watering. As the newest community garden in Wellington, we need your help to get off the ground! We'll provide the tools, materials, and instructions. We're a friendly bunch who welcomes any and all to join. No experience needed.

We'll garden rain or shine, but we'll post on Facebook and have someone there at 11am if we need to cancel due to any weather warnings or hazards. Speaking of health and safety - please bring sunscreen, weather-ready clothes, robust shoes, and a water.

Hope to see you there!
label: Community & Culture

description:
AGM - Annual General Meeting, This is to formally advise all members of the upcoming Annual General Meeting (AGM) of the Kapiti Softball Club.
Details of the AGM are as follows:
Date: Sunday 24 August
Time: 4.00pm
Venue: Te-Atiawa park, Clubrooms
In line with our Club’s constitution, this notice is being provided at least three weeks in advance of the meeting. A formal agenda, the Annual Report, and Financial Statements will be available on the day, and will be made available on our website after the AGM.
If you wish to submit any remits or notices of motion, these must be received in writing by the Secretary no later than Sunday 17 August 2025.You can send these to info@kapitisoftball.co.nz
Committee Vacancies
This year, several current committee members have indicated they will not be standing again. While all roles are open to nominations and elected at the AGM, we especially want to highlight the following upcoming vacancies:
• Treasurer
• Club Captain
• Junior Convenor
This is a big change for our club, and we encourage any members who are interested in helping shape the future of our club to consider putting their name forward. If you'd like to learn more about what's involved in any of the roles, feel free to reach out for a chat.
Quorum Reminder: As per our constitution, at least 10 members must be present for the AGM to proceed, so we would greatly appreciate your attendance and support.
label: Hobbies & Interests

Latino Party Night – CanSurvive Fundraiser, Latino Party Night – CanSurvive Fundraiser
Latino Party Night is back! Get ready to let your hair down and join us for a fabulous night of music, dancing and delicious tapas on Saturday 4 October – all for a great cause!

We’re thrilled to have Cumbiasonica and Olin Yoliztli performing live and teaching us some moves - and the tasty tapas we mentioned is included too! At just $55 per person, this is sure to be one of the hottest tickets in town, so what are you waiting for?

description:
Murder Mystery 'Interactive', Murder Mystery 'Interactive'
Murder Mystery ‘Gatsby’ is the world’s first ever fully interactive theatre show, where every guest in the theatre gets to become a detective for the evening and try to solve the mystery of who killed the infamous stage director Larry Lugosi.

Set to a Gatsby theme, all guests are encouraged to come dressed in the glam of the 1920’s. Dress up is not compulsory but it does add to the immersive experience. No acting is required as the cast members of the show are the suspects, and guests get multiple opportunities throughout the evening to interact with the suspects to work out which one of them is the Murderer.

There is a reason this is NZ's longest running comedy show, so get ready to laugh in the face of Murder, as this show is a side splitting comedy with some guests even complaining that their “face hurt from laughing so much”. Others have said... “Haven’t laughed that much in ages, thanks guys and girls” and “Thanks team for such a great night!! We came last night and that’s the best fun I have ever had”.

Get a group of friends together, grab your costumes and book now for the latest sensation in live entertainment. But beware! There are many distractions along the way to keep you from solving this dastardly deed!
label: Arts & Theatre

description: Community Garden Build Day: From Plot to Harvest, A community event for building and planting a new community garden. Join your neighbors to prepare the soil, build raised beds, and plant a variety of vegetables and herbs. This is a great way to meet people and get involved in local food systems.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Mahi Ready Day, Are you job hunting at the moment? Are you fixing up your CV and not sure where to start?
Come along to Mahi Ready Day: A friendly, supportive, community-led event to help you build confidence and practical tools for finding work.
You can drop in any time between 10am and 2pm to chat with one of our helpful facilitators, or listen to a talk about career prepared-ness.
Everyone is welcome!
Timebank members can pay using time credits, and everyone else is welcome to contribute koha.
Workshops & stalls including (keep an eye on this event for more updates and a full programme!)
CV & Cover Letter help
Practice interviews
LinkedIn headshots
Style and clothing advice
Employment red flags to look out for
Online and tech support
Here's what's on (+more to be announced)
Here are some examples of what's on:
10:30am - 11.15am - Talk: Showcasing Your Strengths: Turning Skills and Experience into Employment
Job hunting can feel overwhelming, especially in this very tough market. This will be a relaxed, mana enhancing, practical session where you can ask questions in a safe environment. Angelique has hired people for over 30 years and will share insider tips on how to write a good cover letter, what makes a CV stand out and how to prepare for interviews.
11:30am-12pm - Talk: Employment red flags
Dhilum from Community Law Wellington and Hutt Valley will lead this session on what to look out for when it comes to employment, in particular for people in ethnic and migrant communities - including discrimination, unpaid wages and visa precarity.
12:30pm-1.10pm - Making a Living as a Freelancer
Roger has been working 'portfolio' for many years and prefers the freedom that this style of work provides. He has run workshops & coached 00's of people working in this way originally under the NEWORK Centre banner. He will share some tricks on how to find work & also to juggle several roles simultaneously.
10-11am & 1-2pm - Professional Headshots
Need a new LinkedIn profile pic? Starting a public facing role? Setting up a portfolio? David will be offering professional headshots and can make you feel at ease while taking a great photo of you!
10am-2pm - CV & Cover Letter Support
Get some advice and support on how to make your job application stand out in a crowd.NB: Bring a paper copy of your CV and Cover Letter, or make sure you can access it through your email account on one of our laptops.
10am-2pm - Practice interviews
Come and practice your interview skills with Lisa - a friendly, supportive face with years of experience interviewing job candidates.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Makara Churches and Historic Cottage Tour, Makara Churches and Historic Cottage Tour
The Makara Churches St Matthias and St Patricks date back to the 1800's. Monk Cottage built in 1867 is used as a local musuem for the area.

The churches and cottage will be open over one weekend from 10am till 3pm for people to visit. They are all within walking distance of each other.

Local people will be on site to talk to visitors. The cottage has information about early settlement of the area. St Patricks church has beautiful stained glass windows dedicated to early settlers. St Matthias has a graveyard where the early settlers are buried.


Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/makara-churches-and-historic-cottage-tour/


Health & Safety:
No particular health and safety issues apart from possibly someone tripping on an entry step. None of the buildings have difficult entryways, only 2 or 3 steps to get inside.

The road outside is quite busy at weekends so care must be taken getting in and out of cars if parked outside the grounds. There is plenty of parking inside the venue area off the road.
label: Community & Culture

description:
MMC Evening Connection, We’re excited to share with you this brand new event:
MMC Evening Connection! #2
Created in response to requests for more after-hours activities, these evenings gathering is all about community, storytelling, and belonging.
Whether you're new to Marlborough or a long-time local, join us for a relaxed Friday evening of conversation and connection in a welcoming space. This is your chance to meet others, share experiences, and celebrate the diverse cultures that make up our region.
Special Highlight
We are proud to welcome Puku Rangi Tea, a cultural performing group from Rapa Nui (Easter Island). They will share with us their rich journey through history, legends, and the vibrant traditions of the island.
Come along for Kōrero, laughter, and meaningful connection.
Bring a friend or make a few new ones!
Limited Capacity | RSVP Only |
label: Community & Culture

description:
Meet Dr Hinemoa Elder – Ara, A Māori Guidebook for the Mind, Come and meet bestselling author Dr Hinemoa Elder as she introduces her new book, Ara: A Māori Guidebook of the Mind.
Dr Hinemoa will be speaking about how her experiences as a psychiatrist, mother, whānau member and descendant have informed her writing.

She’ll share Māori resources for thinking about thinking, and provide much-needed and practical life guidance for our local and global communities.

Hinemoa’s short talk will be followed by a Q&A with the opportunity to meet this inspiring wāhine, ask questions and have her sign your books.

Everyone is welcome at this free event.

We expect this one to be popular, so please RSVP to Hedley's Books if you can to help us manage numbers.
RVSP in store, email sales@hedleysbooks.co.nz or call/text 0272816421.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland, Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland
Wonderland was Wellington’s first ever amusement park. Based in Miramar, it opened in 1907 and was located near the present-day Wētā Cave. At the time it was one of the biggest amusement parks in the Southern Hemisphere. Its various attractions were originally to be found at the New Zealand International Exhibition of 1906-1907 and were brought to Wellington after that exhibition closed. The park has a fascinating and interesting back story which the panellists will explore.

This very special event will be an unmissable treat for all local history buffs as well as a fabulous journey into Wellington’s and especially Miramar’s past, and features two of Aotearoa’s finest and most acclaimed historical novelists and Wellington City Libraries' own Local History Specialist.

Meet the panel:

Tracy Farr:
Tracy Farr's debut novel The Life and Loves of Lena Gaunt was long­listed for Australia’s Miles Franklin Literary Award, shortlisted for the Barbara Jefferis Award and Western Australian Premier’s Book Awards. Wonderland is her third novel and is set in and during the time of Miramar’s Wonderland.

Philippa Werry:
Multi-award winning historical fiction writer Philippa Werry’s most recent book Iris and me about the travels of Robin Hyde won the Young Adult Fiction Award at the NZ Book Awards for Children and Young Adults. Her numerous other works include award winning fiction, non-fiction, picture books, plays and poetry, with a special emphasis on children and young adults, and a particularly strong focus on Aotearoa / New Zealand stories and history.

And to complete our illustrious panel we have Wellington City Library’s Local History Specialist, Gábor Tóth.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour - FULLY BOOKED, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour - FULLY BOOKED
Explore Māori settlements, one of New Zealand's oldest farms, military fortifications, and prison buildings, on a guided walking tour of Mātai Moana, Miramar.

First settled in the 1350s, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford has a rich and layered history of Māori settlement and conflict, early agriculture, and farming, military fortifications, and changing prison populations.

Today, it is a predator-free paradise for a thriving native wildlife population, occasional filming site, and much-loved recreation space for locals and visitors alike.

Join Kate Curtis, history educator and creator of the Mātai Moana historic trail map, on a guided walking tour full of stories of life up the hill. The tour will begin outside the now-closed Wellington Prison, and end with a cuppa in the historic Miramar Prison Garden.

Children and on-leash dogs are welcome.


Booking is REQUIRED
Cost: suggested koha $20
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/matai-moana-mount-crawford-historic-walking-tour/


Health & Safety
This is a walking tour with some uneven terrain. A reasonable level of fitness is needed. Please wear comfortable shoes and dress for the weather.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

description:
Mākara Model School Quiz Night, Mākara Model School Quiz Night
Kia ora e te whānau,

Get ready to put your thinking caps on and join us for a night full of fun, laughs, and friendly competition at our Pub Quiz Night – happening on Sunday 14th September at Bar 1852 in Brooklyn!

Here’s everything you need to know:

🌟 Teams:
Teams can have up to 6 people – you can either organise your own crew or let us know if you’d like to be popped into a team. We’ll make sure everyone is covered!

🍬 Tickets:
Just can be bought by contacting Kiri in the school office () and are just $20 per person – this includes:
• Your quiz night entry
• A goodie bag
• Prizes for the top 3 winning teams, as well as the chance to win HEAPS of spot prizes

🎁 Raffle:
We’re also running a raffle with some amazing prizes, keep your eyes peeled for details....

🎉 It’s going to be a fantastic night of community fun and a great fundraiser for our kura – we can’t wait to see you there!

Commanding the decks this week is our super rad neighbour, DJ Boss Dude of Creeps Record Parlour - expect an otherworldly sound journey through Alt/Indie Rock, Psychedelic, Post Punk & Shoe Gaze
The perfect pre-party for Hail, Meteor!'s "Nearer" Album Release party later on at Moon, or whatever your weekend plans are!
Free entry, happy hour on board!

description:
Ngāwi Community Emergency Response Planning, Come along to the Ngāwi Community Hall on 27 September to learn more about your community’s emergency response plans.

At this session you will:

- Learn how making your own household plan beforehand will make a positive difference in an emergency.
- Learn more about Community Emergency Hubs and the type of help that is needed after an emergency.
- Learn more about and provide feedback on Ngāwi Community Emergency Plans.

Food will be provided. We look forward to seeing you there!

For more information, please email info@wremo.nz

We aim to make our community events inclusive to all people. If you are attending the event and have specific accessibility requirements, you can send us an email at info@wremo.nz with the event name and we will get in touch to see how we can meet your needs as best we can.

Please, invite friends, form winning teams in advance but remember you can also just build a team on the night with unaligned quizzers. Such randomly formed teams are great fun and have won on previous occasions.

The Quiz proper starts at 7pm but you can also have dinner there from 5pm by calling 1852 in advance and making a booking (04 801 9544)

This is the first opportuity for the two choir collaboration, and our Chamber orchestra Chiesa Ensemble to get together as we start rehearals leading to a performance of the masterwork, Weihnachts Oratorium (Bachs's XMAS Oratorio).

description:
Mostly Music Soundscape Series | Rameka Tamaki, Mostly Music Soundscape Series | Rameka Tamaki
People can expect a level of artistry and mastery over the guitar. Rameka will be playing a selection of Classical Guitar pieces which include places like Spain, Japan, South America, and also his own compositions. These will range from Baroque, to Romantic, and Modern, with elements of different genres that encompass different cultures and time periods from around the world.

Rameka Tamaki (Tūhoe, Maniapoto, Samoan, Tongan, Irish) is a Classical Guitarist from Aotearoa, New Zealand who has performed in festivals and shows around the world. With a passion for the guitar and Māori culture he completed his Bachelor of Music with First Class Honours at The New Zealand School of Music, Victoria University. His performances include ASIA Topa, The New Zealand Opera Company, Performance Space at Carriageworks Sydney, the Matariki Ahi Kā Festival, Gardens Magic, and Los Angeles for Kapa Haka.


About the Mostly Music Soundscape Series

A curated series of intimate live music experiences showcasing the depth, texture and emotion of sound. Each performance invites you to immerse yourself in a new soundscape, informed by genre, sonic craft, and music as an art form. Designed for music lovers who want more than a background soundtrack, this series celebrates live performance with a diverse range of acclaimed performers.

Saturday 21 June — Nick Granville Trio

Saturday 26 July — Seth Boy Trio

Saturday 30 August — Michelle Velvin Harpist

Saturday 20 September — The Weather Machine

Saturday 27 September — Rameka Tamaki

Saturday 25 October — Danica Bryant

Doors at 7:30pm, with events starting at 8pm. Each event will be 60—90 minutes in two sets.

These events will take place inside at The Bond Store, Paraparaumu and are seated with general admission. As a season pass holder you will be reserved seats near the front of the audience.

The Bond Store is located at 21 Birmingham Street, Paraparaumu. It operates as The Tasting Room which serves food and beverages.

With thanks to support from Creative NZ's Creative Communities Fund administered by Kāpiti Coast District Council.

North City Crack Chicken x Heinz Fried Chicken Sauce Pop-Up, Heinz’s fan-favourite Fried Chicken Sauce has finally landed in Aotearoa, and it’s making its NZ debut in style – with a limited-time pop-up collab at Crack Chicken. - Crack Chicken Willis Lane – 1 Willis Street, Wellington Central

description:
Out in the Pool 🌈, Out in the Pool 🌈
Our Out in the Pool sessions are regular monthly sessions for all queer, transgender, gender diverse and non-binary folks 🌈

We invite the LGBTQI+ community and allies to dive in and swim in a safe and welcoming environment at Keith Spry Pool. These sessions are held on the first Sunday of every month and run 6pm-8pm.

Out in the Pool evenings at Keith Spry have:
🥽 Gender neutral changing rooms and bathrooms, as well as our Men's and Women's changing facilities.
🦄 Recreation lanes with inflatables, as well as the Dive board open (as staffing allows).
🏊‍♀️ Lane space will be available to swim some lengths or aqua jog, and the teaching pool will be open as staffing allows.
😎 Spa and Sauna available
🎶 Music, swimming and good vibes only.

There is no additional cost for these sessions, simply turn up and pay our regular pool entry fees. There is no need to register, just come on down!

description:
Over the Rainbow, Over the Rainbow
There’s no place like Pōneke.

Queer historian Will Hansen and legendary barman Malcolm Vaughan kōrero the capital’s vibrant LGBTQIA+ nightlife for Wellington Heritage Festival.


About Will

Will Hansen (he/him) is a transgender historian based in Pōneke. He is the recipient of a Judith Binney Trust Writing Award and is currently working on turning his PhD thesis – ‘Queer Activism in Aotearoa, 1961-2013’ into a book. Will is also a trustee of Kawe Mahara Queer Archives Aotearoa.


About Mal

Malcolm Vaughan is a Wellington gay icon. Before the Homosexual Law Reform Act of 1986, Mal worked at a series of bars and late-night haunts in the capital. More than just places to drink, venues like The Dominion, Bamboo Bar, Casper’s, The Dome (to name a few) provided a safe place in the capital for the city’s rainbow community to meet without prejudice. Today, Malcolm alongside husband, Scotty Kennedy ow and run the iconic Cuba Street establishment Scotty & Mal’s Cocktail and Lounge Bar.

Advocates for many LGBTQIA+ causes, they have supported many community initiatives over the years. In 2000 they co-founded the After Life Memorial Trust, now called the Chrissy Wītoko Memorial Trust, which originally provided financial support for AIDS patients of the rainbow community. The Trust continues to provide a wide range of support for the Wellington rainbow community.
label: Community & Culture

description:
PANEL TALK: BALLROOM CULTURE, Ballroom is a queer subculture. The Ballroom scene today was created by Black and Latinx trans women in the late 1960s in Harlem, New York. Since then, ballroom has taken over the world with scenes in Europe, Asia, Africa, South America and Oceania.
The Aotearoa Ballroom scene was ignited by Māori and MVPFAFF+ youth in Tāmaki Makaurau over 10 years ago, and has since inspired other leaders across the motu to forge their own Ballroom communities in their respective cities. 
In preparation for The Grand Kiki House of Marama Ball, hear from influential figures who have made significant contributions to their own scenes. With international Icons and Legends coming to Aotearoa for the first time, there has never been a better time to learn and enhance our own knowledge and experience of Ballroom. 
Featuring ballroom leaders Arturo Mulan (NYC, USA), Matyouz Royalty (Paris, EU), Jaycee Iman (Auckland, NZ), Karamera Marama and Romé Marama.
Panellists
Icon Arturo Mulan (NYC Father of the International House of Miyake-Mugler) (he/him) is a ballroom Icon and Legend from the beating heart of Ballroom, NYC. Arturo has been involved in Ballroom since 1996 and has established himself as a visionary choreographer and community leader, with the title of NYC father of the international mainstream House of Miyake Mugler. His influence spans competitive wins, global workshops, and has dedicated his time to bringing diverse artistry into ballroom culture, and ballroom culture into diverse arts opportunities; such as Legendary - Season 2 (HBO Max), Brooklyn Nets performances, Cats the Jellicle Ball on Broadway and more.
Icon Tantine Matyouz Royalty (International Godmother of the International House of Gorgeous Gucci) (he/she/they) is a ballroom Icon and Legend from the Paris Ballroom scene and is the creator of the ‘Fashion Killa’ category. They discovered voguing and ballroom culture in 2009 during a trip to New York which they believe changed their life. Their impact within ballroom spans several categories: Commentator vs Commentator, Hands Performance, Runway and Fashion categories. Matyouz has become a staple commentator and music artist within the ballroom community, with a repertoire of modelling and influencer opportunities in their resumé.
Legendary Overall Founding Mother Jaycee Iman aka Jaycee Tanuvasa (she/her) is an inter-disciplinary Sāmoan artist and choreographer of fa’afafine, femme queen & trans experience. Born and raised in South Auckland, Tāmaki Makaurau, her work is firmly rooted in community as she places autonomy and story sovereignty at the core of each of her projects. She celebrates the fullness of young, queer, brown life and works collaboratively to create empowering and responsive reflections of this across a range of media such as theatre, film and activations.
Founding Mother Karamera Marama (he/they) is an emerging multi-disciplinary, queer and Māori artist professing in Graphic Design, Dance and Performance Arts. They are the Co-Founding Mother of the trailblazing Kiki House of Marama, Co-Director of Pōneke-based queer arts collective OVĀ and member of the Aotearoa Ballroom council. Karamera has been involved in Ballroom since 2020 competing in Performance and Fashion categories and winning numerous grand prizes across Aotearoa & so-called Australia respectfully; most notably within Vogue Fem categories.
Founding Mother Romé Marama (he/him) whakapapa to Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Kahungunu, Ngāti Hineuru, and Ngāti Tūwharetoa. He is an emerging multi-disciplinary performing artist, as well as the Co-Founding Mother of the House of Marama and Co-Founding Director of OVĀ. For the past five years, he has been a prominent figure in Aotearoa Ballroom, both competing and facilitating events. Renowned in the RUNWAY category, Romé has secured multiple Grand Prize titles across Aotearoa and so-called Australia.
Facilitator: Kasi Marama (he/him/barb) 
Kasi Valu ('Eua, Ma'ufanga, Lapaha / Tonga) Full-Time sergeant of Gag city #Barbz Part-Time hater of the Rihanna #Navy and Casual staff member of the #Beyhive. Retired Hater of the #swifties and founding member of Azealia Banks support group. Actor, Writer, and Producer. His work currently centres on the experiences, wit, complexities, and universality of Pacific peoples, all whilst being an all-time fia botz, professional guesser and self-deprecating in this miserable world.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Split Bill: Sohn Zone & D.E.I.'s, Sohn Zone - Rich & Rebecca Sohn

The Sohn Zone is a half hour of comedy, improvised in form and content, from Second City, Annoyance and iO Chicago veterans, Rich and Rebecca Sohn.
This show is organic. They trust each other, the audience, improv, and the moment to find their form. Nothing is decided beforehand.

Rich and Rebecca Sohn met as improvisers in Chicago over 30 years ago. As long-time teachers, this duo show began when former students asked them to headline a new evening of improv. Students often expressed surprise at how different their teaching styles were and took to saying “you’re in the Sohn zone” when seeing the couple work together.

D.E.I.'s - Mo Munn & Ralph Hilaga

When two besties land jobs at a prestigious company, they discover they’re not there for their skills — they’re the token hires. What follows is an improvised journey of chaos, corporate jargon, and an earnest attempt to prove they’re more than just the diversity checkbox.

From the chaotic minds of Wellington improv duo Mo and Ralph, D.E.I.’s is a sharp, satirical, improvised workplace comedy about tokenism, identity, and the conundrums of modern day allyship. If you’ve ever wondered what happens when the diversity quota starts talking back — this is it.

As the Sohn Zone is improvised, we cannot guarantee the presence or absence of specific content or themes beyond what is in the description above. The show may contain mature themes and language, but not gratuitously. D.E.I.'s contains strong language and adult themes, and discussions of topics like racism, queerness, and tokenism. Some material may touch on lived experiences of marginalisation and may be confronting for some audience members.

Both shows may contain voluntary audience interaction, such as giving a suggestion for a scene.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour, Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour
Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.

Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.

This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.

Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!

The presentation will cover both traditional methods of researching and writing, as well as demonstrate some off-the-shelf Artificial Intelligence applications that can help support your storytelling.

Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.

The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.

Please register here: https://walktours.nz/book

This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).
label: Community & Culture

description:
Paddy the Wanderer, Paddy the Wanderer
A dog’s eye view of Wellington waterfront history with Wellington Museum Senior Curator, Taonga, Ian Wards.

Bring your canine family member. Dog treats included!

Who was Paddy the Wanderer?

Paddy the Wanderer was a beloved Airdale Terrier known for roaming Wellington waterfront in the 1930s. After many adventures and years of dedication to the city’s maritime community, the Wellington Harbour Board bestowed Paddy the title of “Assistant Night Watchman in Charge of Pirates, Rodents and Smugglers.”

A life-sized statue of Paddy is proudly on display at Wellington Museum and the drinking fountain for dogs and their humans outside of the New Zealand Academy of Fine Arts is also dedicated to him.

Retrace Paddy’s pawprints and fetch fascinating stories with Wellington Museum’s history dog-walk.

Note: please bring socialised/trained dogs only. And don’t forget to BYO doggy-doo bags!

Walk begins at Wellington Museum and ends at Oriental Bay.

Sunday 19 October | 10am–12pm
Dogs go FREE

Tickets:

Adults: $20

Children: $12

Family of 3: $40

Family of 4: $55

description:
World Press Photo Exhibition 2025, Gathered from across the globe, step into stories that matter. The World Press Photo Exhibition 2025 brings compelling images captured by photojournalists and documentary photographers around the world. They capture powerful moments from world events that help people better understand issues of today. You’ll see stories of migration, climate change, war, protest, family, animals, sport, and more. 
This year’s World Press Photo competition attracted 59,320 entries from 3,778 photographers across 141 countries. A global jury chose 42 winners across six regions and three categories. These stunning images can be seen at the Tākina exhibition centre in Wellington from 5 September to 5 October.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Practices of Compassion, Explore the practices of the Sisters of Compassion then and now, through the lens of the historic crèche and the ongoing mahi of the Compassion Soup Kitchen.

Learn about the historic crèche established by Meri Hōhepa Suzanne Aubert and the Daughters of Our Lady of Compassion, now known as the Pukeahu Education Centre. Hear the stories of the practices of compassion led by the Sisters in early 20th century Wellington.

Then, walk over to the Compassion Soup Kitchen on Tory Street where the Sisters of Compassion and their co-workers are still supporting people with kai, aroha and much more.

This programme offers a unique look at the past and present practices of compassion emanating from these two influential and historic Wellington sites. Please bring along a cash koha for the Compassion Soup Kitchen.

Session times:
Wednesday 22 October 12pm — 1:30pm
Thursday 23 October 12pm — 1:30pm

Booking is required.

The Compassion Soup Kitchen is a two-minute walk from the Pukeahu Education Centre.
Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather.

description:
SPANK, SPANK
SPANK is happening — and it’s going to be something special!

This isn’t your average dance party — it’s a kinky night with dancing, a dark room, the St. Andrew’s Cross, and more. We’ll have kinky costumes, a spectacular VJ, and a great DJ setting the mood all night long. And this time, we’re making it even better by opening up opportunities for the community to be part of the action.

We’re inviting members of the kink community to submit their own acts, scenes, or performances — whether it’s an amateur kinky act, exhibitionism, or something they’re excited to share in a safe, supportive environment. No professional acts — just real community energy and creativity.

Want to get involved? Send your ideas and scene proposals to by 31 July. This is your chance to be part of something exciting and make SPANK a night to remember!

Ticket link (Only people with the ticket link can find this event)

description:
Sapphic Speed Dating Dinner Party, This 4-course sapphic experience is more like a big gay dinner party than a traditional speed dating event (it even features fabulous local performer, Ginger Velour, as the MC to guide you through the evening!) With each course in the meal, you’ll switch tables and sit with a new group of 4-6 cute strangers—although it’s Wellington, so no guarantees it won’t be your ex. There will be conversation question cards on the tables if you get stuck on what to say, but your best chats will come from just being yourself!

And don’t stress about asking a hottie for their number if you’re shy—we’ve designed this experience to be as easy and low-stakes as possible. Each attendee will have a paper bag “mailbox” that you can slip a note into at the end of the night to avoid any awkward face-to-face interactions. Whether you both want to connect after that is up to you, but this is the time to shoot your shot!

After purchasing a ticket, you will be sent a short questionnaire. Please fill it out promptly! This helps the organisers place you in groups with similar interests so you have the best chance at finding what you’re looking for.

No TERFs no SWERFs. This event is open to all people 18+ who identify as sapphic/lesbian/queer. Bi, pan, questioning, and ace folks are all welcome.

Additional info:
- Most dietary requirements can be accommodated by the amazing chefs at Everybody Eats. Please include your dietaries when prompted in the questionnaire.
- Accessibility: Everybody Eats is up a flight of stairs and does not have wheelchair access. There are gender neutral bathrooms inside the restaurant and all chairs have backs. If you'd prefer not to stand up and move around the space after each course, please email the organiser with any mobility requests at goldenhourgigz@gmail.com

Churton Park Toasmasters meeting, Would you like to improve your communication skills? Become a more confident public speaker? Grow your leadership skills? Meet new people?
Churton Park Toastmasters Club is just for you. We are multicultural, supportive, a friendly fun club where you can lose that fear of public speaking and improve your confidence, communication and leadership skills.
We meet on Thursdays every fortnight. The meeting will be held at the Johnsonville Bowling Club (34 Frankmoore Avenue, Johnsonville). Please arrive about 10 minutes earlier so that we can meet and explain how the meeting is organised.
We welcome guests to any of our meetings. There is no pressure to participate and you can just observe. Come visit us and meet our dynamic and diverse group. We're sure you will enjoy your time at the meeting!

description:
Speed Puzzle fundraiser for CanSurvive Dragon Boat Club, Join us for CanSurvive’s very first speed puzzling event!
Each team receives the same 500-piece puzzle and races to complete it as fast as they can.
You can have up to three people in a team and there’s a two-hour time limit.
Our unique puzzle design is top secret and stays covered until the timer starts and you can rip into it! What we can tell you is that we’ve created a beautiful new design in collaboration with New Zealand artist Lori Davis, and it’s been produced by New Zealand’s premium puzzle company, PieceHouse.
The best bit… anyone can join in! Whether you’re a speedy puzzler or prefer to take your time over a cuppa, you won’t regret giving it a go.
So, what are you waiting for? You can puzzle solo or team up with family and friends to meet like-minded puzzlers - and a few dragonboaters! - for a fun afternoon you won’t forget.
As well as the main event, we’ll have bonus puzzles on the go for the super speedy, there’s a kitchen on site for refreshments and there’ll be a raffle and CanSurvive goodies to buy, including our new puzzle - because why share the puzzle that's included with your ticket when every team member could have their own?

description:
Spring Céilí Dance with The Great Beag Céilí Band, Spring Céilí Dance with The Great Beag Céilí Band
Spring has sprung, the days are getting longer, the rain is falling sideways. Must be about time we had another céilí! Join The Great Beag Céilí Band at St Michael’s Hall in Kelburn for a rousing evening of dancing to foot-stomping celtic tunes. Our Autumn céilí sold out so make sure you get your tickets early!

If you’ve never been to a céilí (or ceilidh) before, fear not - céilí dancing is very easy! No fancy moves or any previous experience required: our caller will explain each dance, and we’ll all walk it through a couple of times before adding the music.

This is social dancing so bring all your friends! No need to bring a specific partner - there’ll be lots of friendly people to dance with.

Discounted online tickets are available on Humanitix until midnight on September 26th: $24 / $16 concession
https://events.humanitix.com/beag-ceili-spring-ceili-2025

Some door sales may be available on the day: $30 / $20 concession (cash only)

—

Doors open 7:30pm

Adults and age 10+ welcome. Under 16s accompanied by an adult.

Light refreshments will be available. We recommend bringing a water bottle to grab a quick drink between dances - hydration is key!
This is an alcohol-free event.

Getting here: St Michael’s Hall is located at 81 Upland Road in Kelburn Village, just behind the church.
There is very limited on-street parking in the village. We recommend public transport: the 4, 18, 21, and 22 buses stop regularly right outside coming up from Te Aro or down from Northland and Karori.

Be safe online: Tickets are only available online from the Humanitix event. Do not buy tickets from other sources such as Facebook comments or resale sites - these are always scams. If you can no longer attend, please contact us via Humanitix, our socials, or email to discuss refunds.

Health notice: Céilí dancing is a great way to meet lots of people. If you are feeling unwell then please stay home and rest this time, we will see you at the next one.

description:
THE GRAND KIKI HOUSE OF MARAMA BALL, The Trailblazing Kiki House of Marama present THE GRAND KIKI HOUSE OF MARAMA BALL 🌙
Proudly supported by OVĀ Collective and Te Papa Tongarewa.
The Grand Kiki House of Marama Ball will celebrate five years of the Kiki House of Marama excellence and the legacy of the growing Wellington Ballroom scene.
Join us for a night of high-energy performances and out-of-this-world fashion as walkers compete for trophies and prizes in a display of Black and Brown queer and trans joy, liberation, and Ballroom* artistry.
With a fabulous line-up of Categories, Judges, Commentators and DJ, including major local and international Ballroom figures, we invite you to wear your best outfits and prepare to finger snap ✨ 🤏 dance 💃 and cheer 🥳 the night away at Te Papa Tongarewa on Sat 4th Oct.
Ballroom Community Walkers & Spectators Ticket Access
Contact our House account on Instagram @houseofmarama or your local Ballroom leaders for the access codes to Ballroom Community Spectators & Walkers tickets.
There is a discount code for Fem Queens FREE access for FQ who are not walking/competing, please contact us or your local leaders for the discount code.
Categories & Themes
Virgin Vogue - A Marama Storm (Treasure)
Bizarre - Nocturnal Creatures of Folklore
Realness (FQ, TM and BQ) - Date Night Under the Moonlight
Hands Performance - Memoirs from Mother Marama
Body (Slim, Thicc and Luscious) - Heavenly Bodies
Butch Queen Vogue Fem - A Marama Storm (Pirates)
Face (FF, MF and GNC) - Beauty of the Blood Moon
OTA Best Dressed - Once in a Blue Moon
Commentator vs. Commentator - Echoes of the Moon
Femme Queen Performance - A Marama Storm (Mermaids)
OTA Runway - The Phases of Marama
House of the Night (no theme)
Judges, Commentators & DJ announcement coming soon...
Please do not hesitate to contact us via houseofmarama@gmail.com or on all social media @houseofmarama for any questions or concerns.
⎯
Ballroom* is a safe space created in the 1960's, forged by the Black, Latinx and queer Americans in protest against the racism and queerphobia that they faced from the non-queer community and white queer community. It is a space held to protect trans womxn of colour, so as guests and participants within this culture it is imperative that we all do our best to respect and honour this sacred space. Homophobia, Transphobia, and any discriminatory language and/or beliefs will not be tolerated. Remember to check your privilege at the door.
To learn more about the culture of Underground Ballroom check out this link: https://artsandculture.google.com/project/ballroom. Be sure to check out the growing Wellington Ballroom scene and community by following @houseofmarama and @ova_collective on Instagram.
label: Community & Culture

🕒 11:30 PM – 2:00 AM

Details: This is the final stop! Everyone should meet at this final venue at 11:30PM for a massive final Halloween party!


Wristband Policy
This is an open-format crawl. You must start at the first venue to collect your wristband. Once you have your wristband, you can visit any participating venues labeled as “Middle Stops” at your convenience between 8:30 PM and 11:30 PM or stay at the wristband venue until 10:30pm. After 11:30 PM, all participants will meet at the final venue to celebrate at the final party location!
Please remember that you need to collect your wristband at the first stop (wristband venue), as it is required for entry into all venues except the first one. Please also note that wristbands are no longer available after 10:30PM at the first venue. No refunds will be given if you show up late and miss the wristband pick-up window!
This club crawl is a walking bar crawl—all venues are within walking distance of each other. Please plan accordingly for transportation and your walking schedule.
Wristbands for entry will be provided by event staff only. To pick up your wristband, please check in with the event staff at the front reception or host stand.


2025 CRAWL MAP:





🎟️ General Admission – $20
Includes access to all official crawl stops. No frills — just the fun.
───────────────────────────────────────

👑 VIP Ticket – $25
Includes everything in GA plus:
🔥 Access to the VIP-only crawl challenge for free tickets
🚀 First dibs on future crawl drops & pre-sales
───────────────────────────────────────

🤯 Ultra VIP – $35
For the dangerously curious. Includes everything in VIP plus:
🏆 Name on our “Crawl Wall of Fame”
📜 Official “Certified Crawl Legend” digital certificate
🚪 Access to a future exclusive pre-sale drop
❓ A mystery bonus item we legally can’t describe 👀




A SPOOKTACULAR HAUNTED HOP PARTY YOU WON'T WANT TO MISS
Skip the overpriced cover charge and long lines at a single bar. With one ticket, you’ll unlock access to multiple Halloween hotspots across Wellington, each with its own theme, music, and party energy. Whether you're rocking a full costume or just out for the night, this is your chance to experience the city’s top nightlife all in one thrilling Halloween themed experience.
THIS IS NOT YOUR AVERAGE HALLOWEEN NIGHT OUT
One bar? One vibe? That’s not how Wellington does Halloween. Grab your crew and bounce between the city’s best bars and clubs, each bringing something different to the table. From spooky cocktails to wild dance floors, the night builds up to one massive end-of-night party you won’t want to miss. 🧛‍♀️
THE BIGGEST HALLOWEEN PARTY NIGHT IN WELLINGTON
This crazy Halloween experience crawl will take you through the city’s top bars and clubs with a line-up built for non-stop fun. Expect packed dance floors, themed drinks, and a crowd ready to party in full costume.
GET YOUR TICKETS BEFORE THEY VANISH!
Spots are filling fast, so now’s the time to lock in your plans. Round up your friends, pick your costume, and get ready to sip, dance, and crawl your way through one of the most exciting nights Wellington has to offer. Halloween only comes once a year... so grab your tickets today! 🎟️



18+ EVENT / GOVERNMENT ISSUED ID REQUIRED


TIPS FOR OUR CRAWL
Pick Up Wristbands On Time: Collect your wristband(s) during the designated check-in time at the scheduled location before 10:30 PM. Late arrivals will not be accommodated — no wristband, no entry.
Assign a Proxy if Needed: Can’t make check-in? Have a friend pick up your wristband for you so they don’t miss out.
Day-Of Updates: Review the Digital Crawl Map on the morning of the event for any last-minute changes or venue updates.
Check Venue Schedule: Each venue’s crawl time is listed in the Digital Crawl Map. Wristbands and drink specials are valid only during these scheduled times.
_______________________________________


IMPORTANT DISCLAIMERS
Age Requirement: You must be 18+ years of age with a valid government-issued ID to participate in this event. No exceptions.
Wristbands: Your wristband is your key to entry. You must present your ticket or QR code at check-in to receive your wristband. Wristbands must be worn at all times to access participating bars and venues. Wristband pickup location and time are listed on the crawl map. If you do not pick up your wristband at the designated location and time, it may not be available, and you will not be able to access crawl venues. No wristband, no entry.
Ticket Policy: All sales are final—no refunds, exchanges, or transfers. In case of event cancellation without a rescheduled date, a refund (excluding fees) will be automatically issued. Event lineup, venues, and specials are subject to change without notice.
Admission & Venue Rights: Participating venues reserve the right to refuse service or entry to any attendee based on intoxication, dress code, inappropriate behaviour, or venue capacity. If refused entry at one venue, you may visit alternative crawl venues available at that time. No refunds will be given if you are denied entry for any of these reasons.
Capacity and Late Entry: Some venues may hit capacity during the event. If a venue reaches capacity or you arrive late, you may have to wait in line to gain entry. There is no guarantee of immediate access or entry to any specific venue once capacity is reached, and no refunds will be provided due to waiting times or access issues.
Self-Guided Crawl: This is a self-guided event with no host leading the group. You must use the digital crawl map to navigate between venues.
Venue Awareness: If bar staff are unaware of the crawl, you must contact the venue representative listed on the crawl map. If you cannot reach them, consider that venue unavailable and proceed to an alternative crawl venue open at that time. Nightlife venues may reach capacity or close early, and not all staff members may be aware of the crawl.
Drink Specials: Drink specials are offered by participating venues and may be modified or discontinued at any time without notice.
Event Time Restrictions: Your ticket is valid only for crawl venues during the scheduled crawl times listed on the crawl map. It is not valid for entry outside these times. If you arrive late or at the wrong venue, refunds will not be issued.
Security Checks: Wristbands do not entitle you to skip venue security checks. All attendees must comply with security screening before entry.
Costume Policy: Do not wear costumes that include items which could be considered or used as weapons. Highly offensive costumes are not tolerated and may result in denial of entry without refund.
Crawl Notifications: Sign up for crawl notification texts to receive updates about when to move to the next venue. There is no host to notify you in person.
Respect & Conduct: Treat others and the event venues with respect. Disorderly conduct, inappropriate behaviour, or damage to the venues will result in removal from the event without a refund. The participating bars reserve the right to refuse entry or remove attendees for inappropriate behaviour at any time.
Liability Waiver: By purchasing a ticket and participating in the crawl, you understand and agree that you are attending entirely at your own risk. You voluntarily assume all risks and dangers incidental to this event, including but not limited to: personal injury, illness, disability, property loss, theft, damage, accidents, death, alcohol-related incidents, and actions of other participants, staff, or third parties. You, on behalf of yourself and your heirs, executors, and assigns, hereby fully release, waive, and discharge Events Per Se, its owners, officers, directors, employees, contractors, volunteers, affiliates, sponsors, participating venues, and their respective representatives from any and all liability, claims, demands, actions, or causes of action whatsoever arising out of or related to any loss, damage, injury, illness, or death — whether caused by negligence, gross negligence, breach of contract, or otherwise — that may occur before, during, or after the event. You agree to indemnify and hold harmless Events Per Se and all released parties from any claims, costs, or expenses (including legal fees) brought by you or on your behalf, or by any third party as a result of your actions during the event. You acknowledge that you have read and understood this waiver, that you are participating voluntarily, and that this waiver is intended to be as broad and inclusive as permitted by applicable law.
Event Changes: Bars and venues may change, but the event will continue rain or shine. Always check the digital crawl map for the latest venue list and updates. Be sure to check your email for any last-minute updates.
*By purchasing a ticket, you confirm that you have read, understood, and agreed to all disclaimers, terms, and conditions stated above, and accept full responsibility for your participation in the event.

description:
Tram 17 Inauguration (Fathers Day 2025), Join us at the Wellington Tramway Museum as we put our latest restoration project into active service at the museum!
Tram 17 was built in 1904 by the Wellington City Council Tramways as a four wheeled box (Palace) style tram. By 1917 the system had grown and 17 was rebuilt into its current form adding a set of trucks converting the tram to 8 wheels. Tram tram saw regular service until the 1940’s where it was eventually use for peak time travel, before being withdrawn in the late 50’s.
It was then sold, and taken to Bell road in Raumati on the Kapiti coast where it served as a beach hutt until the 80’s where it was donated to the Wellington tramway museum for display and eventual restoration.
2014 a conservation and restoration plan was put together, and the tram was shipped out to the Wheelwright Shop in the Wairarapa for a full body overhaul. It was transported back to the museum in 2017 and put on public display until new trucks (wheelsets) could be manufacturedby A&G price in Thames.
Since 2019 the tram has undergone new wiring, and extensive testing and running in and is now ready to take passengers along our museum.
Tram 17 is a wonderful achievement by all
Those involved, and we cannot wait to welcome you this Father’s Day to enjoy a ride on this heritage tram, saved from the scrap heap, and then saved again from rotting away.
Please note: We intend to run tram 17, however due to the nature and style of the tram, its operation is weather dependent. If we deem that the tram cannot run, we will advise accordingly.

description:
Wellington Decent Homes Town Hall, Join us for a discussion with Wellington City Council Mayoral candidates focused on how council can play its role in ensuring decent homes for all Wellingtonians.
Kai provided, with vegan and gf options.
Seating is available. The entrance has step-free access and a pull door. There is a wheelchair accessible bathroom with a heavy pull door. Staff will be available to assist with these before, during and after the event. If you have any questions about accessibility, you can contact Courtney either by email: courtney.ford@tearozerowaste.org.nz or by phone 021 280 1532.
Bike parking right outside 🚲
Bring your questions! Or, share your question with us ahead of the event here. We'll select a few questions that represent the most common themes.

description:
Saturday Laughs with Michael Macaulay and Lana Walters, Saturday Laughs is a comedy showcase with top Kiwi comedians from around the country, right in the heart of Wellington at Fringe Bar!

This month features headline act Lana Walters
Winner of the Billy T award, Lana is a fabulous standup comedian, television writer and improviser. A regular panelist on 7Days and The Project, you may have also seen her in the Best Foods Comedy Gala or The Great Comedy Debate. As well as all this, Lana is a mum of two young kids giving her endless material and sleepless nights.

With MC Michael Macaulay
Michael started in comedy in the late 90s, eventually winning the Becks Beer award for Best Newcomer at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in 2001. After a nearly 20 year hiatus he returned to comedy in a totally different country and having learned no life lessons at all.
Since then he has twice been nominated for ‘Best MC’, in the Welly Awards; won his own Welly in 2020 for being an all-round nice person; and performs up and down Aotearoa.

Also featuring
Gabby Anderson
Ralph Hilaga
and more!

description:
Tours of St Gerard's Church & Monastery - FULLY BOOKED, Tours of St Gerard's Church & Monastery - FULLY BOOKED
Find out what's behind the facade of this iconic building, one of the most recognisable in Wellington's landscape, and hear about its history.

Mount Victoria Historical Society is running tours in conjunction with St Gerard's Trust to give neighbours and visitors a chance to see the iconic monastery and now-deconsecrated church before seismic and renovation work commences. You will be guided through different areas of the monastery and the church, and learn about its history.


Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: Free
This event is fully booked.
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/tours-of-st-gerards-church-monastery/


Health & Safety:
There are stairs, so visitors need to be comfortable using these. Numbers are limited.

Join us at 7pm for a Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious evening of Quizney themed trivia at 1852 Pub & Kitchen, Wellington!
Sport your best costume, brush up on your movie knowledge (including Pixar) and get ready to put all those years of watching "Quizney" to good use. Oh, did we mention we're having a sing-a-long round where you'll need to remember the lyrics of your favourite song lyrics?
In true Gee Quiz fashion, we'll also have fantastically-fun bonus games including our legendary but stressful Alphabetical round, where your team will negotiate 26 fast-fire questions as the time tick down, plus Last Prince and Princess Standing and The Line Up!

description:
WINTER SERIES: Crop Swap Te Whanganui a Tara X Wellington Timebank, WINTER SERIES: Crop Swap Te Whanganui a Tara X Wellington Timebank
Crop Swap is a FREE heart-warming monthly community gathering to share what we have with each other. Think of it like a community garden potluck when each offering regardless of the amount adds up to a bounty.

Everyone is welcome - with or without something to share🌱

WHEN?
☕ Come along at 10:30am for a kōrero with our friendly community and enjoy free @Peoples coffee, usually with a scone or muffin that someone has brought along.
Swapping kicks off from 11.00am.

WHERE?
You can find us in the community room on the ground floor of block C of the Newtown Park Apartments, 320 Mansfield St, Newtown, Wellington.

IDEAS OF WHAT TO BRING
🧡Bring a friend!
🍪Maybe you like baking?
🍋 Surplus lemons?
🌱excess seedlings
📖 Have garden books or magazines to destash?
🥬Too much silver beet going crazy?
🫘Left over seeds from summer to share?
💐Got some foraged flowers?

Crop Swap is the place for you!
Note; giving isn't necessary but we do welcome koha of help / waiata / pūtea towards costs like room hire / milaka etc.

description:
Women’s Day of Action - Taitoko Levin, Women’s Day of Action - Taitoko Levin
Women’s Day of Action: Celebrating the women in our lives!

RSVP here: https://www.together.org.nz/wdoa_levin

132 years and one day after women secured the right to vote in Aotearoa, we are gathering again in strength and solidarity.

The Government gutted Pay Equity legislation that would have eased the cost of living and lifted pay of 182,000+ people. Across Aotearoa there will be activations to send a clear message: Pay equity is not optional. Our livelihoods should never be on the political chopping block.

Join us for a community friendly event for the whole family. There will be speeches from community leaders, kai, stalls, health checks and more!

When:11am-2pm
Where: Taitoko Levin Village Green - Corner of Queen and Salisbury Streets, Levin, Levin 5510

Wear: purple, green and white in honour of suffrage

Everyone is welcome – bring your whānau, friends and community 💜💚🤍

description:
Wellington Wizards Quiz Night Fundraiser, ✨ Quiz Night Fundraiser – Support the Wellington Wizards! ✨
Think you’ve got what it takes to be the ultimate quiz champion? Gather your team, put your knowledge to the test, and join us for a night of trivia, prizes, and fun—all while supporting the Wellington Wizards, a brand-new ultimate frisbee club!
📅 Date: Thursday, 2nd October, 2025
🕖 Time: 7pm - 9pm (Approximately)
📍 Location: 1852, 55 Cleveland St, Brooklyn
🧙 About the Wellington Wizards
We are a new ultimate frisbee club training to compete at the New Zealand Mixed Ultimate Championships Division 1—the highest level of competition in the country, held this year in Christchurch.
Our diverse, mixed-gender team includes high school students, university students, and young professionals, all passionate about the sport and eager to grow. As a brand-new club, we’re fundraising to cover essential costs like uniforms, training field hire, travel expenses, training camps, regional qualifiers, and the final tournament.

description:
Tram 17 Inauguration (Fathers Day 2025), Join us at the Wellington Tramway Museum as we put our latest restoration project into active service at the museum!
Tram 17 was built in 1904 by the Wellington City Council Tramways as a four wheeled box (Palace) style tram. By 1917 the system had grown and 17 was rebuilt into its current form adding a set of trucks converting the tram to 8 wheels. Tram tram saw regular service until the 1940’s where it was eventually use for peak time travel, before being withdrawn in the late 50’s.
It was then sold, and taken to Bell road in Raumati on the Kapiti coast where it served as a beach hutt until the 80’s where it was donated to the Wellington tramway museum for display and eventual restoration.
2014 a conservation and restoration plan was put together, and the tram was shipped out to the Wheelwright Shop in the Wairarapa for a full body overhaul. It was transported back to the museum in 2017 and put on public display until new trucks (wheelsets) could be manufacturedby A&G price in Thames.
Since 2019 the tram has undergone new wiring, and extensive testing and running in and is now ready to take passengers along our museum.
Tram 17 is a wonderful achievement by all
Those involved, and we cannot wait to welcome you this Father’s Day to enjoy a ride on this heritage tram, saved from the scrap heap, and then saved again from rotting away.
Please note: We intend to run tram 17, however due to the nature and style of the tram, its operation is weather dependent. If we deem that the tram cannot run, we will advise accordingly.

description:
AlterCOP30: Climate Fresk Workshop in Wellington, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd.
Donations are welcome to support climate education and action!
In solidarity with AlterCOP30, this November we’re running a series of climate events across Aotearoa - bringing communities together to learn, connect, and take action for a just and sustainable future.
AlterCOP is a Global Initiative founded by The Matcha Initiative and The Transmutation Principle, locally brought to you by Climate Club, Climate Crew, and Climate Training Co.

Botany Tours for Conservation Week at Te Papa, Come behind the scenes to visit the Botany collection which houses more than 300,000 plant specimens collected in Aotearoa New Zealand and overseas.
There are two tours available:
Tuesday 2nd September BOH 11.30 – 12.30pm
Thursday 4th September BOH 3.30 – 4.30PM
You will find out how we store and take care of these valuable collections, and the research they support. There will be a chance to see our precious botanical taonga, including botanical specimens and art, and have a closer look at the very first plants collected by the European naturalists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander over 250 years ago during Captain James Cook’s first voyage to New Zealand.

description:
Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026, Climate Action Week 2026 - Agenda
Dates: February 2026 - 23rd - 27th February
Theme: Leading by Doing: Local Businesses, Local Solutions, Collective Action
Each day features:
Morning: Local Business Story Sessions (Curated stories for our business community to get inspired with raw, honest and authentic stories)
Midday: Action Design Workshops (Crafting Plans & Solutions)
Afternoon: Immersion Experiences and Hands-On Field Visits (Applied Learning & Practical Support)
Day 1 - Water, Risk and Resilience 
Morning: Marlborough businesses facing water risks (horticulture, viticulture, manufacturing, nature, tourism) share adaptation stories: irrigation shifts, stormwater projects, water reuse innovations.
Midday: Business-specific water risks and trials of resilience-building solutions.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to diverse water initiatives across the region
Day 2 - Circular economy & waste
Morning: Circular leaders (including wine, food and beverages, building, construction, fisheries, nature) show how they have reduced waste, repurposed byproducts, or created new revenue streams from "waste."
Midday: Waste Challenge Mapping: Identify business-specific waste streams + select 1 trial action for next 6 months.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to waste initiatives and innovative approaches across the region
Day 3 - Nature and Biodiversity 
Morning: Farmers, viticulturists & landscapers share regenerative planting, biodiversity corridors, and ecosystem services initiatives.
Midday: Biodiversity on Your Site Toolkit Workshop — Co-design biodiversity plans for business properties (guided by local ecologists & farming leaders)
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to nature, land and biodiversity initiatives across the region.
Day 4 - Energy & Carbon
Morning: Businesses share their real decarbonisation journeys: EV transitions, renewable installations, process efficiencies — including the unexpected savings, costs and impacts.
Midday: Carbon Reduction Sprints — Design quick-win carbon actions + long-term projects with support from energy consultants and local peers.
Afternoon: Site visits to Carbon and Energy initiatives across the region
Day 5 - Taking the courage to act
Morning: Businesses share how they initiated climate actions, including failures, lessons, and unexpected wins.
Midday: Climate Action Map Workshop — Business leaders build their tailored action roadmaps (guided by peers + facilitators).
Afternoon: Immersion to unique businesses focussed on climate resilience
Immersion Experience Hosts Confirmed
Yealands Estate Winery
Carbonscape
Wineworks
Climate Action Marlborough has had the support of Yealands Estate Wines from its inception and we are super grateful to have their support for Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026. They are committed to influencing the Marlborough business community, driving collaboration that impacts climate resilience, education, health and wellbeing of a thriving region and growing our regions expertise.

Conservation Colouring Competition The Masterton Library is celebrating the importance of conservation with a colouring competition—and there are some great prizes up for grabs. There will also be an informative display featuring conservation-themed resources you’re welcome to take home with you.

Dr Marie Doole Biodiversity Funding Talk Dr Marie Doole will discuss the pros and cons around nature/biodiversity credits, an emerging option for funding the protection of biodiversity, particularly on private land, by investors, whether corporate or philanthropic. Worth attending if you've been following the media hype.

Think Like a Forest Film Forest and Bird are showing this film, starring Sam the Trap Man, in three locations. The Regent have generously offered to show it where it will have the most effect—on the big screen! The film is produced by Pure Advantage who have an aspirational programme around landscape-scale restoration of native forests called Recloaking Papatūānuku.

Kōkako Morning Hikoi Join us for a special one-off tour and experience the magic of the kōkako at Pūkaha. Follow our expert guide to a kōkako hotspot and enjoy the rare opportunity to possibly see and hear kōkako. After your walk, return to the centre for a hot drink and morning tea.

Waihinga Bridge Planting Morning Ruamāhanga Farm Foundation is hosting a morning of planting and a celebration of children's voices at the start of the soon to be opened Waihinga Bridge Walkway. Tools will be provided and all ages and abilities are welcome!

Exploring Ngahere Under Story and Campfire Talk The Tramping Gently Club Art Collective (TGCAC) takes up temporary residency at Te Whare Whakapapa Raranga to explore human-centred warning systems and ngahere's role in mitigating danger. Join us in bringing the understory into te whare through kōrero and creative exploration.
