description:
Thorburn 1K - Community Weeding Competition, Kia ora e te whanau!
We kick off the community weeding season with a competition: The Thorburn 1k. Evergreen buckthorn - or Rhamnus alaternus - is a big threat to te taiao on Te Raekaihau. It prevents native plants from establishing by forming dense stands of salt and wind tolerant bushes that grow on steep escarpments. Join us to help remove 1000 of these plants across two weeding sessions! A point schedule helps you to get motivated and compete for the highly coveted Thorburn 1k medal.
Please meet at the intersection of Te Ranga-a-Hiwi and Ruru tracks. We will provide tools and gloves but please bring your own if you have some. We will finish at the Alice Krebs lodge for hot drinks and kai and there will be time for community consultation.
In the event of bad weather forecast, the day will be moved forward to Saturday.

description:

BOWIE-OKE – David Bowie Karaoke 🎤

Calling all starmen, space oddities, and heroes (even if it’s just for one day) — it’s your time to shine! Step up to the mic and unleash your inner Ziggy.

💥 Venue: The Last Post Restaurant & Bar, 57 Fox St, Featherston RSA
💥 Date: Friday 26 September, 7.30 pm ‘til late

Dress loud, sing proud, and channel your favourite Bowie era — from glam and soul to Berlin cool or ‘90s brilliance. It’s karaoke, but make it Bowie. 🌟

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

☆ BOWIETOWN FEATHERSTON ☆
⚡Enter the Bowie universe!⚡

This September, Featherston transforms into BowieTown for the very first time – a full weekend celebrating the music, artistry, and magic of David Bowie. Expect live music, dance, creativity, food, and plenty of ways to let your inner Ziggy shine.
Event link https://www.facebook.com/share/1A1dp5NUzJ/

📅 Friday 26 – Sunday 28 September 2025
Featherston, Wairarapa


📍 Here’s what’s happening across the weekend 📍

⭐ Bowie-oke
Last Post Restaurant & Bar (Featherston RSA) 🎤 Friday 26 Sept, 7.30 pm ‘til late
Bowie karaoke to kick things off!
Event link https://www.facebook.com/share/1TdhZKFpvH/

Brac & Bow 🍸🍰 Friday 26 – Sunday 28 Sept
Sweet and stylish, Bowie-style.

30 Books Recommended by Bowie 📚 Friday 26 & Saturday 27 Sept.
Discover what the Thin White Duke read.

Featherston Library 🎨 Saturday 27 Sept, 10 – 11 am.
Kids (and big kids) welcome.


⭐ Bowie Barkers Dog Party
Dorset Square 🐾 Saturday 27 Sept, 11 am.
Walk & Bark + bring/swap/donate/buy dog gear. Hosted by Madame Mutts.


⭐ Bowie Art Bash + Portrait Exhibition
ANZAC Hal l🎨 Saturday 27 Sept 1 – 3 pm
Life drawing with Bowie models (bring your own gear), $10 cash entry. Plus a Bowie Portrait Exhibition with works for sale (free entry).


⭐ Bowie Pizzas
The Last Post Restaurant & Bar (Featherston RSA) 🍕 Saturday 27 Sept from 5 pm
Thin-crust Ziggy-style deliciousness!


⭐ BOWIE BLASTOFF CONCERT + AFTERPARTY
ANZAC Hall 🚀 Saturday 27 Sept 7 pm
Entry $20 (cash only, door sales)
Live performances from Mad Honey, The Davids, Taza Manaza, Tangle Dance Community, Justine Rose Kingdon, Fräulein Sylvia, and Hugo Del Mar.
Followed by the Blastoff Afterparty – put on your red shoes and dance, dance, dance to Bowie + beyond with DJ Nyx. (Alcohol-free event.)
Event link https://www.facebook.com/share/1GKm5wibcF/


⭐ The Davids Flashmob Dance
The Squircle (beside Featherston Fresh Choice Carpark) 💃 Sunday 28 Sept 1.30 pm.
Don’t miss this surprise Bowie moment!


⭐ Bowie Storytime with Penny Griffin
Chicken & Frog Bookshop 📖 Sunday 28 Sept, 2 pm
Bowie books read aloud for kids of all ages – with special guest star “Angus.”


⭐ Bowie Feast
At Brac & Bow 🍽️ Sunday 28 Sept 6 pm
Bowie Roast Dinners, Preprandial Bowie Cocktails, and Bowie-inspired Desserts.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

✨ Plus all weekend: check out Bowie-era books in Featherston Booktown and browse vintage Bowie bric-a-brac in local shops.


⚡ Featherston will NEVER be the SAME. Step inside the starman’s world — only at BowieTown 2025.

description:
Mostly Music Soundscape Series | The Weather Machine, Mostly Music Soundscape Series | The Weather Machine
The Weather Machine brings an electrifying blend of soulful longing, theatrical glam, and retro-nostalgic indie rock to the stage. Their live shows are dynamic and heartfelt, weaving together lush arrangements, unexpected instrumentation, and soaring vocal performances. With violin, sax, clarinet, and layered harmonies in the mix, audiences can expect a genre-blurring experience that feels both intimate and cinematic. Whether it’s a delicate folk tune or a full-throttle rock anthem, The Weather Machine delivers each moment with passion, precision, and a deep love for musical storytelling.

The Weather Machine began as the brainchild of Portland, Oregon songwriter Slater Smith. What started as a DIY indie-folk project in the city’s vibrant underground scene has since evolved into a professional, internationally touring band. Over the years, they’ve shared stages with acts like The Lumineers, Alabama Shakes, and Cold War Kids. In 2021, Smith relocated to Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Aotearoa, bringing the project with him and forming a new Wellington-based lineup. Now spanning two continents, The Weather Machine continues to expand its sound with a fresh, collaborative spirit.



About the Mostly Music Soundscape Series

A curated series of intimate live music experiences showcasing the depth, texture and emotion of sound. Each performance invites you to immerse yourself in a new soundscape, informed by genre, sonic craft, and music as an art form. Designed for music lovers who want more than a background soundtrack, this series celebrates live performance with a diverse range of acclaimed performers.

Saturday 21 June — Nick Granville Trio

Saturday 26 July — Seth Boy Trio

Saturday 30 August — Michelle Velvin Harpist

Saturday 20 September — The Weather Machine

Saturday 27 September — Rameka Tamaki

Saturday 25 October — Danica Bryant

Doors at 7:30pm, with events starting at 8pm. Each event will be 60—90 minutes in two sets.

These events will take place inside at The Bond Store, Paraparaumu and are seated with general admission. As a season pass holder you will be reserved seats near the front of the audience.

The Bond Store is located at 21 Birmingham Street, Paraparaumu. It operates as The Tasting Room which serves food and beverages.

With thanks to support from Creative NZ's Creative Communities Fund administered by Kāpiti Coast District Council.

description:
Carnival of Chaos, Myth, chaos, murder, alchemy, mystery, and devils are afoot in this four-night festival featuring six short retellings of classic works with strange new twists! We invite you to THEA 303’s ‘Carnival of Chaos’ in Studio 77, premiering hybrid works from the House of Echoes (1 & 3 October): The Odyssey, Medea and The Devil is a Lover, and the House of Secrets (2 & 4 October): Rope, The Taming of the Shrew  and  God’s Gift.

Each adaptation has been directed, designed, produced, choreographed and managed by the students.

House of Echoes (Season A): Performs on the 1st and the 3rd of October

The Odyssey – An adaptation of Homer’s The Odyssey
Odysseus just wants to get home to his true love, but the journey isn’t exactly smooth. The streets after 2 a.m. and too many beers are alive with obstacles; cops are grumpy, goth girls are tempting, and the help of the Gods is nowhere to be found. Meanwhile, back home, a dangerous polycule is getting cozy with his Penelope…

Medea – An adaptation of Euripides’ Medea
Medea lives her perfect 1950s white picket fence dream! When her husband starts taking new pills “Conservatol, the wonder drug for traditional love” she learns that traditional love means different to what she thought. Betrayal, hurt, and anger push her to the edge making her act in ways she never thought she would. “Heaven has no rage like love to hatred turned, nor Hell a fury like a woman scorned.”

The Devil is a Lover – An adaptation of William Shakespeare’s Love Labours Lost and Ben Johnson’s The Devil is an Ass
Satan and two devils, Beelzebub and Pug, make a pact to travel to a 1920s speakeasy on Earth and abstain from corruption for 3 years. As the narrative combines absurdist actions with Shakespearean dialogue, the three devils quickly learn of the difficulties present in avoiding corruption and the effect their devilish meddling has on humanity.

House of Secrets (Season B): Performs on the 2nd and 4th of October

Rope – An adaptation of Patrick Hamilton’s Rope (1929)
Not a whodunnit, but a howdoyahideit? Marion and Melanie are sure they’ve committed the perfect murder by killing their friend Norman and hiding his body in a chest, a chest their select group of friends have been invited over to have a murder mystery games night around. It’s foolproof, until the over analytical Constance comes to play…

The Taming of the Shrew – An adaptation of William Shakespeare’s Taming of the Shrew
In 1970's Aotearoa, sisters Katherina and Bianca find their love lives complicated by their father's order that one may not pursue romance unless the other follows suit. The sudden appearance of a charming factory owner and friend of Bianca's beau could mark a new hope for the two, but will this lead to an ocean of love or does something far more sinister lurk beneath the surface?

God’s Gift – An adaptation of Ben Johnson’s The Alchemist
The Carnival has come to town in 1615 London. Lovewit has gone to see the show, leaving her manor in the hands of Jeremy the Butler, the “Alchemist,” and Dol, a hardworking prostitute. Lovewit’s house becomes a place for schemes, with ample opportunities to take money from foolish men. Will Dol be happy with her split of the money? Or will a surprise visitor shake things up?

Content Forecast: mentions of and implied sexual violence and domestic abuse, mentions of drug use, strobe lighting, violence, coarse language, loud noises, haze, and smoke.
label: Festivals

description:
John Bishop | Wellington, John Bishop | Wellington
Comedy superstar John Bishop is set to return to Australia & New Zealand with his new show 25 Years Of Stand Up, to celebrate his incredible 25-year career.

John Bishop said: “I can’t believe that next year it will be 25 years since I first performed at the Frog and Bucket in Manchester. It’s been a rollercoaster! And I can’t thank the fans enough who have supported me all the way. I really hope you can come and celebrate with me.”

John has achieved huge success with a number of his own comedy, entertainment and documentary TV shows including: ‘John Bishop’s Australia’, ‘John Bishop’s Britain’; ‘John Bishop’s Only Joking’; ‘The John Bishop Show’ (BBC1); ‘The John
Bishop Christmas Show’ and ‘John Bishop’s Gorilla Adventure’, ‘John Bishop’s Ireland’ and four series of the critically acclaimed ‘John Bishop: In Conversation With…’ which saw him chatting one to one with some of the biggest names in entertainment, music and sport. Other TV credits include two series of ’The John Bishop Show’, ‘Doctor Who’ and the documentary John & Joe Bishop: Life After Deaf.

Last year, John starred in the UK & Ireland tour of Mother Goose with Ian McKellen, which included a hugely successful run in London’s West End.

‘John Bishop has taken on the mantle of Britain’s top comic…the funniest two hours you’ll have any time soon’ ★★★★★ Daily Mirror

‘Bishop has funny bones… everything is infused with his startlingly natural personality’ ★★★★The Times

description:
ChoctoberFest, Porirua is the home of New Zealand’s favourite chocolate — Whittaker's. So it's only fitting it has a festival celebrating all things chocolate. During September and October, the city is serving up a range of tasty treats for ChoctoberFest, all featuring Whittaker’s chocolate.
More than 30 local businesses will be competing in the Whittaker’s Bake Off and Top of the Chocs. Head in to participating spots, and try unique chocolate drinks and amazing baked goods. You can then vote for your favourites.
Indulge your tastebuds and try special drinks such as a whipped white choc biscoff latte, or a coldbrew shot choc maltini. For a sweet snack, how about a molten embrace, kunafa chocolate croissant, or a banoffee flossy pie? There are plenty of options for all chocolate lovers, including vegan and gluten free items.
As well as voting for your favourite items, you can join the fan club, share reviews, and be in to win. Up for grabs are 100 Whittaker’s Peanut Slabs, an exclusive tour of the Whittaker’s factory, and ChoctoberFest vouchers for local cafes and bars.
The festival has been running since 2022, and is a highlight of the local hospitality scene.

description:
Day of the Dead - Dia de los Muertos Celebration, Day of the Dead - Dia de los Muertos Celebration
¡Celebra con nosotros el Día de los Muertos con música, baile, comida tradicional y altares conmemorativos!

About this Event

Welcome to the Day of the Dead - Dia de los Muertos Celebration at AWHI Yoga & Wellbeing! Join us for a vibrant and colorful event filled with traditional live music, storytelling, rituals for remembering the dead and delicious prehispanic Mexican cacao drink. Honour your loved ones at our ofrenda, or altar, and learn more from our faciltator, Claudio Escutia, about this rich cultural tradition.
Let's come together to celebrate life and remember those who have passed in a joyful and meaningful way. Don't miss out on this special celebration!
What to Expect:
Cleansing copal and herbal welcoming.
An opening ceremony to acknowledge the Tlalmanalli (offering and altar) with the deep sound of the conch shell in the four directions and drums sounds.
History of the day of the dead celebration.
Explanation of the altar, and the main elements for an ofrenda.
Storytelling: learn of Mexican legends like Catrinas and Xoloitzcuintle (the Mexican dog that helps the dead to find their way to Mictlan, the Aztec underword).
Remembering and sharing histories about the loved ones that passed away (optional but encouraged) 
Traditional Mexican chants for remembering the loved ones 
Atole de Chocolate, a traditional prehispanic drink - amazing in flavour, consumed cold or hot
Music to invoke emotion and imagery of contemplative natural and mystical environments
Finish with a shamanic atmosphere of relaxation and traditional chants.
label: Festivals

description:
Dancesplash 2025, ArtSplash is a week-long festival, held every two years, that celebrates tāmariki and rangatahi experiencing performance on the big stage in dance and choir concerts. This year, we have two separate groups performing – one at ArtSplash and the other at DanceSplash.
Mrs Long and Mr Graff have a hard-working troupe of dancers training to perform on Thursday 28 August at the 5pm show, held at the Opera House.
This is a new venue for the show, what a treat! This group will be heading into town by 8:15am for the dress rehearsal, before returning to school to catch their breath. They’ll head back in together on the bus and will be ready to head home with their spectator parents at the conclusion of the show. Watch this space for more details and how you can help.
Tickets are now on sale. You can purchase them via the Ticketmaster website. NOTE: Due to limited seating and a high number of schools involved, there is a limit of TWO tickets per performer. Don’t miss out!

description:
Day of the Dead Celebration - Dia de los Muertos, Join Claudio for this special occasion we will be celebrating one of the most important holidays in Mexico, the day of the dead or “Dia de los Muertos”.

The Day of the Dead is one of the traditions that has remained alive throughout the centuries; the main holidays are November 1 & 2, which UNESCO designated and cataloged as an Intangible Heritage of Humanity in 2003.

This special celebration dates back to prehispanic times before the arrival of Europeans to America, and has been alive and widely celebrated over the years.

Expect:

Cleansing copal and herbal welcoming.

An opening ceremony to acknowledge the Tlalmanalli (offering and altar) with the deep sound of the conch shell in the four directions and drums sounds.

History of the day of the dead celebration.

Explanation of the altar, and the main elements for an ofrenda.

Storytelling: learn of Mexican legends like Catrinas and Xoloitzcuintle (the Mexican dog that helps the dead to find their way to Mictlan, the Aztec underword).

Remembering and sharing histories about the loved ones that passed away (optional but encouraged)

Traditional Mexican chants for remembering the loved ones

Atole de Chocolate, a traditional prehispanic drink - amazing in flavour, consumed cold or hot

Music to invoke emotion and imagery of contemplative natural and mystical environments

Finish with a shamanic atmosphere of relaxation and traditional chants.
label: Festivals

description:
Dasara and Bathukamma, *
Dussehra / Bathukamma Festival Invitation – 2025!
*
*Dear WTCF Friends & Family,*
We are delighted to invite you to the 2025 Dussehra / Bathukamma Festival Celebration! Let’s come together to honour our vibrant traditions and rich cultural heritage — followed by a delicious dinner sponsored by WTCF.
Event Details
*Date* : Saturday, 4th October 2025
*Time* : 5:00 PM to 9:00 PM
*Event Begins* : Sharp at 5:00 PM – Please arrive on time to take part in all the festivities!
*Food* : Pure Vegetarian
*Dinner* : Served from 7:30 PM onwards
*Venue* : Amesbury School Community Hall
48 Amesbury Drive, Churton Park, Wellington 6037
The celebrations will begin promptly at 5:00 PM.
We kindly request everyone to arrive on time, so you don’t miss any of the festive fun and vibrant traditions we have planned!
Tickets (Includes Dinner):
Single Ticket – $15
Family– $35
Dinner will be provided and sponsored by WTCF as part of the celebration.
(No need to bring a dish this time — just come and enjoy!)
Dress Code:
Traditional attire is encouraged! Let’s light up the evening in colourful sarees, lehengas, and kurta sets.
About the Festivals:
Dussehra – Celebrates the victory of good over evil, symbolizing strength, virtue, and righteousness.
Bathukamma – A floral festival dedicated to Goddess Gauri, celebrating femininity, nature, and togetherness.
Enjoy a joyful evening filled with:
Cultural performances
Music & dance
Delicious traditional food
Community bonding
Please RSVP by 1 October 2025:
https://forms.gle/wBqjRHPgfMUFaLPF9
Looking forward to celebrating with you all!
*Warm Regards,*
WTCF Team

description:
Eastbourne Garden Show, Step into a world of six acclaimed private gardens each a living canvas of colour, design and inspiration from lush natives to sculpted landscapes. Each garden tells a story and provides a visual image of wonderful creations.
One garden, allegedly with the best vista, has not been opened to the public before. One garden has previously featured in the House and Garden magazine. The tour (self-guided) will begin with lunch and an opportunity to buy potted plants in the tranquil St Alban's church garden, 11 Ngaio St Eastbourne, Lower Hutt, Wellington. The tour will end with hors d'oeuvre, wine and live music in the last garden.
This is a chance not just to visit amazing gardens but support the earthquake strengthening of St Alban's historic church and hall for a rejuvenated community hub.
St Albans church garden
The six private gardens all lie within a less than 100 m walk of the 83 Metlink Marine Parade bus route, but a car or bicycle would be more convenient.
A glimpse of the six separate gardens (a-e).
a
a
b
c
d
e
f
f
The garden show is in support of earthquake strengthening of the de Jersey Clere designed St Alban's church and adjacent hall to remake this a community hub.
For the last hundred years and more, this beautiful church designed by acclaimed architect Frederick de Jersey Clere has been the heart of Anglican parish life for people in the eastern bays of Wellington. People have rejoiced, prayed and wept in it through happy family milestones and sad occasions, through two world wars and countless celebrations and crises. Along with its parish hall and tranquil garden, it has been the base for social and community services and outreach, and its memorial wall houses the ashes of local residents.
But in 2016 the congregation had to suddenly leave the church, which was deemed an earthquake risk.
Since then, the parish has explored alternatives for continuing its life and service to the people of the eastern bays. In that process it has kept its ministry and worship going through borrowed premises in local schools and other churches. Now, however, the parish has decided it needs to go back to its original base and strengthen both St Alban’s Church and the parish hall so it can continue to serve the community from its heart and home in Ngaio Street, for the next hundred years and more.
Detailed plans for strengthening the church and hall to meet acceptable safety standards have been drawn up, and fund-raising is under way. The parish is a registered charity (CC22188) and tax-deductible receipts will be issued for all donations.
Postponement by 1 day to 30 Nov if weather were to dictate and would be announced on this web site.

description:
Day of the Dead Celebration - Dia de los Muertos, Join Claudio for this special occasion we will be celebrating one of the most important holidays in Mexico, the day of the dead or “Dia de los Muertos”.

The Day of the Dead is one of the traditions that has remained alive throughout the centuries; the main holidays are November 1 & 2, which UNESCO designated and cataloged as an Intangible Heritage of Humanity in 2003.

This special celebration dates back to prehispanic times before the arrival of Europeans to America, and has been alive and widely celebrated over the years.

Expect:

Cleansing copal and herbal welcoming.

An opening ceremony to acknowledge the Tlalmanalli (offering and altar) with the deep sound of the conch shell in the four directions and drums sounds.

History of the day of the dead celebration.

Explanation of the altar, and the main elements for an ofrenda.

Storytelling: learn of Mexican legends like Catrinas and Xoloitzcuintle (the Mexican dog that helps the dead to find their way to Mictlan, the Aztec underword).

Remembering and sharing histories about the loved ones that passed away (optional but encouraged)

Traditional Mexican chants for remembering the loved ones

Atole de Chocolate, a traditional prehispanic drink - amazing in flavour, consumed cold or hot

Music to invoke emotion and imagery of contemplative natural and mystical environments

Finish with a shamanic atmosphere of relaxation and traditional chants.

description:
Secure Development Training - September 2025, Have you been to a Kawaiicon and found yourself realising that you want to know more? Are you a curious developer who wants to know what happens if you prod a web application? Are you a QA looking to take the worst path possible through an app?
Maybe the PrivSec Secure Development Training is for you!
Agenda
The training is a one day course consisting of the following:
A detailed overview of the OWASP Top Ten Web Application vulnerabilities.
Multiple real world examples and case studies of exploited vulnerabilities.
Hands on experience exploiting these vulnerabilities on a custom web application
Techniques and tooling to identify and exploit these bug classes, using both source code analysis and dynamic testing techniques.
Remediation steps and techniques to mitigate and avoid these issues.
Outcomes
By the end of the day, you will have an understanding of tools and techniques used to compromise web applications and hands on experience in exploiting multiple vulnerabilities in the OWASP top ten.
About the Trainer
Training will be led by one of our Senior consultants, Jack Moran and supported by Sriram Jayaraman
Jack is a Senior Consultant at PrivSec Consulting. He has worked in the offensive security space for the better part of a decade, focusing on web and mobile application testing, along with code reviews and security configuration reviews. He has a number of CVEs credited to himself, and his enthusiasm towards security security is infectious.
Sriram is an ex-developer, turned security consultant. He has a strong background in web application penetration testing, along with code review. He has familiarity with several programming and scripting languages and frameworks such as Python, Javascript, PHP, Node.js, Angular and React.
Notes for the Day
Lunch and snacks will be provided. We will teach you how to hack.

description:
Family Grave Day 2025 - Wellington, Family Grave Day 2025 - Wellington
The world’s biggest family-friendly rave just got haunted… and Wellington, we’re coming for YOU! 👻

This is not your average Halloween party – it’s a full-blown Halloween rave for the whole family, packed with banging beats, dazzling performers, and spooky surprises at every turn. Whether you’re a mini-monster or a grown-up ghoul, get ready for an afternoon of music, mayhem, and memories you’ll never forget. Costumes are highly encouraged – the more outrageous, the better!

Date & Time: Saturday 15th November, 1PM – 4PM
Location The Hunter Lounge

🎟 Tickets
First Release - SOLD OUT!
Second Release - ON SALE NOW

👉 https://megatix.com.au/events/FGDWELL25


👻 WHAT TO EXPECT:

🧛‍♀️ All-Ages Family Rave – Dress to impress in your spookiest costumes for maximum Halloween fun!

🏢 Prime City Venue – The Hunter Lounge is easy to get to with great parking and public transport links.

🎶 Club DJs & Performers – International DJs dropping trance, techno & nostalgic bangers, plus stilt walkers, jugglers, and spine-tingling roaming performers!

🔇 Silent Disco & Sensory Zone – Pop on your headphones and dance in spooky silence, or chill out in our sensory space.

🕷️ Spooky Interactive Fun – Inflatables, Halloween-themed games, arts & crafts, face painting, and more!

🍕 Frightfully Good Food – Delicious restaurant meals available onsite to keep the ghouls fed.

🥂 Adult Beverages Available – Enjoy a drink while the kids rave (responsibly, of course).

💀 Immersive Halloween Atmosphere – Expect haunted lighting, eerie decor, and special effects that’ll transport you to the other side.

🧙‍♀️ Giveaways & Surprises – Don’t miss your chance to rave beyond the grave… and win!

⚡ Spots are limited – secure your tickets before they vanish into the night! ⚡

Love. Laughter. Gin. This is Valentine’s Day — the GinFlatables way.

Kapiti’s most unique adults-only (18+) festival is back — and this time, it’s bringing the love! The last GinFlatables SOLD OUT in under 24 hours, so don’t wait to grab your tickets. (On Sale From 1st November).

Brought to you by Kapiti Castles, on Saturday 14 February 2026, The Bond Store Distillery will transform into a giant playground for grown-ups. Bounce, race, and joust your way through epic inflatables, giant games, and laugh-out-loud moments.

Your ticket includes a FREE drink to kickstart the night, plus live DJs pumping high-energy tunes to keep you dancing all evening. Whether you’re coupled up, flying solo, or out with your crew, this is the Valentine’s event for fun-lovers.

description:
Great Sounds Great Festival 2025, Eyegum Music Collective presents GREAT SOUNDS GREAT, a multi-venue music and arts festival taking over Pōneke's Cuba Street precinct for one night only on Saturday 6 September 2025. Showcasing 40 of Aotearoa's best artists across 10 neighbouring venues, this is one big party you shouldn't miss.

Eyegum has worked hard to curate a programme that is sure to offer something for everyone, from first time gig-goers to seasoned live music obsessives. The eclectic lineup includes perennial indie maestros The Bats, capital hometown heroes The Phoenix Foundation, hip hop superstar JessB, troubadour-turned-party starter Anthonie Tonnon, captivating genre-bender Reb Fountain, the incredible local-by-way-of-Naarm Jen Cloher, plus a selection of up-and-coming artists handpicked from Eyegum's Free Wednesday weekly showcase series, and everything in between. There will also be plenty more to be announced soon.

Excitingly for 2025, we will be adding three new venues: St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records and 13 Garrett Street (sponsored by Radio Active), as well as a travelling electronic stage curated by Tonic Collective. This means more artists and music to experience in a variety of special and unique spaces throughout the night.

Ticket holders will receive a wristband that will give them access to each of the participating venues throughout the event. Information on how to pick up wristbands will be provided to ticket holders closer to the time.

Tickets are on sale now at eyegum.co.nz/great-sounds-great

When: from 4pm Saturday 6 September 2025
Where: San Fran, Meow, Valhalla, Rogue & Vagabond, Bedlam & Squalor, Hotel Bristol (2 stages), St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records, 13 Garrett St

Who: The lineup will include Anthonie Tonnon, Baby Zionov, Bad Taste, BADTAB, Baeoli, Bathysphere, The Bats, By A Damn Sight, Cindy, Eveline Breaker, Goya, Half/Angel, Hans Pucket, Iris Little, Jazmine Mary, Jen Cloher, JessB, JHL, Jim Nothing, Jordan Hamel, Leah Dodd, LEAO, Louisa Nicklin, The Phoenix Foundation, Reb Fountain, Rebecca Hawkes, Shayne P Carter (solo), Sig Wilder & Friends, Sofia Machray, Space Bats, Attack!, The Spectre Collective: live-scored cinema, Star Time, plus more artists to be announced soon.

description:
Cushion Concert with The Lighthouse Trio, IAS Cushion Concerts presents local bands in the intimate environment of historic Inverlochy House. Join us as The Light House Trio explores some new interpretations of familiar melodies and unheard compositions! The trio will play original arrangements of favourite tunes as well as come brand new original songs. Expect mysterious ballads, soulful blues, and exhilarating bop.

The Lighthouse Trio is made up of three of Wellington's busiest players; Alex Trask, Jeremy Grant, and Elijah Mulheron. Alex is a highly regarded alto saxophonist who is seen all around town leading bands and playing for some of the leading musical organisations, including the RNZAF band and formerly the Rodger Fox Big Band. Elijah is the busiest bassist in town and often appears with Wellington legends such as Callum Allardice and John Rae. Jeremy is an extremely captivating guitarist and the creative force behind the arrangements you will hear.

The trio is celebrating the release of their debut EP with a tour of their own backyard, playing for the first time in Pito-one and Raumati, and finishing with a gig in central Wellington. Come along for an evening of fresh music presented in a relaxed setting, we hope to see you there!

https://www.facebook.com/share/1CAASvj8fd/

Free entry for tamariki and no worries if cushion's aren't your thing - we have chairs!

Ngā mihi nui to our friends at Wellington City Council for sponsoring our 2025 Cushion Concert series. This helps ensure artists are paid a living wage for their performance. Seventy five percent of all ticket proceeds go directly to the artists.

description:
Heritage Festival - Self-guided Tour of Truby King Park, Discover the hidden history of Truby King Park—scan, stroll, and uncover stories with your smartphone.

Step into a garden full of stories, some inspiring, some surprising. From cherry trees and hospital wards to the people who shaped New Zealand’s early healthcare, follow the QR trail to uncover the layers of Truby King Park’s past.

Health & Safety
This is a self-guided experience. Please explore within your limits. Wear good shoes and dress for the weather.

Parts of the park may be cordoned off for your safety. Please respect the cordons. Paths and steps may be slippery when wet.

Any time during the festival
18 Oct - 9 Nov 2025
Daily, dawn til dusk
Free

description:
Bikespace - Road Ready Workshop, With the arrival of Spring what better time to get your bike ready for the road.
We’re continuing our series of one hour workshops targeted at those who want to learn a bit more about how their bike works and how to maintain & repair it to keep it running at its best.
This workshop is more general than some of our other more topic specific sessions. We will cover:
* Road Readiness. A front to back check for safety and performance
* Drivetrain tuning and maintenance
* Brake tuning and maintenance
* Tyres & Tubes. Pressures and repair.
Sunday, September 21st from 9:00am to 10:00am at the Bikespace workshop.
We'll spend most of the hour with interactive learning followed by time to work on individuals bicycles. To allow hands-on participation we are limiting the numbers to this workshop to 8 people and their bikes. Please indicate in the comments if you would like to attend and we will confirm attendees for this session.
We have a number of people indicate interest and then not attend the session. Please make every effort to attend if you sign up.
Due to our lack of covered outdoor space there is always the possibility that we have to reschedule if the weather is really uncooperative.
Bikespace is a Wellington City Council initiative allowing us to offer all our services at no cost to participants.

description:
Japanese Film Festival Upper Hutt 2025, The Embassy of Japan, in cooperation with the Japan Foundation, is very pleased to announce the return of the Japanese Film Festival to Upper Hutt!

The Japanese Film Festival is an annual event held to encourage the growth of Japanese culture and understanding in New Zealand. Each year, we try to give the people of New Zealand some insight into the culture, customs, and traditions of Japan, alongside what is popular with Japanese society today, through film.

Please refer to the details at our website.

Wellington, Whirinaki Whare Taonga: 11-12 October 2025
*Bookings required via the Japanese Film Festival 2025 website above.

Film Schedule
(11 Oct 2025)
10:30-12:30 　What Did You Eat Yesterday? (120mins), 2021, Drama, Rating: G
13:00-15:10 Hit Me Anyone One More Time (127mins), 2019, Comedy, Rating:PG

description:
Integrating Creative Writing Into Painting - 4 Week Course, Creative writing and painting are both powerful forms of artistic expression. By integrating creative writing into your painting practice, you can enhance your imagination, storytelling abilities, emotional expression, attention to detail, and personal style on the canvas. Please bring along a journal or laptop.

COURSE CONTENT
Each session presents a key idea backed by research or concrete examples, followed by practical writing exercises with optional sharing. We learn by doing and from each other.

1. Generating work from the interior: tapping into memories, conflict, emotion, and observation to generate art.
2. Figuring out what matters to you, then learning how to grow your fragmented ideas into something whole. For example, how do you turn a feeling, or a fleeting moment in time into a story? Into a painting? Into a work of art? What are the building blocks you need?
3. Inspiration from other creative sources: people, music, poetry, reading, random incidents. Ways to generate fresh ideas. How to clarify and focus in writing and art.
4. Structure and boundaries. Dreaming big but being real. How do you find and stick to a creative process? Understanding how you learn and what kind of feedback you need. Designing your next project.

Thursday mornings, 9:30 - 11:45 am.
4 - 25 September.

description:
Irish Cultural Festival, Irish Cultural Festival
Join the Fun at the Community Cultural Festival! 🍀

Get ready for an unforgettable afternoon of celebration, culture, and community spirit!

The Hutt Valley Irish Society invites you to a lively Community Cultural Festival filled with the heart and soul of Irish tradition—and plenty of fun for everyone.

🎶 Live Irish Music to get your toes tapping
💃 Traditional Irish Dance performances that will amaze and inspire
🏐 Irish Sports Demos—give Gaelic games a go!
🍞 Soda Bread Making—watch, learn, and taste! Have a go for koha!
🧒 Children's Activities—face painting, crafts, and games galore
🧬 Genealogy Info Booth—trace your roots and explore your heritage

Whether you've got Irish roots or just a love for good craic, there's something for all ages at this community celebration. Entry is free—bring your friends, family, and your dancing shoes!

Don't miss out—let's make it a day to remember!

Thanks to sponsor support from- Hutt Mana Charitable Trust and the Wellington Irish Community Trust and all the participating groups that are going to make this day.

description:
Kaiwhakaataata Māra - Garden Performers, Keep your eyes and ears open for pop-up performances scattered across two of Wellington’s most beautiful gardens. Talented artists will appear spontaneously as you wander through Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush and the Botanic Garden ki Paekākā, bringing music, storytelling, and theatre to life in unexpected places for Te Wā o te Kōanga, Spring Festival 2025.

Botanic Garden ki Paekākā - Love Birds
Brought to you by the Shakespeare Globe Centre New Zealand
Join us at Puriri Lawn for interactive readings celebrating Shakespeare and spring at 11:30am and 2:30pm, with roaming performers delighting visitors in between.
Come dressed to impress for our bird costume competition, with judging at 12pm and 3pm following the readings. Feathers, colours, and creativity encouraged!


Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush - Meet the Moa
With String Bean Puppets
Come meet Nunu, the friendly moa puppet! Nunu will be roaming the garden during two special sessions: 11:00–11:45am and 12:15–1:00pm. Feed him some leaves, give him a cuddle, and enjoy this fun, interactive experience bringing Wellington’s prehistoric past to life.

description:
Kaiwhakaataata Māra | Garden Performers, Kaiwhakaataata Māra | Garden Performers
Keep your eyes and ears open for pop-up performances scattered across two of Wellington’s most beautiful gardens. Talented artists will appear spontaneously as you wander through Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush and the Botanic Garden ki Paekākā, bringing music, storytelling, and theatre to life in unexpected places for Te Wā o te Kōanga, Spring Festival 2025.


Botanic Garden ki Paekākā - Love Birds
Brought to you by the Shakespeare Globe Centre New Zealand
Join us at Puriri Lawn for interactive readings celebrating Shakespeare and spring at 11:30am and 2:30pm, with roaming performers delighting visitors in between.

Come dressed to impress for our bird costume competition, with judging at 12pm and 3pm following the readings. Feathers, colours, and creativity encouraged!


Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush - Meet the Moa
With String Bean Puppets
Come meet Nunu, the friendly moa puppet! Nunu will be roaming the garden during two special sessions: 11:00–11:45am and 12:15–1:00pm. Feed him some leaves, give him a cuddle, and enjoy this fun, interactive experience bringing Wellington’s prehistoric past to life.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:
Irish Cultural Festival, Irish Cultural Festival
Join the Fun at the Community Cultural Festival! 🍀

Get ready for an unforgettable afternoon of celebration, culture, and community spirit!

The Hutt Valley Irish Society invites you to a lively Community Cultural Festival filled with the heart and soul of Irish tradition—and plenty of fun for everyone.

🎶 Live Irish Music to get your toes tapping
💃 Traditional Irish Dance performances that will amaze and inspire
🏐 Irish Sports Demos—give Gaelic games a go!
🍞 Soda Bread Making—watch, learn, and taste! Have a go for koha!
🧒 Children's Activities—face painting, crafts, and games galore
🧬 Genealogy Info Booth—trace your roots and explore your heritage

Whether you've got Irish roots or just a love for good craic, there's something for all ages at this community celebration. Entry is free—bring your friends, family, and your dancing shoes!

Don't miss out—let's make it a day to remember!

Thanks to sponsor support from- Hutt Mana Charitable Trust and the Wellington Irish Community Trust and all the participating groups that are going to make this day.

description:
Jazz Festival: Free Status, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Free Status is a jazz fusion band, drawing melodic inspiration from iconic artists like Herbie Hancock and 70s jazz/funk legends with electronic flair inspired by artists like Moby.

At the heart of Free Status is Tommy David on keys, an accomplished musician/composer in the early stages of his career. He has earned recognition in numerous jazz competitions and supported legendary rock acts such as Dire Straits Legacy Band, Nazareth, Hello Sailor, and plays with popular rockabilly band, Recliner Rockers. With composition at the center of his artistry, he can't wait to share the exciting and genuine compositions he has created.

The rhythm section features Behzad Karakia (drums) and Tyler Diprose (bass), both veterans of performances with many of New Zealand's jazz greats.

On lead alto sax is James Dawes, recently selected for an international touring band on a year-long cruise. His versatility extends well beyond jazz.

On keys is Sam Voyle, whose primary instrument is tenor saxophone. Performing with Tommy since their school days, he has built a strong musical bond that has led to major appearances, including the America's Cup main stage and high-profile corporate events.

On vocals is Melody Lui-Webster, an award-winning singer and accomplished musical theatre performer and actor, with numerous professional stage and television roles.

Thank you for watching!
label: Festivals

description:
Keep Hush X Twisted Frequency | Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, Keep Hush X Twisted Frequency | Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington
Twisted Frequency is teaming up with Keep Hush to bring a slice of Aotearoa’s outdoor festival culture into the city and broadcast to the world.

For the uninitiated, Keep Hush started as an intimate underground club night in London and has grown into a global platform celebrating underground dance music through live streams, pop-ups, and parties in unexpected places.

These folks have such a fantastic kaupapa that resonates deeply with what we are doing down here in Aotearoa and we couldn't be more stoked to work with them and share a bit of the Twisted community's creative passion with the world.

Featuring a carefully selected lineup of talent who are dedicated to creating original homegrown tunes, all representing a unique aspect of the country’s bass music melting pot. This will be a journey of sound from dub-infused taonga pūoro to home mulled jungle breaks and all stops between.

description:
Martinborough Music Festival 2025, Bringing the world to Martinborough for chamber music in the heart of South Wairarapa.

Join us for four exciting concerts over three days, featuring stunning New Zealand and international artists including Natalia Lomeiko (violin), Yuri Zhislin (violin/viola), Matthias Balzat and Ashley Brown (cello), Jian Liu (piano), Wilma Smith and Donald Armstrong (violin), Simon Brew (saxophone) and Caroline Henbest (viola).

These artists will bring to life extraordinary works including Zoltán Kodály's Duo for Violin and Cello, Op. 7; JS Bach's Goldberg Variations for string trio; Shostakovich's Piano Quintet in G minor, Op. 57 and Mozart's String Quintet No. 5 in D major, K.593.

The Sunday afternoon concert will also include the world premiere of Shifting Worlds, a piano quintet by renowned New Zealand composer Louise Webster, who has special ties with South Wairarapa.

Visit martinboroughmusicfestival.co.nz for more information about artists, programmes and links to ticket sales.
label: Festivals

description:
LAUNCHING Season 7 of Seeds to Feeds!, LAUNCHING Season 7 of Seeds to Feeds!
It’s time to prepare for the spring and summer ahead, join us for a meal of celebration and of planning.

We’ll share a delicious celebration meal, made with fresh, locally sourced produce, showcasing dishes that we hope will inspire menus for future harvest Celebrations.

We’ll gather together at 6 pm and spend some time getting connected and inspired.

Dinner will be served at 6.50 pm

After dinner, we will see if we can draw up some ideas, brainstorm resources and garden plans and then look at what your Harvest Festival event might be in March.

We will finish with cake (our favourite) and information on what the next steps will be.

If you are still not sure what Seeds to Feeds is all about, come join us. This is a great way to find out what will be happening in your area and how you can be involved.

RSVP’s essential so we know who we are cooking for x

description:
Light Party at the Esplanade, Light Party at the Esplanade
Join us for Palmy's annual Light Party at the Esplanade!


This fun, free event is perfect for the whole family. We invite you for an evening packed with live music, performances, a free sausage sizzle, bouncy castles, face-painting, lolly bags and much more!


We're also excited to announce the return of the 'Light Train'! It just gets better every year! Don't miss the opportunity to ride the Esplanade Scenic Railway throughout the evening. Tickets will be $2 per person (under 2s free).


And for those looking to buy dinner or a treat we will have a line-up of local food trucks ready to serve you throughout the event.


We can't wait to see you there!


5PM-9PM Saturday 01 November at the carpark next to the Scenic Railway Station.


In case of wet weather, our alternative venue will be at Gateways Christian Fellowship (located across from the Warehouse on Church Street).

description:
NZ Brewers Fest - Monster Mash, NZ Brewers Fest - Monster Mash
🦇A Day of Decadence, Darkness and Delights 🕷️

Join us from midday until the shadows stretch long, as Brewtown transforms into a haunted haven of unholy delights for NZ Brewers Fest 2025 – Monster Mash!

🍻Fiendishly good Beer!
It wouldn’t be NZBF without great beer, and this year 20 of Aotearoa’s best breweries will descend on Brewtown to pour every style you could possibly desire, from crisp Lagers, cold IPAs and hoppy Pale Ales, to funky Sours, smoky Porters, rich Pastry Stouts – and everything in between!

Visit Brewtown’s own custom Unimog Bar for 13 beers handpicked by our craft beer experts, but get in quick – we only have 1 keg of each, and they won’t last long!

🍸Haunting Spirits & Wine!
New for this year! Step into our haunted cocktail bar for some seriously spooky spirits! Our mixologists have been hard at work creating some devilishly delicious drops just for you.

We’re bringing in some of the best wines the Wairarapa has to offer, so whether you prefer a crisp Sauv, a fruity Pinot or a refreshing Frosé there will be something to enjoy.

Still not enough for you? Then head down to the Everything Else Bar, for NZ crafted ciders, as well as bourbon, rum, gin and vodka alongside a range of low and no alcohol beers, cocktails and soft drinks.

🌮Monstrously Good Kai!
The NZBF food court hosts the region’s top foodies, bringing you big, bold, flavour-packed festival eats that’ll satisfy both the living and the undead.
Watch this space as we announce our festive foodie lineup!

⚔️Enthralling Entertainment!
Lose yourself in a cabaret of the bizarre, where the performances are as dark as they are dazzling. Expect sultry burlesque, twisted characters and moments that will thrill, chill, and have you begging for more.

Witness the brutal thrill of buhurt armoured combat, as warriors face off in full medieval kit in a raw display of might and mayhem.

Dance the day away at the main stage, as Welly’s top talent smash out tune after tune, all building up to a headline show from Brewtown favourites, The Blueprint – as they bring a special set just for Monster Mash! Trust us, you haven’t seen them like this before…

Grab your mates and get stuck in at the Games Zone, where a bit of friendly rivalry meets festive fun, and the loser buys the next round.

Enjoy dressing up? Go all out in your most terrifying, theatrical or jaw-dropping costume — and you might just take out the crown in our epic Best Dressed Competition, with spooky-good prizes up for grabs.

With affordable return coaches from Welly and Petone and great discounts for group tickets it's scarily easy to get involved!
🎃 R18

description:
NZ Mountain Film Festival 2025 - Awards Night, A collection of New Zealand-made mountain films - brought to you by the Vic Uni Tramping Club, Wellington Tramping and Mountaineering Club, and of course the New Zealand Mountain Film and Book Festival!

Awards Night: Thursday 25 Sep (doors open at 6:00pm, films start at 6:30pm):

- Footprints on Katmai (22 mins) Max Romey, USA. Following his grandmother's footsteps to one
of the most remote and bear-strewn beaches in Alaska, painter Max Romey discovers that an
ocean of problems is closer to home than he could have imagined. BEST FILM ON THE ENVIRONMENT
- Alone Across Gola (20 mins) Jude Kriwald, UK, NZ Premiere. Stranded in Liberia’s Gola
rainforest, filmmaker Jude Kriwald faces hunger, isolation, robbery and disappearing trails. A raw
tale of one man’s solo, self-filmed journey chasing a childhood dream. With only a bike and a
tent, Jude pushes the limits of survival and self-discovery. BEST ADVENTUROUS SPORTS & LIFESTYLES
- Zahir (36 mins) Julien Nadiras, Switzerland, subtitles. Katherine and Eline take on an iconic rock
route, accessing it by bike. Their all-eco ascent tests endurance, nerve, and friendship, with long
runouts and tiny holds pushing them to the edge.
- Body of a Line (10 mins) Henna Taylor, subtitles, USA. A cleverly animated short film that
morphs into real life as Madaleine undertakes an intimate and creative journey to climb a difficult
rock route, with original music and poetry. BEST SHORT FILM
- Trango (46 mins) Leo Hoorn, USA. After a two-year attempt, ski mountaineers ski the first
descent of the Great Trango Glacier. They navigate risk, grapple with grief, and face physical
danger as they push the limits of human experience. Unspoken trust and support within their
expedition team allows them to face the unimaginable together. GRAND PRIZE FILM

Total running time: 120 minutes + 15 minute intermission.
label: Festivals

description:
NZ Mountain Film Festival 2025 - Pure NZ Night, A collection of New Zealand-made mountain films - brought to you by the Vic Uni Tramping Club, Wellington Tramping and Mountaineering Club, and of course the New Zealand Mountain Film and Book Festival!


Pedals To Powder (28 mins) Nick Kowalski, NZ. Two women cycle to every ski field in Aotearoa
in one wild season, braving storms and exhaustion—uncovering a hidden world of independent
ski culture along the way.
All in or Nothing (24 mins) Gordon Duff, NZ. Up against 120 riders with full support crews, a
young athlete only has himself to rely on. Follow his gruelling six days as he attempts to win the
overall title at the NZ MTB Rally. BEST DOCUMENTARY
Riverbound - The Storybook Has Just Begun (13 mins) Dylan Gerschwitz & Deane Parker,
NZ, World Premiere. Yak, a former pro kayaker now paraplegic, takes on Class 3 rapids in the
Upper Buller Gorge. Can packrafting restore his freedom—and redefine who gets to run wild
rivers? FESTIVAL SPIRIT AWARD
As One - The MHS Adventure Racing Team (15 mins) Louie Burger, NZ, World Premiere.
This uplifting documentary follows nine Motueka High students on a wild, 40-hour adventure
racing from the West Coast home—raising funds for World Vision with grit, laughs, and heart.
Spirit of the West (12 mins) Pedro Pimentel, NZ, World Premiere. Set against New Zealand’s
wild West Coast, this film captures the spirit of the Old Ghost Ultra—where community, resilience,
and grit collide in a transformative celebration of people and place. COMMUNITY SPIRIT
AWARD
Rakiura Solo (13 mins) Michael Beckmann, NZ. A tough solo hike around the 130km North West
Circuit on Stewart Island/Rakiura. Beyond the challenge, what makes this island truly special is
its rich wildlife. An ambient film without dialogue.
Waiatoto (20 mins) Josh Morgan & Jasper Gibson, NZ. This film tells the story of a traverse
across the Southern Alps through packraft, skis and tramping. Starting at the Matukituki, the route
went via Tititea, the Volta Glacier, and the Waiatoto, to the Tasman Sea. BEST NZ MADE FILM


Total running time: 125 minutes + 15 minute intermission.
label: Festivals

description:
NZ Drum & Dance Camp, NZ Drum & Dance Camp
Join us this 24th to 27th October for a West African musical immersion at our annual NZ Drum Dance Camp.

Set amidst 38 acres of native bushland just a short drive from Wellington, this weekend is a celebration of unity, rhythm, and the soul-stirring power of African drum and dance, curated for the NZ African drumming community.

We are excited to announce that Epizo Bangoura will be back to join us again in 2025!

Epizo Bangoura is a celebrated master musician from Guinea, West Africa, known for his extraordinary versatility on the Kora (African harp), Balafon (African tuned percussion), and Djembe/Duns.

Epizo will be joined by Ghanaian Master Drummer Yaw Asumadu and special guest Jimi Dale.

Camp Highlights:

♪ Djembe and Dunun Workshops: Suitable for all skill levels, from enthusiastic beginners to advanced drummers, guided by our awesome team of teachers.
♪ Traditional Dance: with the effervescent Epizo Bangoura.
♪ Group Jams and Musical Sessions: Strengthen communal bonds through captivating group jams and impromptu musical sessions.
♪ Tranquil Setting: Enjoy the native bushland environ - build mind, body and spirit whilst enhancing our weekend of music and togetherness.
♪ Catering – Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included on Saturday and Sunday, as well as breakfast Monday. Please bring a shared (pre-prepared) plate for Friday evening kai.

Featured Instructors:

Epizo Bangoura: A master of the djembe and traditional dance, Epizo brings profound knowledge and vibrant energy, embodying the essence of West African music and dance.

Yaw Asumadu: A Master Drummer from Ghana, Yaw has performed globally and taught African drumming for 25 years, collaborating with legendary artists.

Jimi Dale: A pioneer of African music in NZ, Jimi has been teaching African Drum and Dance classes since 1995 and formed the world music and dance group, Tamani. We are excited to have Jimi back again teaching us a dun dance piece.

Pricing Details:
♪ Early Bird: $450 (Reserve by Sunday 31st August 2025)
♪ Adult rate: $495
♪ Kids 9 – 14 years old: $250
♪ Kids 8 and under: $175
♪ Family Packages available on request
♪ Single Day & night $220 (includes 3 meals and full day tuition)
♪ Drum Hire: $15

Event Schedule Snapshot:
♪ Friday, 24th October: Arrive from 4pm - A warm welcome sets the stage for a weekend filled with rhythm and learning.
Bring a share plate for dinner.
♪ Saturday, 25th October: Engage in enriching drum and dance workshops. Participants will be grouped into their appropriate levels.
♪ Sunday, 26th October: Continue your musical journey with drum and dance sessions, leading to a group performance that encapsulates the weekend’s shared experiences.
♪ Monday, 27th October: Morning All in Drum & Dance ceremony, then it's time to hit the road.

FAQs
♪ Getting Ready: Bring your drum (if available), snacks for the weekend, dance-appropriate shoes, sleeping gear (pillowcase & sheet, sleeping bag/ doona), warm clothes, and an eager spirit.
♪ Beginners are warmly welcomed – our camp is a nurturing space for newcomers to discover the joy of African drumming and dance, bolstered by a supportive community.

For more information and tickets -
https://africandrumming.co.nz/tours-and-retreats/nz-drum-dance-camp/

More questions?
Contact - Tulletha at or call: 028 474 1123

⚔️Enthralling Entertainment!
Lose yourself in a cabaret of the bizarre, where the performances are as dark as they are dazzling. Expect sultry burlesque, twisted characters and moments that will thrill, chill, and have you begging for more.

Witness the brutal thrill of buhurt armoured combat, as warriors face off in full medieval kit in a raw display of might and mayhem.

Dance the day away at the main stage, as Welly’s top talent smash out tune after tune, all building up to a headline show from Brewtown favourites, The Blueprint – as they bring a special set just for Monster Mash! Trust us, you haven’t seen them like this before…

Grab your mates and get stuck in at the Games Zone, where a bit of friendly rivalry meets festive fun, and the loser buys the next round.

Enjoy dressing up? Go all out in your most terrifying, theatrical or jaw-dropping costume — and you might just take out the crown in our epic Best Dressed Competition, with spooky-good prizes up for grabs.

With affordable return coaches from Welly and Petone and great discounts for group tickets it's scarily easy to get involved!
🎃 R18

description:
NZ Mountain Film Festival 2025 - Award Night, A collection of New Zealand-made mountain films - brought to you by the Vic Uni Tramping Club, Wellington Tramping and Mountaineering Club, and of course the New Zealand Mountain Film and Book Festival!


Footprints on Katmai (22 mins) Max Romey, USA. Following his grandmother's footsteps to one
of the most remote and bear-strewn beaches in Alaska, painter Max Romey discovers that an
ocean of problems is closer to home than he could have imagined. BEST FILM ON THE ENVIRONMENT
Alone Across Gola (20 mins) Jude Kriwald, UK, NZ Premiere. Stranded in Liberia’s Gola
rainforest, filmmaker Jude Kriwald faces hunger, isolation, robbery and disappearing trails. A raw
tale of one man’s solo, self-filmed journey chasing a childhood dream. With only a bike and a
tent, Jude pushes the limits of survival and self-discovery. BEST ADVENTUROUS SPORTS & LIFESTYLES
Zahir (36 mins) Julien Nadiras, Switzerland, subtitles. Katherine and Eline take on an iconic rock
route, accessing it by bike. Their all-eco ascent tests endurance, nerve, and friendship, with long
runouts and tiny holds pushing them to the edge.
Body of a Line (10 mins) Henna Taylor, subtitles, USA. A cleverly animated short film that
morphs into real life as Madaleine undertakes an intimate and creative journey to climb a difficult
rock route, with original music and poetry. BEST SHORT FILM
Trango (46 mins) Leo Hoorn, USA. After a two-year attempt, ski mountaineers ski the first
descent of the Great Trango Glacier. They navigate risk, grapple with grief, and face physical
danger as they push the limits of human experience. Unspoken trust and support within their
expedition team allows them to face the unimaginable together. GRAND PRIZE FILM


Total running time: 120 minutes + 15 minute intermission.

description:
POP Go the Festival Singers: Island Bay Presbyterian Church, The Festival Singers invite you to a enjoy unforgettable music in POP go the Festival Singers – a dazzling celebration of popular songs from the 1920s right through to today. Expect energy, variety, and entertainment as we journey through swing, rock ’n’ roll, Motown, disco, soft rock, and contemporary pop.
The programme sparkles with classics and favourites: a Beach Boys Medley full of surfside sunshine, Ruru Karaitiana’s iconic Blue Smoke, Elvis Presley’s Hound Dog, and Bobby Darin’s Beyond the Sea. We’ll groove with Pharrell Williams’ Happy, cheer to Survivor’s Eye of the Tiger, and celebrate Kiwi pride in Crowded House’s Weather with You. Heartfelt beauty shines through Simon and Garfunkel’s Bridge Over Troubled Water and Billy Joel’s And So It Goes, while fun abounds with The Lion Sleeps Tonight and Gershwin’s sultry Summertime.
Swing makes its mark with Glenn Miller’s Chattanooga Choo Choo and In the Mood, while a rousing Queen Medley and an exuberant ABBA Medley bring the concert to a thrilling close. Along the way, enjoy contemporary sparkle with Dua Lipa’s Levitating and the timeless artistry of these unforgettable hits.
With the incomparable Jonathan Berkahn at the piano, every piece shines with character and style. This concert promises nostalgia, joy, and toe-tapping fun – a true trip down memory lane with something for everyone.
Join us and be part of a celebration of music that entertains, connects, and uplifts.

description:
Yoga & Cacao Twilight & Morning Edition - Pop-up Parlour 2025, Yoga & Cacao Twilight & Morning Edition - Pop-up Parlour 2025
Come and join Jenny Allan for a cup of ceremonial grade cacao and then enjoy a gentle and relaxing restorative yoga practice - twilight edition.

Event details

• What - 1.5 hr yoga session
• When -
TWILIGHT EDITION 7-8.30pm Tuesday 23rd September 2025
MORNING EDITION 10-11.30am Saturday 27th September 2025

• Where - St Marks, 98 Rāwhiti Road, Pukerua Bay
• Cost - $30 per person

• What to bring? Most props are provided but feel free to bring your own yoga mat for extra comfort as well as a cushion, blanket, socks and an eye pillow if you have one.

This class is suitable for all - no previous experience is required.

LIMITED SPACES AVAILABLE.
TWILIGHT SESSION - https://tinyurl.com/5a2pad44
MORNING SESSION - https://tinyurl.com/mw82z38u

Restorative yoga is a practice of deep relaxation in which yoga poses (asanas) are held for several minutes with the use of props such as blocks, bolster and blankets to support the body in gentle stretch.

When your body enters a state of relaxation, your mind will also relax. Once you have been guided to let go of any tension held in your body, all that is required is for you to pay attention to your breath, becoming aware of any thoughts that may arise, and then gently releasing them.

This restful practice calms both mind and body, allowing the nervous system to enter its parasympathetic state – the state of “rest and digest”, in which healing is enabled and enhanced.

About Cacao
Cacao is a superfood. It is plant medicine at its finest. Its scientific name, Theobroma cacao, translates to "food of the Gods." Containing many minerals, vitamins and phytonutrients such as flavonoids and antioxidants, it is also an extremely potent adaptogen that encourages the body to come into balance.

Cacao has a particularly strong influence on the heart – both physiologically and energetically. Cacao anecdotally is reported to enhance connection in community, hence its beauty in being shared in circle.

In Jenny's experience, cacao seems to enhance whatever it is that you are doing – be it running a marathon or meditating – cacao can make you go deeper, further, longer, stronger. However she does seem to have a mind of her own so be open to the experience she offers you – it may not always go quite how you planned!

Cacao is very safe and tolerated well by most people. However it is to be used with caution by people who are taking high doses of SSRIs. Cacao releases serotonin, so it works as a mild antidepressant. When taken with SSRIs that release serotonin chemically it can lead to serotonin syndrome. Individuals taking MAOIs (monoamine oxidase inhibitors) should avoid consuming ceremonial cacao due to potential interactions.

This workshop is part of Pukerua Bay Hub's 2025 Pop-up Parlour - thanks for your support.

Let us keep close together, not far apart.

description:
Rathkeale Christmas Fete 2025, Welcome to the Rathkeale Christmas Fête 2025! Walk through the gates of Rathkeale College on 1st November and be welcomed by a diverse range of colourful stalls, the aroma of freshy cooked food and plenty of festive inspiration.

Now in its 22nd year, the Christmas Fête has become a must-do event on the Wairarapa spring calendar. Stallholders travel from around the North Island to sell their wares and offer Christmas shoppers loads of inspiration. From festive decorations, clothing, arts and crafts, to flowers, toys and plants – there is something for everyone.

Gourmet food is always a highlight at the Fête - think freshly made gourmet burgers, lamb & mint sausages, wraps, curry, salads, and the ever-popular berries & ice-cream - there is always a huge variety of flavours to tempt the taste buds. Devonshire Teas and home baking served in the Rathkeale Homestead rose garden is a time-honoured tradition while refreshing cold drinks can be sipped on as visitors listen to live music performed by students at various times throughout the day. The popular Christmas cake stall features again this year - but visitors are encouraged to get in early as the cakes often sell out by midday.

The beauty of this Fête is that it’s a day out for the whole family. In addition to the 120 plus stalls, there is plenty to entertain the children including facepainting and magic shows throughout the day.

Visitors can also explore the beautiful, expansive grounds of Rathkeale College including the school gardens designed by Alfred Buxton, the Greek Amphitheatre and the 3km eco-trail which weaves through large stands of native trees, including ancient kahikatea.

Eftpos is available, but we strongly recommend that visitors bring cash.

Koha/gold coin entry.
Rathkeale College is a five-minute drive north of Masterton in the Wairarapa.

Exclusive behind-the-scenes access to CAANZ you won’t get at standard info nights.
Real conversations with CAANZ professionals answering the gritty questions others skip.
Practical tips and tricks to channel yourself into the profession with confidence.

Rave to the Grave – Fund-Raise the Dead for BATS Theatre and RadioActive.FM will transform the Kent Tce into a pumping, all-night celebration on Halloween night. description:
The Best of Bill Bryson — Live on Stage, With 21 published nonfiction books, you’ll likely have come across Bill Bryson’s work. One of his most famous books, ‘A Short History of Nearly Everything’, has been given a major rewrite. He takes to the stage at The Opera House to talk about his new findings. 
In ‘A Short History of Nearly Everything 2.0’, Bill updates the book with the latest scientific research on the Earth and the universe. In the live show, you’ll hear about planetology, astronomy, particle physics, the Big Bang, quantum mechanics, and evolution. Throughout his career, the journalist and author has covered a wide range of subjects, including travel, the English language, and the human body. This rare chance to see him live promises forays into many of these areas. All conducted with his usual theatrical flair. 
Bill Bryson has a quest to understand everything that has happened from the Big Bang to the rise of civilisation and what humans are today. Join him as he shares the latest major advances in science.

description:
Slow Grind Fever [AUS] - Wellington Jazz Festival, Express from Melbourne, Australia and crossing international waters for the first time this October, Meow is excited to welcome the slowest, spookiest, smokiest and swingin-est club night Wellington has ever seen: 'Slow Grind Fever'.
For this one-night-only episode of SGF Wellington, founder Richie1250 (106.7 PBS FM) will be joined by fellow Melbourne radio alumnus Dr. Popalotacorn (RRR, 98.1FM Raglan) and Wellington's own belle of the airwaves Miss Juliet (RadioActive.FM Americana)
Slow Grind Fever was born in 2012 when Richie1250 hired a Russian Cultural Centre ballroom and threw a slow dance party for his 30th birthday, and it's been running as a regular monthly club night ever since. Richie and his friends play the slowest, sleaziest, spookiest, sweetest, swinginest old records they can find, and people dance real slow in a haze of smoke and dim red light. It's a good time.
In the last few years Richie has taken Slow Grind Fever on the road, with regular dances in Sydney, Hobart, Darwin and Alice Springs. They post up a monthly Slow Grind Fever mix in the week before the party every month, and have collaborated with Stag-O Lee Records in Germany on a series of Slow Grind Fever LPs and CDs.
Enjoy the music and if you feel so inclined, get down to Slow Grind Fever - Wellington at Meow on Friday 17th October.
Listening to the MP3 mixes is nice, but when you’re in the room all
wrapped up in smoke with the music sizzling right off the old records, through the speakers and into your brain, well, there's nothing quite like it…
http://www.slowgrindfever.com/
https://www.instagram.com/slowgrindfeverclub

Living History: Discover how imperial robes, flowing Hanfu and delicate Qipao tell stories of China's dynasties.
Dance Through Time: Enjoy traditional performances showcasing how movement and costume intertwine.
Cultural Immersion: Interactive activities that bring ancient fashion to life.

description:
Analytics Forum: Social Investment (Wellington, Tue 14 Oct 25), Join us for an NZ Data Science + Analytics Forum event, hosted by the Social Investment Agency / Toi Hou Tāngata (SIA). This event will cover the Agency’s work using data and analytics to support evidence-based decision-making across the social sector, with four speakers each sharing their work, with opportunities for Q&A and networking.
This is a great opportunity to hear direct from SIA and connect with your peers in the Data Science and Analytics field, to learn from some of the leading voices in analytics, data engineering, evaluation, data-driven outcomes, and economic modelling.
Thanks to the Social Investment Agency for hosting this event.
Welcome and Introductions
Sara van der Velde, Chief Executive Officer (Acting), Nicholson Consulting, and Christopher Reid, Manager Pae Ora Data & Insights, Ara Poutama Aotearoa, for NZ Data Science & Analytics Forum
Kylie Reiri, Deputy Chief Executive – Transformation, Technology and Enabling Services, opening remarks for SIA
Speakers
1. Louise Pirini - Manager, Evidence and Insight service
Social Investment and data driven decision making
Explore why data is the power behind social investment – – and how evidence, outcomes, and impact measurement are driving better insights for decision-makers.
2. Peter Holmes - Data Engineer
Feedback loops and data tools
The importance of feedback loops in developing and delivering useful data products such as the Regional Data Explorer.
3. Dan Young - Senior Analyst, Data Science
Analysis and accelerators
Discover how automation and tools like cost-benefit analysis are accelerating evidence-based decisions across the social sector, drawing on linked data using the Stats NZ Integrated Data Infrastructure (IDI) and beyond.
4. Andrew Webber - Chief Economist
Learning and impact measurement
Exploring how the Social Investment Fund is moving from burdensome reporting to practical learning conversations that generate more useful insights for decision-making and provide a clear view of causal impact.

The New Zealand Data Science + Analytics Forum events are free to attend (with an Eventbrite ticket) and open to anyone that has an interest in Data Science and Analytics. Please note that SIA have an in-person event capacity cap of 65 tickets so those getting tickets early will get priority access. This is an in-person only event to allow for discussion and questions.
For more information on the New Zealand Data Science + Analytics Forum, check us out at https://analytics.org.nz/. Sign up to receive notifications of our future events!

description:
Out The Gate, Out the Gate is Theatre Marae presented by Te Rākau Hua o Te Wao Tapu, is a theatrical conversation about incarceration in Aotearoa. Presented by an ensemble of over 16 performers and followed by a facilitated kōrerō. Out the Gate asks questions and provides hope.

Te Rākau’s unique Theatre Marae method combines the complementary spiritual, social and political concepts of the Greek theatre and Marae into a performance hui.

Out the Gate is Theatre Marae in action, created with and for the community, deliberately blurring the lines between research, performance, and public kōrero. A conversation about incarceration in Aotearoa, the work presents episodic vignettes woven together through music, waiata, choreographed movement and physical theatre.

Content advisory: Some taumaha language and content may offend. Recommended for ages 14+. Whānau and tamariki welcome with parental guidance.

description:
NZIFF: Went Up the Hill, An unsettling, sinister slow-burn thriller, Samuel Van Grinsven unites rising star Dacre Montgomery with Phantom Thread’s Vicky Krieps and New Zealand’s own Sarah Peirse for a supernatural chiller like no other.

In the icy, shadow-stricken world of Went Up the Hill’s Christchurch, it would seem that the death of Elizabeth, wife of Jill (Vicky Krieps), has taken with it warmth itself. The unexpected suicide of her partner has left her a hollowed-out shell – that is, until Jack (Dacre Montgomery), Elizabeth’s long-absent son, arrives at the funeral, apparently invited by Jill herself, though she does not remember doing so.

The circumstances of Jack’s long absence are unclear – all that is known is that Jack was given up for adoption at a very young age. Staying the night at Jill and Elizabeth’s oppressive, concrete-clad mountain abode, it quickly becomes clear that the spirit of Elizabeth has not yet departed – instead, she has gained the ability to possess both wife and son and is utilising this ability to linger and address the needs of either relationship. What initially seems to be a gift from beyond, however, begins to sour when long-hidden secrets of the past begin to emerge, and lines between the two begin to be crossed.

The sophomore feature of Samuel Van Grinsven, Went Up the Hill is a wintry, gothic affair, and a showcase for the untapped talents of Montgomery, who most will recognise as the golden-haired, ill-fated muscle mutt Billy from Stranger Things. Essentially a two-hander (with occasional, welcome interjection from Kiwi legend Sarah Peirse as Jack’s frosty, mystery-shrouded aunt), Van Grinsven tracks the trajectory of these two adrift people and the spirit between them – from unexpected refuge, to joy, to dread – with a purposeful, drip-fed escalation of tension. Questions of control, abuse and the lingering weight of past scars take hold, all while the usually pleasantly scenic Christchurch landscape is transformed into a suffocatingly claustrophobic ice prison. Van Grinsven’s muscular direction bears none of the flashy excesses of an emerging filmmaker – his vision emerges, stately, imposing and fully-formed. — Tom Augustine
label: Film & Media

description:
Miramar Maupuia community centre Raranga, Te Motu Kairangi, with the support of Miramar & Maupuia Community Centre, warmly invites you to:
Monthly Flax Weaving Wānanga
Experience the joy of learning, sharing, and reconnecting with the art of weaving.
Whether you’re a first-time weaver or returning to refresh your skills, all are welcome. We’ll cover basic weaving techniques and tikanga (customs) and provide a supportive, creative space to connect with Māori arts and crafts alongside others.
Session Times
• Open session: 1:30pm – 5:00pm (pack down starts at 4:30pm)
What to Bring
• New weavers: 5–10 rau (blades) of harakeke, sharp scissors.
• An old towel
• Bring a bag, as you must take away leftover harakeke
• Returning weavers: 30–40 rau of harakeke and your weaving tools
• Some tools are available to borrow
• Shared kai (snacks) welcome but not required
• Bring a bag, as you must take away leftover harakeke
Koha appreciated, not required
If you would like to support the kaupapa, please email us at temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com for koha details.
Come and enjoy weaving, learning, and connection in a beautiful, relaxed setting.
Contact
via facebook
https://www.facebook.com/TeMotuKai

Email temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com
If you would like to koha to TMK, please email (Email temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com) for the account details.

description:
Wellington Folk Festival 2025 - our 60th!, Welcome to Wellyfest!
The Wellington Folk Festival is held every Labour Weekend, celebrated on the fourth weekend of October, at Brookfield Outdoor Education Centre – a beautiful site owned by the Scouts at 562 Moores Valley Road, Wainuiomata, Lower Hutt, New Zealand.
The Festival gate is open from 3pm on the Friday, with events running over Friday evening, all day Saturday through to Sunday evening. You can come for the weekend, for a day, half day or an evening. Children (0 - 12) can attend free.
Weekend passes entitle the holders to camp onsite and there are a limited number of bunks available for sale as well.
PLEASE NOTE - ALL EARLYBIRD PRICING CLOSES AT 11.55PM ON SUNDAY 28TH SEPTEMBER. Full-price tickets can be purchased on-line until Sunday 19th October.
After ticket sales close on Humanitix, you can purchase at the gate, from 3pm on Friday 25th of October.  Weekend tickets, day tickets and evening tickets are all available at the gate.  There may even be some bunks available still.  You can email registrations@wellingtonfolkfestival.org.nz to find out.
To read our latest news click here, click the Latest News tab in the menu above, or check out our facebook page here www.facebook.com/Wellyfest/.
If you would like to be added to our email list, sign up to our mailing list here.

description:
XCOMMUNICATE, XCOMMUNICATE
The formidable powerhouse duo COMMUNICATE return to Wellington in November with their clubnight, XCOMMUNICATE, for one night only.

Known for their long sets that incorporate decades of sound, Cyril Orson and Heylady have been punishing dance floors across Aotearoa since they joined forces 3 years ago. Off the back of a monstrous summer, which saw them play 19 shows up and down the country, the pair have spent most of 2025 in the studio finessing their own brand of audio alchemy and preparing to release their label, also named XCOMMUNICATE.

Usually XCOMMUNICATE is a 6 hour journey though decades and sonic realms, however as Heylady is still recovering from a mighty dose of burnout they’ve roped in a couple of their good friends, who happen to be some of Wellington’s finest, to join them as they lay down four hours of four to the floor.

Halo is a mainstay on Wellington dancefloors and it was a no brainer asking her to be on this lineup. A DJ since 2000, she has played festivals across the country and never fails to rock her slot. Her set at Taniwha’s Den last summer was a big highlight and one of the best of the festival. Halo’s ability to drive forward thinking sound and her clever construction of sets are just two reasons you need to be on her floor.

DJ Coda is the godfather of techno in New Zealand. With a career that spans decades, he isn’t just a DJ but a dedicated promoter and one of the trustees of NZ’s longest running student radio station, Radio Active. Part of the COMMUNICATE family from the get go (and a longtime collaborator of Heylady’s), DJ Coda is a master of his craft and never fails to deliver. Armed with knowledge , taste and a hefty love of Detroit, DJ Coda is the man when it comes to rocking the dance floor.
First release tickets are on sale now, grab yours before they are gone and come and dance the evening away with four of the best. We recommend arrive early so you don’t miss out on any of the sets, they are all going to be killer.

IMPORTANT INFO:
Our event is a safe space for all. If you or someone you know is feeling unsafe or harassed, please approach one of the DJs or bar staff. If you are behaving badly and impacting others ability to have a good time safely, you will be removed. Please act with respect and care for your fellow attendees at all times, no means no and this goes for conversations as well as more intimate requests.
