label: Film & Media

description:
NZIFF: What Marielle Knows, Panic around a new digital Big Brother era underpins a clever, absurdist send-up of bourgeois hypocrisy, as a married couple are put on the spot by their daughter’s all-pervasive telepathy.

Germany has a thorny history with mass intelligence gathering, and a continued vigilance around data privacy – and anxiety. Director Frédéric Hambalek taps into it with satirical, ribald flair and a twist of the fantastical in a sharp domestic parable for a new era of global surveillance paranoia.

Julia (Julia Jentsch) is precariously close to a full-blown affair with the workmate she flirts with on smoking breaks. Her husband Tobias (Felix Kramer) dreams of getting even with a publishing house colleague who undercuts his authority in editorial design meetings. When their teenager Marielle (Laeni Geiseler) is slapped by a school friend over an insult, the impact leaves her with the sudden telepathic ability to see everything her parents do throughout the day – a development that spells disaster for the household, as dishonesty can no longer sustain the veneer of stable marital contentment.

As the family descends into a desperate, riotous war of manipulation, they must experiment with new moral codes. Is radical honesty and defiance the best course of action, or should they stifle egos and instincts in line with their preferred image? Better yet, can Marielle’s new powers be curbed? — Carmen Gray
label: Film & Media

description:
NZIFF: Young Mothers, The Dardenne brothers return with a deeply affecting drama exploring the lives of five teen mothers. Hopes and fears steer the young women towards bettering their lives for themselves and their children.

Young Mothers examines the lives of underprivileged teenagers as they come to terms with motherhood for the first time. Living together temporarily in a group home, they are taught how to care for their babies, while grappling with very different personal circumstances. The Dardenne brothers treat the characters with delicate respect while humanising the tumultuous reality that often comes with teenage motherhood.

Jessica, raised in an orphanage, cannot imagine abandoning her child and desperately seeks closure from her birth mother. Julie considers giving up her daughter for adoption, yet her own troubled mother wishes to raise the child to atone for her past mistakes. Brought up by an alcoholic mother, Perla dreams of a stable family, but her delinquent boyfriend wants nothing to do with her or their child. While Ariane has the privilege of a loving partner, both are recovering drug addicts which presents its own challenges.

This is a story of hope told through characters looking for a future free from their past. — Madison Marshall
label: Film & Media

description:
Textiles and Queerness in a NZ Film! Went Up The Hill at NZIFF Wellington, Hi queer friends who love crafts-have I got the film for you! NZ feature film Went Up The Hill will have its Wellington Premiere at the NZ International Film Festival on 21 August at the Embassy at 830pm-get your ticket now!
Come along and be amongst the first to see NZ feature film Went Up The Hill from queer NZ filmmaker Sam Van Grinsven.
Tickets to the Wellington screening are available for $26 at the NZIFF website:
https://www.nziff.co.nz/.../te.../went-up-the-hill/
The film is also screening at NZIFF in centres around the country including Auckland, Christchurch, Dunedin amongst others!
Shot in Canterbury and funded by the NZ Film Commission, the film stars Vicky Krieps (The Phantom Thread) and Dacre Montgomery (Stranger Things) in a poetic ghost story that centres on two queer characters-a woman and her dead wife’s estranged son -as they are each haunted by her spirit. The film premiered to critical acclaim as a Special Presentation at Toronto Film Festival in 2024 where Sam was hailed by Hollywood Reporter as already having the ‘control of a master’ in a film that is ‘captivating', ‘elliptical' and 'technically stunning’.
Sam Van Grinsven has a passion for queer interpretation of genre and seeing queer characters within spaces that historically have not been explored as diversely.
Here's the trailer link-we hope you can join us!
label: Film & Media

description:
The Lot Fundraiser Pub Quiz, Join us for a fun night of trivia and drinks at The Lot fundraiser Pub Quiz - let's raise some money together!

We are a bunch of Maessey University students and we need you help to fund our third year student film The Lot.

The film follows Riley and her boyfriend Jay, as they attempt to purchase snacks for a party. However, their arrogance and lack of communication turns a simple task into the unraveling of their relationship.
The film is a comical narrative that pokes fun at miscommunication and microaggression, and ends (literally) in a big mess. I hope audiences are able to share a laugh and see a bit of themselves in the characters: whether it’s the cashier who’s just trying to make it through his shift, or the partner who’s completely had it with their relationship.

The Top of the South Film Festival (TSFF) returns for it's 11th annual edition. With three days of celebratory events throughout Nelson & Marlborough, this is a chance to walk the red carpet, share food and drinks, and mingle with the celebrities before premiering the 2025 selection of the best short films created both in the Top of the South region and throughout the rest of the country. From thrillers and dramas to westerns, animated comedies and documentaries—this year’s screenings contain entertainment for all.

10:30am-12:30pm - Bus Tour: Join locations manager & scout Dylan Poihipi in a tour around Marlborough as we discuss the art & technicalities of locations for film. Departing from ASB Theatre Marlborough.

description:
NZIFF: Romeria, One of the standouts of Cannes 2025, Carla Simón’s personal exploration of the restlessness of a young woman without parents is a poignant example of the healing power of cinema.

After winning the Best Film in Berlin with Alcarràs (2022), Spanish director Carla Simón looks back into her own memories and heals pains from the past with her spellbinding third feature film Romería.

Eighteen-year-old Marina is an aspiring film student who sets out to trace the fate of her biological parents – who both died during the HIV epidemic of the late 1980s, early 1990s. Raised in Barcelona by her maternal grandparents, Marina visits her paternal family in Galicia, in order to obtain the paternity recognition documents that would allow her to apply for a scholarship. Guided on her journey by the pages of her mother's diary, Marina revisits her parents’ story of love and addiction...

Simón brushes with delicate touches the dynamics of a difficult family reconciliation and the motions of post-adolescent desire (the attraction between Marina and her cousin). While she initially draws from the tropes of summertime family dramas, Simón then turns Romería into a dreamlike fable where the past comes alive through the present thanks to the simple, yet enchanting true magic of cinema.— Paolo Bertolin
label: Film & Media

The Sameer Project is an on-the-ground aid organisation organised by Palestinians in the diaspora, which crowdfunds in order to provide tents, medical care and direct cash aid to those most affected in Gaza. They can be found on Instagram at @thesameerproject.

description:
Reels for Meals: Wicked: For Good, November's Reels for Meals movie fundraiser is Wicked: For Good.
Last year’s global cinematic cultural sensation, which became the most successful Broadway film adaptation of all time, now reaches its epic, electrifying, emotional conclusion in Wicked: For Good.
The final chapter of the untold story of the witches of Oz begins with Elphaba (Cynthia Erivo) and Glinda (Ariana Grande) estranged and living with the consequences of their choices.
Elphaba, now demonised as The Wicked Witch of the West, lives in exile, hidden within the Ozian forest while continuing her fight for the freedom of Oz’s silenced Animals and desperately trying to expose the truth she knows about The Wizard (Jeff Goldblum).
Glinda, meanwhile, has become the glamorous symbol of Goodness for all of Oz, living at the palace in Emerald City and revelling in the perks of fame and popularity. Under the instruction of Madame Morrible (Michelle Yeoh), Glinda is deployed to serve as an effervescent comfort to Oz, reassuring the masses that all is well under the rule of The Wizard.
As Glinda’s stardom expands and she prepares to marry Prince Fiyero (Jonathan Bailey) in a spectacular Ozian wedding, she is haunted by her separation from Elphaba. She attempts to broker a conciliation between Elphaba and The Wizard, but those efforts will fail, driving Elphaba and Glinda only further apart. The aftershocks will transform Boq (Ethan Slater) and Fiyero forever, and threaten the safety of Elphaba’s sister, Nessarose (Marissa Bode), when a girl from Kansas comes crashing into all their lives.
As an angry mob rises against the Wicked Witch, Glinda and Elphaba will need to come together one final time. With their singular friendship now the fulcrum of their futures, they will need to truly see each other, with honesty and empathy, if they are to change themselves, and all of Oz, for good.

All profits from this movie fundraiser go to the Lower Hutt Foodbank.

description:
Film Talks At Aratoi Presents the Bride of Frankenstein (1935), Film Talks at Aratoi presents The Bride of Frankenstein (1935)
Halloween Film Night 2025

Get ready for a night of cinematic chills and festive frights! Since 2022, Film Talks’ Halloween Film Night has brought Wairarapa audiences together to celebrate classic horror in a fun, immersive atmosphere.

This year, join us on Halloween night for James Whale’s masterpiece, The Bride of Frankenstein (1935). Widely regarded as one of the greatest horror films ever made, it combines unforgettable imagery, Gothic atmosphere, and a surprising touch of dark humour.

Doors open at 6:45 pm, and the movie begins at 7 pm at Aratoi, 12 Bruce Street, Masterton. Running time: 75 minutes.

Costumes encouraged! Spot prizes will be awarded for the best dressed, adding to the spirit of the night. Bring friends, family, or come on your own and join a community of film lovers for playful scares, shared laughs, and a celebration of classic cinema.

Reserve Your Seats. Koha welcome — suggested $5. Your contribution helps keep Film Talks alive and accessible for our community.

Presented by Film Talks, and Aratoi, in association with the Wellington Heritage Festival.

Step into the shadows this Halloween and celebrate the 90th anniversary of one of cinema’s most haunting Gothic classics!

description:
Christof Van Der Ven - “Is This What We’ve Become?” Album Tour, After 5 years Christof is coming back to New Zealand to tour his newly released album.

He plays at the Abandoned Brewery taproom in Petone on the 30th of October.

Christof van der Ven has built a truly impressive CV over the course of his career, from supporting the likes of Bon Iver, The Staves, Mel Parsons, Bear’s Den, Lisa Hannigan, and Nick Mulvey, to playing in front of thousands of fans across the world.

Hailing originally from Holland, Christof van der Ven moved to Galway in 2007 before settling in London. He has released two LPs, Empty Handed (2018) and You Were The Place (2019), alongside multiple EPs. His career has been supported by DIY, Clash, Gold Flake Paint and his music has been played on BBC6 Radio and Radio X.
NEW ALBUM “Is this what we’ve become?”

Throughout ‘is this what we’ve become?’ Christof speaks to loved ones and past selves, reflecting on years of promise, regret and loss. His storytelling is characterized by gentle melodies and rich, textured arrangements, as his younger selves confront him with unfulfilled ambitions and perceived failures. When Christof turns towards friends and family, he finds them too in moments of upheaval, in need of support. Amidst the unpredictable and uncontrollable, community and friendship emerge, providing roots, giving comfort as Christof ruminates on how he came to be - and can come to accept - who he is now.

Written by Christof, ‘is this what we’ve become?’ also features musical contributions from Jools Owen (Bear’s Den, Bess Atwell), Tommy Heap (Billie Marten, Matthew and the Atlas), Marcus Hamblett (Villagers, Bear’s Den), and Estilo String Quartet. The album was produced and recorded by Christof and Ian Grimble (Daughter, Manic Street Preachers, Matt Corby, Fionn Regan), who also mixed the LP. ‘is this what we’ve become?’ incorporates recordings from both studio sessions in London, as well as ad hoc recording sessions engineered by Christof across the UK.

description:
Choral Connections Concert, NZCF presents Choral Connections, a concert featuring two of New Zealand’s finest youth choirs – the acclaimed New Zealand Secondary Students' Choir, directed by Sue Densem, and the Aotearoa Academy Choir, directed by Rowan Johnston and Elise Bradley.
Set in the soaring acoustics of Wellington’s Cathedral of St Paul, this public concert forms the centrepiece of NZCF’s Choral Connect convention – a bi-annual professional development conference that brings together choral directors from around the country.
At the end of the concert, conference delegates with join with the two youth choirs to form a massed choir of over 150 voices to sing under the direction of international choral clinician Dr Pearl Shankuan.
New Zealand Secondary Students' Choir
Aotearoa's national choir for secondary school students, NZSSC gathers during school holidays to rehearse and perform across the motu. Each two-year cycle culminates in an international tour: in July 2024, the choir travelled to China, where they took part in the Shanghai Oriental Art Centre Chorus Exchange, the Chorus and Conducting Art Conference in Hangzhou, and the China International Chorus Festival in Beijing.
NZSSC is directed by Sue Densem, alongside Assistant Conductor and Accompanist Brent Stewart and Assistant Conductor and Vocal Consultant Ben Madden.
Aotearoa New Zealand Academy Choir
The Academy Choir was established as a pipeline for talented singers from across Aotearoa who are aspiring to join NZSSC or the NZ Youth Choir. In 2024, the Academy Choir received a Gold Diploma at the World Choir Games in Auckland.
The Aotearoa Academy Choir is co-directed by Elise Bradley and Rowan Johnston.
Dr Pearl Shangkuan is a highly sought-after conductor, lecturer and clinician who has led performances and workshops on six continents. She is the National President-elect of the American Choral Directors Association (ACDA), the chorus director of the Grand Rapids Symphony and Professor Emerita of Music at Calvin University in Grand Rapids, Michigan. She has conducted several times at Carnegie Hall and other major concert halls in the US. Her guest conducting engagements regularly take her to Europe, Asia, and across North America.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
TOI & Friends present: Kirikā (burning, feverish), TOI & Friends present: Kirikā (burning, feverish)
The dancefloor is set to light up this October when Wellington's finest soul/funk/roots collective TOI get together with some of their best buds to pay homage to Aotearoa’s criminally overlooked 1970s boogie scene.

The soul/funk/disco magic of the likes of Dalvanius, Mark Williams, Collision, Prince Tui Teka, The Yandall Sisters, 1860 and Tina Cross had a new light shone on it with the release of John
Baker and Alan Perrot’s 2017 compilation Heed the Call: Whakarongo Ngā Tamariki. Now the capital has a chance to celebrate the music live as TOI rediscover and reimagine these sonic taonga.

Comprised of a stellar lineup of Aotearoa’s leading musicians, for over a decade TOI have been bringing crowds together to groove all across New Zealand and Australia in both headline spots and as support for the likes of Red Hot Chili Peppers, Ocean Alley, Fat Freddy’s Drop and Tash Sultana. Don’t miss your chance to see them for this one-night-only exploration of one of Aotearoa’s most interesting and dynamic scenes.

Featuring the vocal stylings of Wellington’s own leading lady of soul Lisa Tomlins, TOI’s Conway Jeune (aka C-Way Green from Fat Freddy’s Drop) and another very special guest to be announced. TOI is Conway Jeune (Guitar, Lead Vocals), Bryn Van Vliet (Saxophone & BVs), Jules Blewman (Lead Guitar), Luther Hunt (Drums & BVs), Kaito Walley (Trombone & Percussion), Daniel Hayles (Keys & Synths) and Johnny Lawrence (Bass).

description:
PALMERSTON NORTH - Regent on Broadway, PALMERSTON NORTH - Regent on Broadway
We invite you to join us for a night of Creedence Clearwater Revival and John Fogerty, as we celebrate the music of one of the world’s most iconic bands – from the songs they wrote, to the songs covered, to the songs they wrote for others.

From their album debut in 1968 to their last album in 1972, CCR was a juggernaut of phenomenal proportions.

No other band has created such an impact in such a short time.
The Creedence Clearwater Collective brings to the stage a band that captures the unique CCR sound.

You do not want to hear through the grapevine that you missed out on this fun, hit-packed live concert.

Join us, a real-life travelling band.

Ticket Link 👇
https://www.regent.co.nz/shows/creedence-clearwater-collective-2

The New Zealand Swing Quartet, Join dynamic saxophonist and frontman Oscar Lavën and The New Zealand Swing Quartet as they blast out the joyous party music of the New Orleans French Quarter, made famous by Louis Armstrong and Jelly Roll Morton. You'll be dancing before you know it.
The lineup includes these seriously clever cats: Oscar Lavën (clarinet/sax/tomfoolery), Mat Enright (trumpet and vocals), Ayrton Foote (piano), Adrian Jensen (guitar), Dan Yeabsley (bass), and Jacob Randall (drums).

Tommy and the Midnight Sun @ The RSC, Free Entry, koha for the band!

Brought to you by freestyler extraordinaire Tommy Midnight, anticipate a night that begins with heartfelt songwriting to wash away your winter woes, transitioning through to high energy conscious hiphop, soul and Raumati groove complete with horns, in his full band the Midnight Sun.

description:
Brynzilian Big Band - Wellington Jazz Festival, Brynzilian Big Band - Wellington Jazz Festival
The Brynzilian Big Band is a 17-piece powerhouse jazz orchestra founded and led by saxophonist Bryn van Vliet.

Based in Wellington, Bryn is a multi-disciplinary artist known for his dynamic career as an instrumentalist (saxophone, woodwinds, vocals), performer, composer, arranger, and educator.

As a founding member of TOI and former lead alto saxophonist for the Rodger Fox Big Band, he has earned a reputation as a versatile and sought-after musician.

The Brynzilian Big Band presents fresh, vibrant compositions inspired by iconic Brazilian music styles such as Samba, Bossa Nova, and Forró. Bryn’s writing reflects his deep affection for
Brazilian music, while honoring its traditional roots and spirit.

Featuring 17 of Wellington’s finest musicians, the Brynzilian Big Band promises a performance that will make you dance,
laugh, shout, cry — and maybe even hug your neighbour.


Check out some footage of the band here:
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Peter Hook and The Light, Bassist Peter Hook has intimate knowledge of the music of bands Joy Division and New Order. He’s one of the founding members of both British new wave bands. In July 2026, he is bringing his band The Light to The Opera House in Wellington. Together they will perform New Order’s album ‘Get Ready’ in full to celebrate its 25th anniversary. To make the concert even better, they will also perform a selection of greatest hits from Joy Division’s and New Order’s back catalogue. Get ready to enjoy songs like Disorder, Shadowplay, Transmission, Love Will Tear Us Apart, Blue Monday, and True Faith. 
The dark and ethereal sound of Joy Division and New Order ushered in the post-punk era and continue to be influential in the rock music scene. Peter Hook and The Light are careful to meticulously recreate their music in a live setting. Audiences are in for a show where treasured songs are played with the passion and energy they deserve.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
NZSSC @ Te Raukura ki Kāpiti !, NZSSC @ Te Raukura ki Kāpiti !
NZ’s best young singers to perform first full-length public concert of 2025 at Te Raukura ki Kāpiti this September

The New Zealand Secondary Students’ Choir (NZSSC) will perform their first full-length public concert of 2025 on Saturday 27th September at Te Raukura ki Kāpiti, in the stunning Coastlands Theatre. Concert starts 6pm

The NZSSC has achieved considerable success since its formation in 1986. Bringing their “infectious joy for music-making” to the Kāpiti coast for the first time since 2022, you will see and hear exactly why the NZSSC has won titles such as 'Children's Choir of the World' at Llangollen Eisteddfod and embarked on 16 international tours, including Canada, Singapore, China, USA, South America, Australia and South Africa, during their almost 40 year existence!

Under the direction of Sue Densem, the NZSSC gathers our finest young voices (14–18) throughout Aotearoa and offers a once in a lifetime opportunity – a two-year membership that sees students learning from some of the country’s top choral teachers and composers, as well as performing throughout Aotearoa. The 2-year experience culminates in an exciting international tour in July of the 2nd year, before singers part ways.

As with all their concerts, the repertoire for this Kāpiti concert will be a wonderful mix of cultures, featuring Māori waiata ā-ringa and Pasifika songs with a sprinkling of choral cannon plus some classics like you’ve never heard them before!

Bring the whole family for an evening of choral excellence and entertainment!

Get your Early Bird Special before 29 August 2025 to secure a great concert at a great bargain!

--

Get ready for an unforgettable outing of jazz as Australian saxophonist Julien Wilson teams up with Wellington’s own jazz drummer Mark Lockett for a special trio performance at The Rogue.

Having collaborated for many years, both locally in Australia and on international tours, Julien and Mark bring a wealth of experience and a deep musical connection to the stage.

description:
Pumpkinhead - Sloth 30th Anniversary Tour, Pumpkinhead celebrate the 30th anniversary of their critically acclaimed album Sloth this year, performing three exclusive never to be repeated reunion shows.

Sloth entered the New Zealand Album Charts on 30 April 1995, peaked at number 28 and stayed in the charts for 4 weeks. Their single “I Like” made it to number 16 in the Official Top 40 singles chart 10 March 1995.

“Now “Sloth”, Pumpkinhead’s debut album, compresses the quintet’s live energy into a head spinning whirlpool of fierce punky rock, powerful pop, and tempo-hopping Faith No More style metal. Not for the innocent!” – 4.5 stars – NZ HERALD 1995

“Sloth is the sound of a band that’s already found its feet, the sound of a band that’s played 500 gigs before recording their debut album. What we’ve got here is a classy, polished debut. “I Like” these songs a lot” – Kevin List – RIP IT UP 1995

description:
Secrets, Orchestra Wellington’s 2025 season, The Dictator’s Shadow,
follows Dmitri Shostakovich’s career, tracing his trajectory as a
brilliant young composer catapulted to early fame and then hurled into danger.
The next chapter in our story is Secrets, featuring an array of bold works and exciting talent! As we continue our exploration of Dmitri Shostakovich's journey 50 years after his death, we present his fourth symphony. The work, was meant to be his boldest statement yet — but the composer withdrew it before its premiere. Why? The whispers were clear: this music would not please the authorities. It stayed hidden for decades, a secret too dangerous to share.
We partner with At The World's Edge Music Festival (AWE) to present the stunning talents of soloists Benjamin Baker (violin) and Yura Lee (viola) in a performance of Mozart’s luminous Sinfonia Concertante. This work offers a moment of balance — a conversation between violin and viola, full of warmth and understanding, reminding us of beauty even in troubled times.
With generous support from the Orchestra Wellington Foundation we also reveal a brand-new secret: the world premiere of "House of the Faun" by WIlliam Philipson, the 2025 SOUNZ Commission for Orchestra and Sistema Youth Orchestra | Te Tono Mahinga a SOUNZ mā te Rāngi Puoro me te Rāngi Puoro Taiohi a Sistema. The work is designed to showcase the young musicians of Arohanui Strings+ by setting their playing against the full orchestra in a rich and immersive musical landscape.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
The Lighthouse Trio at The Pito-one Depot, The Lighthouse Trio at The Pito-one Depot
Join us as we explore some new interpretations of familiar melodies and unheard compositions! The trio will play original arrangements of favourite tunes as well as come brand new original songs. Expect mysterious ballads, soulful blues, and exhilarating bop.

The Lighthouse Trio is made up of three of Wellington's busiest players; Alex Trask, Jeremy Grant, and Elijah Mulheron. Alex is a highly regarded alto saxophonist who is seen all around town leading bands and playing for some of the leading musical organisations, including the RNZAF band and formerly the Rodger Fox Big Band. Elijah is the busiest bassist in town and often appears with Wellington legends such as Callum Allardice and John Rae. Jeremy is an extremely captivating guitarist and the creative force behind the arrangements you will hear.

The trio is celebrating the release of their debut EP with a tour of their own backyard, playing for the first time in Pito-one and Raumati, and finishing with a gig in central Wellington. Come along for an evening of fresh music presented in a relaxed setting, we hope to see you there!

Door sales available for $20

description:
Cheesy Lovers by Le Marché Français, Calling all cheese lovers!
Looking for a fun and original night out for two? Whether it’s a romantic date, a chill evening with a friend, or a cozy family moment, our Cheesy Lovers workshop is the perfect plan
What’s on the menu:
Roll up your sleeves and make two fresh cheeses from scratch, step by step, with our expert cheesemongers
Discover the magic of artisan cheesemaking — milk, love, and a little bit of alchemy

Then, get creative and build your very own cheese platter for two — beautiful and delicious
A full spread of charcuterie, fruits, nuts, and condiments will be waiting for you, along with expert tips on pairing and presentation. And of course… tasting is highly encouraged
It’s an intimate, tasty, hands-on experience for anyone who loves good food, good vibes, and of course... cheese
Hosted in our cozy shop

description: Cognac vs Armagnac, Noble Rot sommelier Maciej Zimny has a undeniable passion for brandy, and he is yearning to share that with you. Maciej will guide you on an educational journey through this fascinating world focusing on the most prestigious French regions for brandy production: Cognac and Armagnac. He’ll provide detailed insight into the appellations, distillation and ageing processes, differences in oak maturation and why one region focuses on vintage expressions while the other ages blends for several years in barrel. But don’t worry, this isn’t a classroom affair—they'll be pouring 8 different spirits paired to a unique three-course menu to showcase Maciej’s knowledge, and he’ll even teach you the sommelier’s techniques for how to taste spirits correctly. Fall in love with brandy, find your favourite and next time you’re ordering a nightcap you can show off your new-found knowledge to your friends.

Tickets or bookings are not required—just turn up!

It's been four years since Alexia released a Chardonnay, so the first taste of the new vintage is highly anticipated.

description:
Āhuru Kai Kōhua Poaka: Burger Wellington, The boil-up is a dish of love, traditionally made in big pots for whānau and friends. It brings people together. Te Papa wanted to capture the essence of this traditional Māori kai and give it a gourmet twist.

Traditional boil-up pork roulade, with Pagro lettuce and tomato, puha mousseline, and horopito aioli in a toasted Brezelmania watercress milk bun, with hand-cut kūmara fries, mānuka honey aioli, a shot of bone broth, and a heart-shaped raspberry framboise dessert.

Join us at the Te Papa Cafe on Level 1, walk-ins welcome. Reserve your spot by booking now.

Please note we aren’t able to accommodate dietary requirements.

description:
Urban Wine Walk - Pōneke Wellington, The streets and laneways of Pōneke Wellington are set to come alive this Spring as a line-up of eight venues each play host to an incredible winemaker, who'll be there ready to pour and chat you through an unforgettable afternoon.


HOW IT WORKS
Kick things off at your chosen starting spot with something to eat, and then let the adventure unfold. Wander at your own pace, glass in hand, discovering incredible wines and venues along the way.

With a stellar line-up of winemakers, good vibes at every stop, and a guaranteed sell-out crowd, the Urban Wine Walk is the ultimate self-guided tasting experience you and your crew won’t want to miss!


PARTICIPATING VENUES & WINEMAKERS
1 - Choice Bros Ft. Coney Wines (NZ)
2 - Glou Glou Ft. Halite (NZ)
3 - Little Beer Quarter Ft. Hopes Grove & Aard (NZ)
4 - Lulu Bar Ft. Margrain Vineyard (NZ)
5 - Noble Rot Ft. VALLI (NZ)
6 - Panhead Tory St Ft. The Good Way (NZ)
7 - The Arborist Rooftop Bar Ft. Matawhero (NZ)
8 - The Tasting Room Ft. Tettonica Wines (NZ)

*Please note that traditional venue menus may vary due to the nature of the event.


TICKETS
Vino Lover Pass – $79 + Booking Fee (Limited Availability)

WHAT’S INCLUDED
Wine Tastings – Up to 3 wines per winemaker along the trail
$10 Food Voucher – Redeem at your nominated starting venue (before 1pm)
$25 Wine Voucher – Put towards event-day wine orders (six-pack minimum, participating producers only)
Event Essentials – Your official wristband & keepsake tasting glass


EVENT REGISTRATION & COLLECTION
Before heading to your nominated starting venue, swing by the official registration point to collect your wristband, tasting glass & vouchers.

Where: Panhead Tory St (1 Tory St)
When: Saturday 18th October | 11am – 1pm

Please note: The Urban Wine Walk officially runs from 12-4pm. Arrive early to grab your event pack and avoid the rush!


REFUND POLICY
Tickets are non-refundable (we’re all in for good times rain, hail or shine!). The only exception is if the event is cancelled or postponed by the organisers – then we’ve got you covered.


GETTING AROUND
One of the best parts about the Urban Wine Walk...? It’s totally self-guided! After checking in at your nominated starting venue, the day is yours! Wander at your own pace, discover new spots and sip your way through the trail however you like.


Sorry kids, Urban Wine Walk is strictly 18 Years and Over!


----------

description:
Le Petit Chef, InterContinental Wellington proudly presents the first official Le Petit Chef experience in New Zealand - an extraordinary fusion of theatre, storytelling, and fine dining.

Step into the whimsical animated world of Le Petit Chef, the world’s tiniest and most determined chef, as he embarks on a globe-trotting quest to source the finest ingredients. Using groundbreaking 3D projection mapping technology, your table transforms into a magical stage, where continents shift, spices fly, and the art of cooking comes thrillingly to life before your eyes.

As the journey unfolds, a five-course menu is served in perfect harmony with the story. Highlights include Wairarapa crayfish bouillabaisse, corn-fed chicken with Perigord truffle, and a decadent Valrhona chocolate dessert. Choose from the Grand Menu ($180), Classic Menu ($140), Vegetarian Menu ($140), or a dedicated Kids Menu $70). While each menu offers a distinct culinary experience, the stunning visual show remains the same for all guests and is centered around the Grand Menu storyline.

Please note, while primarily designed for individual bookings, some shared seating may apply due to the technical nature of the performance.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Club Tropicana, This August, Beach Babylon becomes Club Tropicana, a retro, romantic escape inspired by 1960s tropical honeymoons, classic tiki bars and vintage beach glamour. Picture golden sunsets, flamingos, thatched umbrellas and the carefree buzz of a sun-soaked getaway, right in the heart of Wellington. No passport required.

The menu is vibrant and full of escapist flair. Start with coconut prawns and banana blossom kokoda, then dive into mains like mango glazed  pork rib rack or the tropical tofu paneer curry. Save room for dessert: pineapple upside-down pudding or a coconut rum fondue to bring the tropical fantasy to a sweet finale. Behind the bar, the tiki and kava-spiked cocktails flow freely, from Blue Hawaiian’s to retro rum punches, all dressed to impress with flamingo stirrers, umbrellas and tropical garnishes.

A golden-age soundtrack sets the mood, featuring the smooth calypso of Harry Belafonte, beachy vibes from The Beach Boys, and sun-drenched classics by Astrud Gilberto.

Club Tropicana is a winter getaway, fun and fabulously over the top.
label: Food & Drink

description:
JETAA Wellington - Brewkaiwa September @ Mean Doses, We will be having our September Brewkaiwa at Mean Doses, a bold and modern craft brewery in the heart of Wellington. Known for its inventive beers and laid-back atmosphere, it’s the perfect place to share a drink and good conversation.
Brewkaiwa is JETAA’s monthly casual meetup for anyone with any connection to Japan.
We’re a diverse group of people who have studied, worked, or lived in Japan or have been invited along by someone who has.
Come join us for a brew and stay for the kaiwa! Bring your friends!
***Japanese or alcohol consumption NOT REQUIRED!***
Brewkaiwaとは
一杯いかがですか？
JETAAがウェリントンで親睦会を開催するとどうなるのか？その結果、BREWKAIWA！
2020年に始まった、ブリューカイワは、ウェリントンの様々なバーで毎月開催されている飲み会です。大人気の国際交流グルップです！！！ 日本で働いたり、住んだり、旅行したことのある人達に人気のあるイベントです！！！お酒を飲んで、友達を出来、素敵なごちそうを食べ、おまけに異文化を知られます！
日本語が話せる外国人も良く参加しているので、日本語しか話せなくても全然大丈夫です！
是非来てください！
label: Food & Drink

description:

description:
Traditional Kölsch Service!, Kölsch Service is BACK!! Enjoy our fresh batch of Dösen Kölsch the traditional way - just like in Köln.
What's Kölsch service?
It's kinda like beer yum cha but there's only one thing on the menu - 200ml glasses of Kölsch bier!

We keep track of your tab by marking the edge of your coaster and when your glass is empty - voilà, another glass appears!
If you're done, just pop your coaster on top of your glass to indicate no more.
You can order food and non-alcoholics the same way, just take a seat and everything will come to you.
To make sure you get a table, book here: https://www.meandoses.co.nz/bookings
PLUS DEUTSCHES ESSEN!

We're serving up Apache's take on Currywurst - the classic German streetfood that is a dream with a crisp Kölsch. Yes we'll sort some vegan ones too!
We're also slinging more amazing fresh Brezels
from Brezelmania, served with cheese sauce

We'll be running Kölsch service from 12pm - 5pm on Saturday October 4th, come along and get the Köln experience!

The streets and laneways of Pōneke Wellington are set to come alive this Spring as a line-up of eight venues each play host to an incredible winemaker, who'll be there ready to pour and chat you through an unforgettable afternoon.
HOW IT WORKS
Kick things off at your chosen starting spot with something to eat, and then let the adventure unfold. Wander at your own pace, glass in hand, discovering incredible wines and venues along the way.
With a stellar line-up of winemakers, good vibes at every stop, and a guaranteed sell-out crowd, the Urban Wine Walk is the ultimate self-guided tasting experience you and your crew won’t want to miss!
PARTICIPATING VENUES & WINEMAKERS
1 - Choice Bros Ft. Coney Wines (NZ)
2 - Glou Glou Ft. Halite (NZ)
3 - Little Beer Quarter Ft. Hopes Grove & Aard (NZ)
4 - Lulu Bar Ft. Margrain Vineyard (NZ)
5 - Noble Rot Ft. VALLI (NZ)
6 - Panhead Tory St Ft. The Good Way (NZ)
7 - The Arborist Rooftop Bar Ft. Matawhero (NZ)
8 - The Tasting Room Ft. Tettonica Wines (NZ)
*Please note that traditional venue menus may vary due to the nature of the event.
TICKETS
Vino Lover Pass – $79 + Booking Fee (Limited Availability)
WHAT’S INCLUDED
Wine Tastings – Up to 3 wines per winemaker along the trail
$10 Food Voucher – Redeem at your nominated starting venue (before 1pm)
$25 Wine Voucher – Put towards event-day wine orders (six-pack minimum, participating producers only)
Event Essentials – Your official wristband & keepsake tasting glass
EVENT REGISTRATION & COLLECTION
Before heading to your nominated starting venue, swing by the official registration point to collect your wristband, tasting glass & vouchers.
📍 Where: Panhead Tory St (1 Tory St)
🗓️ When: Saturday 18th October | 11am – 1pm
Please note: The Urban Wine Walk officially runs from 12-4pm. Arrive early to grab your event pack and avoid the rush!
REFUND POLICY
Tickets are non-refundable (we’re all in for good times rain, hail or shine!). The only exception is if the event is cancelled or postponed by the organisers – then we’ve got you covered.
GETTING AROUND
One of the best parts about the Urban Wine Walk...? It’s totally self-guided! After checking in at your nominated starting venue, the day is yours! Wander at your own pace, discover new spots and sip your way through the trail however you like.
**Sorry kids, Urban Wine Walk is strictly 18 Years and Over!
----------

description:
Michelin Star to Martinborough, Join celebrated Chef and Union Square owner Adam Newell for a once-in-a-lifetime culinary experience. Take a journey through four decades of his exceptional career, including his Michelin-starred tenure at the renowned Fulham Road Restaurant in London. This exclusive event will offer an intimate exploration of Chef Newell's evolution as a chef and restaurateur, showcasing iconic dishes from four pivotal periods in his career.

Set in the elegant Napoleon dining room inside the historic Martinborough Hotel, each course represents a defining moment in Chef Newell’s career. Paired with fine wines selected by in-house Sommelier Carl Fraser, this evening is designed to be a feast for both the palate and the mind.

Course 1: 1980s – Claridge’s Hotel, London
A taste of the refined sophistication from one of London’s most prestigious hotels.
Course 2: 1990s – Le Gavroche, London
A nod to the classic French techniques that helped shape Chef Newell's early career.
Course 3: 2000s – Zibibbo, Wellington
A celebration of New Zealand’s finest ingredients and a significant step in his culinary journey.
Course 4: 2010s – Union Square Bistro, Martinborough
Reflecting his achievements at Union Square, the course that represents his current culinary vision.

This evening offers guests a unique chance to experience the evolution of one chef's journey through extraordinary dishes paired with wines that elevate each moment.

description:
9 September Whisky Tasting, Whisky Tasting: 9 September 2025
Hosted by Matt Mueller
In September, we'll get back on track, away from the International Whiskies of our August tasting, and on to the Eastern Highlands of Scotland: Glendronach.
Named for the valley of the brambles surrounding the distillery, Glendronach was the second distillery to gain a legal whisky license, and is currently under the stewardship of Dr. Rachel Barrie, a legend in the whisky industry. Dr Barrie has recently revamped the Glendronach lineup, and we're going to see how she's doing: we'll try the previous 12 and 15 year--old bottlings against her new releases. She's worked her magic at Ben Riach, and we'll see how she's doing at Glendronach (I suspect quite well!). Additionally, we'll try the highland peated Glendronach, a departure from the familiar smokey peat of Islay. We'll expect a sweeter, softer style, bolstered by some sherry maturation.
Please join me for this wonderful tasting of Glendronachs:
Tuesday, September 9
7:30pm Start time (arrive early to get a beer and a seat)
$60 per person
Seatoun Clubhouse (16 Dundas Street, Seatoun)
See you then,
Matt
Matt & the Clubhouse Team

description: Sweet Sensations, Noble Rot wants to sing the praises of sweet wines and help you to learn that they aren't just one note. They'll showcase a range of wines from around the world that lean towards the sweeter side without leaving a cloying sensation on your palate, enhanced by a specially-curated five-course degustation menu from entree to dessert. If you would like to explore your favourite level of sweetness in wine, this event is for you. The knowledgeable Noble Rot team are here to show you that sweetness is one of wine’s most versatile assets, as well-balanced sweetness in wine can be delicate, elegant and complementary to both sweet and savoury dishes. Discover how some grape varieties are more suited to producing sweeter wines and how their level of sweetness is achieved. If you're into the sweeter things in life, this one is for you.

description:
Plant Sale, I have had great success with NZ and imported seed propagation this year so we have a wonderful range of plants ready to go in the ground now.
Some varieties are extremely limited due to the cost of the imported seed and the tiny amount of seeds per packet (only 5 in some cases).
We will be accepting preorders by messenger so get in quick if you don't want to miss out on these special plants.
Please note: Our garden will not be open during the plant sale. We aim to open in approximately 5 weeks but it depends how the tulips progress.
As other plants reach maturity we will make them available for sale on our open days. We have decided to have a pre season sale to make room for more beauties.
Abutilon - a range of mixed colours including peach, rose and lemon.
Dwarf Agapanthus - a fine leaved pale blue variety. Great for edging paths and beds. Will not take over.
Aubretia - Lavender trailing plant for rock walls and garden edges.
Arabis - White blooming Spring groundcover
Ajuga - Pink and purple varieties. Great November blooming groundcover for damp areas.
Aster - Early summer flowering variety in blue/lavender
Calamintha - new for us so I shall borrow the Chiltern seeds description. This is a most pleasant plant for your border or herb garden. Heavily scented with a fragrance described as pennyroyal-like, it is an erect perennial with small, somewhat hairy leaves. In summer it bears numerous whorled spikes of tiny blue flowers with long purple bracts. The herb can be used for flavouring. Flowers the first year from seed. 1½ft (45cm).
Campanula glomerata - deep purple
Cerastium - grey trailing leaves smothered in white blooms in Spring. (These have just been cut back)
Cerinthe - By popular demand. Technically an annual but a non invasive self sowing one so once its in your garden you'll have more each year. Glaucous foliage and interesting pendular purple blooms.
Dianthus - Grey leaves and red blooms
Erigeron multiradiatus - A beautiful evergreen groundcover with yellow centred purple/blue daisies from late spring.
Erysimum - a specialty for us as we love them so much. What's not to love? Front to mid border, semi shrubby evergreen perennial, glorious scented blooms and we have individual named colours.
Ivory, Purple bi-colour, Fire King, Vulcan, Ellen Willmott, Primrose, Ruby gem, Siberian allionii and the brand new Tangerine Titan.
Euphorbia - golden foam. Another newbie for us but we love the the chartreuse euphorbias add to the garden so we had to give it a go.
Euphorbia characias - the blue leaved evergreen semi shrubs with huge chartreuse heads that grace our garden every spring.
Geum - Yes, you guessed it, another favourite of ours. We have a good stock of the common types plus some more unusual ones.
Tall - Yellow, Red and Orange (Firestorm).
Dwarf - Deep orange/red, Lemon with hints of pink, blush (very pale pink) and the original geum rivale in a beautiful coppery peach.
Lunaria (Honesty). Two types available. Chedglow the purple leaf version that has taken Chelsea by storm the last couple of years. Variegata - the green leaves become edged in white in their second year before blooming with the typical mauve flowers.
Lysimachia nummularis - yellow creeping jenny. Great lime leaf trailing plant for part shady damp areas. One only.
Orlaya grandiflora - another favourite among designers. A self sowing annual that will provide weeks of beautiful white lacecap flowers. Perfect for filling in border spaces until the summer perennials fill in or to give a light airy feel to meadows and spring plantings. Seedlings will return year after year.
Pelargonium - Deep red
Pulmonaria - Raspberry splash
Romulea - small bulbs grow fine grassy leaves before erupting into a mass of deep rosy purple crocus type flowers in late spring.
Scabiosa - another specialty plant for us as they provide such amazing flower power all summer and autumn. They are not frost hardy but are perennial in sheltered spots for at least 3 years. Enjoy the flowers and at the end of the season collect several packets worth of seed to multiply your stock.
Named varieties available:
Snowmaiden - white, Black Knight - deep maroon, Beaujolias Bonnets - a gorgeous blend of pink, white and burgundy on the same flower, Burgundy beau - a new one this year, Salmon Queen - the most delicious shade of salmon pink. Pale yellow Fata morgana, and blue ones will be available later in the season.
Stachys officinalis - dark pink flowered evergreen groundcover. Perfect for the front of garden beds and rock gardens.
Sissyrinchium blue eyed grass. Low grassy leaves burst in to a mass of blue star shaped flowers in Spring.
Sedum mexicana - a bright lime evergreen succulent groundcover. Perfect for supporting bold tulips in spring and bright perennials in summer.
Sedum Mr Goodbud. A slightly pinker version than the well known Autumn joy.
Sparaxia - very special maroon flowers. Couple only.
Symphytum grandiflora - low-lying evergreen groundcover with medium sized leaves and stunning cream bell flowers all through spring. Excellent spreading plant for difficult to grow areas such as the shade of evergreen trees.
Urospermum - sown last spring and flowered for the first time in summer. Don't be put off by its dandelion looking leaves. This is a beauty with huge lemon flowers ( yes again like a dandelion but oh so much more beautiful). It has survived a wet winter in our gravel garden and also in soil. Definitely not a weed!
Violets - green leaf with white scented flowers and the later flowering purple leaved Viola labadorica with purple flowers.

description:
Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture 2025 | Whakatū Nelson, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects are excited to welcome Ian Moore to New Zealand to present this year’s lecture series ‘The Past Needs a Future’ which will focus on adaptive reuse.
Ian is the principal of Ian Moore Architects, established in 1990. The practice has won numerous Australian and international awards and has been published and exhibited widely, including at the Venice Architecture Biennale in 2008 and 2012.
Initially studying civil and structural engineering at the Auckland Technical Institute in New Zealand, Ian moved on to study architecture at the University of Technology, Sydney, graduating with honours in 1988.
Ian has taught at numerous universities and been a speaker and guest lecturer throughout Australia as well as internationally.
Ian has also been a member of awards juries in Australia, New Zealand and at the World Festival of Interiors in 2013 and the World Architecture Festival in 2015. In 2003, Ian was the inaugural Creative Director for the Australian Institute of Architects annual conference.
About the Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture
The annual Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture commemorates the late Ian Athfield, a singular and much-loved figure in New Zealand architecture.
Affectionately known as ‘Ath’, Ian was knighted in 2014 and was one of New Zealand’s most influential architects. He won more than 60 national and international architecture and design awards and the lecture series was established to honour his legacy and celebrate his larrikin spirit.
In keeping with that spirit, each year the lecture is given by a person with something to say – someone who is challenging orthodoxy and a business-as-usual approach to practice, and life.
During his career, Ath designed many significant buildings, none more so than his own home in Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, which enraged the neighbours, perplexed the Council and inspired the city for decades.
Ath was talented, original, insightful, opinionated, provocative, and sometimes outrageous. His architecture is stimulating, challenging, ever-changing, but never careless.
In 2004, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects awarded Ath the Gold Medal for career achievements, noting at the time “What defines Athfield above all is his contagious enthusiasm, his devotion to architecture, and his unswerving belief in its possibilities. Believing architecture to be a civilising force, he has demonstrated a strong commitment to architecture’s public realm: the streets we live in; the urban centres we inhabit; the countryside we love and so often abuse.”
The Sir Ian Athfield Lecture Series is proudly sponsored by Resene.
Timing:
Doors open: 5.00pm
Lecture: 5.30pm - 6.30pm
Q&A: 6.30pm - 7.00pm
Lecture dates:
Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington | Wednesday 3 September | Michael Fowler Centre
Tāhuna Queenstown | Friday 5 September | Crowne Plaza
Whakatū Nelson | Tuesday 9 September | The Suter - Te Aratoi o Whakatū
Ōtautahi Christchurch | Wednesday 10 September | Black Box Theatre - Papa Hou
Heretaunga Hastings | Thursday 11 September | Toi Toi

description:
123 of Painting, In this introduction to painting, tutor Melissa McDougall, will start the class on a journey through the basic elements of painting in acrylic and oil paint. This class is structured for students new to painting as well as returning students from prior 123 of Painting classes or the like.

The class is structured around a series of exercises that explore the foundations of still-life and portrait painting. New students will be informally assessed in order to create a programme that best meets their needs.

With an emphasis on simple beginnings, the lessons will include colour theory, skin tones, structure and composition.

Teaching is done by analysing and copying master paintings in order to improve observational skills while learning the components of structure and composition.

Class is suitable for all levels of experience; we start from where you are. Melissa focuses on a personalised approach for the student with an emphasis on finding that person’s passion in art.

All basic materials provided.

Monday evenings, 13 Oct - 8 Dec (no class on Labour Day, 27 Oct), 6:30-8:30 pm.

description:

We will prepare simple, traditional Japanese home-style meals consisting of rice, soup, and a main dish (Ichijyu-issai). In each class, we'll make a different-flavoured miso soup along with a popular Japanese dish -- for example, teriyaki chicken or tonkatsu (crumbed pork cutlet).

We'll introduce you to Japanese food that's easy to prepare, tasty, and made with simple fresh ingredients plus we'll show you how easy it is to incorporate tasty and healthy Japanese food into your daily diet.
All ingredients are included in the fee. You just need to bring an apron, a dish cloth, a tea towel, and a container to take your food home in. Don't forget your smartphone if you want to take photos!

By the end of the course, you’ll:

become more familiar with using Japanese ingredients
feel more confident to cook authentic Japanese-style dishes at home
have the know-how to make delicious, well-balanced, and nourishing meals for the whole family.

Note: Our cooking courses are designed to provide a collaborative and immersive learning experience where learners often work in pairs and/or groups. While we wish to create an inclusive environment for all participants, it is important to note that our courses are unable to accommodate specific food allergies or deviate from the preplanned dishes and menus.

description:
Wellington Foraging Workshop 14th September 2025, Wellington Foraging Workshop 14th September 2025
Join expert forager Felicity Joy of Wild Botanica for a comprehensive Wild Edible Weeds Foraging Workshop in the beautiful community gardens of Mount Victoria, Wellington.

This inspiring experience will open your eyes to the abundance of edible wild plants growing right under your nose.

We’ll unlock the secrets of foraging, connecting with the land, and turning humble "weeds" into delicious, nourishing food. You’ll gain confidence in identifying common edible plants, learn their botanical names, and understand their medicinal and nutritional benefits. We’ll also explore ethical foraging practices, how to spot toxic lookalikes, and share simple, practical ways to incorporate wild foods into your daily meals.

This isn’t just about food: it’s about sustainability, resilience, and reconnecting with the environment in a meaningful way. You'll leave with a deeper appreciation for the land, new skills to support local food security, and the knowledge to make your own simple meals from wild ingredients.

Class sizes are limited, so book early to secure your spot.
For more details and bookings, visit

www.wildbotanica.co.nz
follow @wild.botanica.nz on social media.

For questions, email .

Join my email newsletter to hear about upcoming foraging workshops: https://www.wildbotanica.co.nz/pages/newsletter

description:
Jewellery Making - Lost Wax Cast Rings, Evolve and advance your jewellery-making abilities with exciting lost wax methods to create rings cast in copper, brass, bronze, white bronze and silver - beginners welcome! All material costs included in course fee.

Description
In this fresh 6-week jewellery-making course, you get a hands-on opportunity to develop new techniques creating rings with a sculptural and organic flair.

The lost wax process offers a wide range of creative outcomes such as 3D forms and textures, which are not achievable with fabrication techniques.

You will design and create a pair of rings in jeweller’s wax. These wax masters will be cast professionally for you, outside class, making them in metals of your choice - copper, brass, yellow bronze or white bronze.

Later in the course you will refine your new wax shaping skills and develop a ring to be cast in sterling silver!

In the second part of the course, you will sand and refine your casts into finished jewellery.

The class offers beginners a fun introduction to jewellery making, and for those with some jewellery experience it offers a great way to advance and expand your making techniques to new levels.

All materials included in course fee. Please bring pen and paper and your reading glasses (if you use these) and wear clothing and footwear suitable for a workshop environment.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

- Evolve your jewellery-making abilities with new and exciting lost wax methods
- Develop and create unique sculptural ring designs
- Carve hard jeweller’s wax ring master designs to fit a chosen finger size for casting
- Sculpt and model soft jeweller’s wax master design to fit a chosen finger size for casting
- Combine hard and soft jeweller’s wax to create unique designs ready for casting
- File, sand and polish metal casts into finished jewellery

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly.

6 weeks, Thu 6:00 PM - 8:30 PM
Wellington High School

Time: 4:30 pm – 6:30 pm
Speaker: John (JR) Robson
Description: My journey from banks to BioTechs
  About John Robson:
JR is the Managing Director of cell therapy company, BioOra Limited. BioOra addresses both access and scale issues by providing an affordable and accelerated pathway to market for CAR-T therapies via lower cost, high throughput, GMP licensed manufacturing capabilities from clinical trial through to registration and commercialisation.
 JR is also the General Manager of Bridgewest Ventures in New Zealand, and he holds an executive position within the Bridgewest Group, a San Diego based privately held investment company that focuses on disrupting industries through innovation and with investment assets in excess of US$4 billion, and JR is responsible for the deep tech investment programme in New Zealand.
 JR has nearly 30 years of investment experience across global markets and he has been intimately involved in the start-up community in New Zealand since 2008 through a number of early-stage technology companies as an executive and non-executive director. JR regularly writes and speaks about technology in a number of forums and is an avid futurist.
 In addition to his executive roles, JR has been active in the Not-for-Profit ecosystem in New Zealand for 20 years and was the Chair of the National Board of the Child Cancer Foundation for 4 years, and is currently a Board Member of the One Percent Collective Trust. He was awarded Life Membership of the Child Cancer Foundation in 2017 by the Governor-General of New Zealand, Her Excellency The Rt Hon Dame Patsy Reddy, for his services to Childhood Cancer.
 FB Rice:
FB Rice is a leading independent intellectual property firm with a strong focus on biotechnology and the life sciences. With more than 75 years of experience and a dedicated Wellington office, we’re proud to support New Zealand’s growing biotech community through local presence and expertise.
Our Biotechnology Group brings deep scientific and industry knowledge across areas such as gene therapy, diagnostics, biologics, vaccines, and medical technologies. We work closely with clients across academia, research, and industry to protect innovation and support commercial success—offering strategic advice on patentability, prosecution, due diligence, and portfolio management.
As active participants in New Zealand’s innovation ecosystem, we value collaboration and are committed to helping the local biotech sector thrive.
 Lab-Works:
With over 30 years’ experience, Lab-works Architecture are New Zealand’s leading laboratory design architects, with a proven track record across research, teaching, healthcare, and analytical facilities. We believe well-designed laboratories and support spaces enhance capability, productivity, and competitive advantage, so we ensure our clients benefit from best practice in facility planning, design, and technology. Science is always evolving, and so are we—continuously updating our skills and staying at the forefront of new research to deliver leading-edge projects. Through active involvement in international conferences, standards committees, and ongoing research and development in the built environment, we provide design and technical solutions that are robust, fit-for-purpose, and future-focused.

description:
Lost Wax Casting - 6 Weeks Course, A fantastic class full of fun and inspiration! It starts on Wed 1 October and runs until Wed 5 November, 5.30pm-8pm.

Level one: Students learn carving in hard wax, texture forming in soft wax, and how to clean up and finish your metal pieces. Course costs include basic materials for the process, but do not include the eventual metal costs for the pieces you choose to cast. As this is subject to each students' choice of size and type of metal, we leave this up to you to decide.

Castings may cost between $5 and $40 depending on whether you cast in Silver or Bronze. Casting in Bronze or Brass will be much cheaper.

Level two: expand your range of designs and skills with the wax you prefer using. Learn to set stones into your designs and either: Cast them IN the metal (exciting and organic) or, more advanced students can learn to set them in a fabrication class.

Classes fill fast so please book now to reserve your place!

description:
2-Day Kali Seminar with Stephen Brown from Inosanto Academy in CA, 2-Day Kali Seminar with Stephen Brown from Inosanto Academy in CA
Want to learn the exact martial art skills as used in the Bourne films? Wellington this is your chance...

Tactical Survival Academy is hosting Senior Instructor Stephen Brown from the renowned Inosanto Academy of Martial Arts in Marina Del Rey, Los Angeles!

With over 40 years of martial arts experience and 36 years training under Guro Dan Inosanto, Stephen is one of only two instructors currently teaching Kali classes at the academy alongside Guro Dan Inosanto himself.

Stephen specializes in the Filipino Martial Art of Kali, as passed down through Guro Inosanto’s lineage. His training background also includes extensive experience in Muay Thai, Silat, Western Boxing, Jeet Kune Do, Savate and Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu.

Over the decades, Stephen has worked with:
* Multiple branches of Law Enforcement, Military units and Special Forces.
* Actors, stunt performers, and executives in the film and television industry.
* As a fight choreographer for screen productions.

Known for his precision, adaptability, and deep respect for the cultural roots of the arts he teaches, Stephen brings a wealth of knowledge and embodied experience to every seminar.

Currently based in Marina Del Rey, CA, Stephen is excited to share the Kali method of Guro Inosanto with the New Zealand martial arts community.

• Location: Mt Cook School Hall, 160 Tory Street, Te Aro
• Dates: Sat Sept 6 + Sun Sept 7

description:
Sculpture - Intro to Creature Sculpting, Join us in an exciting new introduction to creative sculpting - a hands on class to produce unique creature figurines and miniatures to bring your imagination to life! - Beginners welcome! All material costs included in course fee.

Description
Whether you want to make creatures cute, creepy, in the style of pop-toys, figurines, or a one-of-a-kind character in your own style, this is the class for you!

Working with air dry clays, oven bake polymer clays and wire, armatures this workshop offers a variety of modelling methods and approaches - a great opportunity to turn ideas into tangible 3D forms. With modern clays we can create translucent, flexible, and even glow-in-the-dark elements to add more realism or a touch of the surreal into each creation!

We’ll kick off working with traditional air-dry clay to get a feel for modelling a few simple forms.

Once familiar with the materials, we’ll go through some basic design elements, guided by animal anatomy and morphology. From here the tutor will show and chat with the group about ways we can transform the creatures from our imagination into unique sculptures full of character.

Students will be coached through designing and creating a series of small-scale creature sculptures, beginning simple, and building to a more complex final form as we gather practice.

The class offers beginner students a fun introduction to sculpting organic forms from scratch, and for those with some hands-on creative experience, it offers a great opportunity to experiment, hone and advance your making skills to new levels.

Please wear closed-in footwear suitable for a workshop environment. bring a work apron if you have one or wear clothes you don’t mind getting a little grubby. Remember to bring your reading glasses if a have them.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

That’s where our holiday workshops come in. After a hiatus, Inspiration Education, in collaboration with StudyTime, is running NCEA Level 2 and 3 revision workshops from 1-3 October at Wellington Girls’ College.
Each session is two hours long and covers an entire external/topic, giving students the chance to:
Go over all the key content they’ll need for the exam
Learn exactly what the exam will be testing
Pick up strategies for tackling the harder Merit and Excellence questions
Receive a workbook to use in the session and keep for revision afterwards
Ask questions and get support from experienced tutors who’ve been through it all before
Why Attend?
These workshops are designed to:
Fill any gaps in knowledge
Build exam confidence
Kickstart motivation heading into Term 4
Spaces are limited and workshops often sell out quickly. Register now to secure your spot and head into exams feeling prepared, confident, and ready to succeed.

Drypoint Printmaking Workshop, Explore drypoint printmaking with experienced local print maker Kirsty White.

In this workshop you will

- Learn to etch a polycarbonate plate
- Use steel needle point tools and wire brushes to create line and texture that will hold ink.
- learn to ink up your plate
- use mull cloth to achieve desired tone
- print on damp printmaking paper
- run this print through a second stage using the relief process of inking up and printing from a natural textured block
- Learn more about your tutor here.

All materials supplied.
Half hour lunch break -bring a packed lunch to eat in the historic Inverlochy House or explore the local Te Aro cafes.

description:
Glass Bead-Making Taster, Join us for this fabulous introduction to working with colourful molten glass!

This class is a great way for absolute beginners to get a taste of working with glass to produce beautiful beads that can be used in a myriad of ways, including making a unique gift for your loved one (or yourself!).

As one of the earliest forms of human adornment, beads have long functioned as a way to express individuality, and what better way to do that than to learn to make your own unique beads?

Students are shown correct lampworking techniques to produce several decorative beads in just 3 hours! How many beads you make is up to you, some students make up to 10 while others make fewer using trickier techniques.

Kids over 12 (or so) are welcome to take the class but anyone under 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.

This Wasn't the Plan: A Musical Theatre Cabaret, Created and performed by Glenn Horsfall

This sold-out Pōneke favourite returns for one night only at Hannah Playhouse!

Please take your seats in this cabaret classroom as lecturer, acclaimed musical theatre performer Glenn Horsfall, takes you through the twists and turns of a life imagined versus a reality lived. Glenn lays bare his journey of self-discovery, from the highs of childhood fame to the lows of bullying and self-doubt. With beautiful songs and hilarious, heartfelt, humbling stories, this show looks at what it means when the script of life gets rewritten.

This Wasn’t The Plan picked up the Auckland Fringe Tour Ready Award and Outstanding Solo Performance Award at NZ Fringe 2025. It’s a must-see for anyone navigating change or questioning societal expectations.

description:
Pebble - Love In Every City, Poems and Songs from the Road

After seasons of wandering through foreign cities, sharing songs with strangers, and capturing stories from the road. PEBBLE has spent the past few years on an open-ended journey: traveling across continents in search of the deepest stories, the wildest love, the purest expression of what it means to be human. From late-night train stations to hidden cafés, from sunlit rooftops to candlelit stages—PEBBLE has been gathering moments and melodies from everywhere he goes, transforming them into songs and poems that reflect a life lived wide open.

“Love in Every City” is the next chapter in that journey—a stripped-back, soul-forward performance that brings those stories home.
Backed by a vision to build a global movement of traveling artists who choose authenticity over perfection, connection over isolation, and creative ownership over compromise, PEBBLE’s work invites us to remember what we’re really here for: to live, to feel, to share.

This show is a moment of reflection and reconnection—
Join us for an intimate night of music, poetry, and storytelling at Moon in Newtown, Pōneke. A suitcase full of songs. A guitar by the table. A heart full of cities.

description:
Writers on Mondays: Brannavan Gnanalingam and Duncan Sarkies, The satire we deserve: Brannavan Gnanalingam and Duncan Sarkies
Two novelists take the pulse of life in Aotearoa and diagnose a hilarious and dangerous arrhythmia. Brannavan Gnanalingam’s The Life and Opinions of Kartik Popat takes the gloves off to better prod the weeping sores of our body politic and social media. Duncan Sarkies depicts the farcical and chilling demise of democracy within an alpaca breeders’ association in Stargazers. Join Pip Adam as she asks both writers about the serious intent behind the hijinks and why it’s a good time to wield the satirical scalpel.

ADMISSION IS FREE—ALL WELCOME
Writers on Mondays is presented with the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Circa Theatre, Meow and Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day and supported by the Letteri Family.

HOW IT WORKS
If you want to Pitch Ya Pal: Submit a short, creative pitch deck. If selected, you’ll present it live on stage to a crowd of (mostly) singles.

Come Watch the Magic: Whether you’re pitching or just along for the ride, expect a night full of laughs and potential right swipes in real life.

description:
Pride and Punchlines, Comedy meets pride this October in Paraparaumu as 2020 Entertainment Ltd presents Pride & Punchlines, an all-queer stand-up night in association with Paekākāriki Pride.

This night isn’t just jokes — it’s visibility, community, and laughter. A chance for queer voices to take centre stage, question norms, and connect through humour. Whether you’re LGBTQIA+ yourself or an ally, there’s something for everyone.

What a Line-Up we have:

Neil Thornton
Veteran, teacher, and industry shaper: Neil brings decades of international and local experience to the stage. He’s performed in NYC clubs, Edinburgh Fringe, and rural NZ towns. His NZ shows — Bearly Kiwi, Ursus Americanus, Hot Mess on Wheels — have won critical praise and awards. He founded the NZ Comedy School to mentor emerging comics.
“Thornton is just a master of the craft … the room is totally unified.” — Theatreview
“A bold performer with intelligent material.” — Ruminator

Kipling DC
A 2026 Billy T Award nominee, Kipling DC is making waves in Wellington’s comedy scene. With roots in Ngāpuhi and Te Hikutu, he mixes crowd work, self-deprecation, and cheeky wit. He’s widely regarded as one of the bold voices to watch.

Oliver Pol
Known for blending social commentary and absurd observations with relatability.

Jac Lynch
Local Kāpiti comedian, bringing grounded humour and home-town pride to the mix.

Meaghan Fisher
Originally from Canada, offering queer perspective with a fresh voice in comedy.

description:
Kotahitanga: Artist Series - Tusiata Avia, We are honoured to host acclaimed poet; Tusiata Avia who will be opening Kotahitanga with her response to He Kura Toi Tangata.

Expect nothing less than the power of the word steeped in truth and machete-sharpened wit from this New Zealand Samoan poetry pantheon.

5:30pm Doors open, bar open
6pm Artist response begins
6:30pm Interval
6:45pm Artist Q&A
7pm Closing Karakia and time to explore He Kura Toi Tangata exhibition
8pm Bar closes, event ends



About Tusiata Avia

Tusiata Avia MNZM is a poet, writer and performer. She has published 5 books of poetry, children’s books, short film, radio documentary. Her iconic play Wild Dogs Under My Skirt showed Off-Broadway in 2020, where it won the Fringe Encore Outstanding Production of the Year. Her most recent play, The Savage Coloniser Show won Best New Play at Wellington Theatre Awards 2024. Both plays are based on books of poetry of the same name.

Tusiata was awarded a Member of the New Zealand Order of Merit for services to poetry and in 2024, the Prime Ministers Award for Literary Achievement: Poetry.


This event has been developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.

description:
The Best of Bill Bryson — Live on Stage, With 21 published nonfiction books, you’ll likely have come across Bill Bryson’s work. One of his most famous books, ‘A Short History of Nearly Everything’, has been given a major rewrite. He takes to the stage at The Opera House to talk about his new findings. 
In ‘A Short History of Nearly Everything 2.0’, Bill updates the book with the latest scientific research on the Earth and the universe. In the live show, you’ll hear about planetology, astronomy, particle physics, the Big Bang, quantum mechanics, and evolution. Throughout his career, the journalist and author has covered a wide range of subjects, including travel, the English language, and the human body. This rare chance to see him live promises forays into many of these areas. All conducted with his usual theatrical flair. 
Bill Bryson has a quest to understand everything that has happened from the Big Bang to the rise of civilisation and what humans are today. Join him as he shares the latest major advances in science.

description:
John Campbell’s Destiny Church Investigation: Part 2 Under His Command, John Campbell investigated Destiny Church in a five-part documentary screened in April this year.
Join us to watch Part 2 of John Campbell’s Destiny Church investigation. John Campbell highlights some consistent themes of Brian Tamaki's Destiny Church: far-right prejudices, manifest anger, and hatred.
In Auckland on 21 June, Destiny Church organised a march to take "a bold public stand for Christian values, Kiwi identity and the future of this nation".
On Saturday, 13 September, Brian Tamaki attended the London “Unite the Kingdom” protest organised by far-right political activist Tommy Robinson that claimed to celebrate 'free speech', but also contained chants of hate, racist conspiracy theories, and Christian nationalist slogans. Among disturbing scenes, some people in the crowd ripped up a flag that read 'Secular Humanism'. To them, the very idea that people of all backgrounds and beliefs can live together with equality and respect is something to fear and destroy. For decades, the far right in the USA has painted humanism as a bogeyman, blaming it for liberal values, the rights of women, and the rights of LGBT people. It shows that those who thrive on fear are deliberately targeting the very values that underpin human rights and human dignity. Humanism is not a fringe or ‘woke’ idea. It is about fairness. It is about reason. It is about believing in the good that people are capable of when they are free to live their lives without fear or prejudice. These protests, which Brian Tamaki is supporting, are a show of force from those who wish to undo progress, to divide communities, and to undermine cherished freedoms.
We have a growing concern for secular values in our community. We cannot be silent. It is essential to keep compassion alive in public life and politics. After watching the documentary, we will discuss our concerns and how we might respond.
Time: Oct 6, 2025 06:30 PM Auckland, Wellington
Join Zoom Meeting
https://us02web.zoom.us/j/88183700512...

This isn’t just a concert, it’s a movement. Under-18 musicians, solo artists, and bands (some joined by over-18 allies) are coming together to rock out with purpose, showing that music knows no borders and compassion has no age limit.
These young performers are using their talents to stand in solidarity with kids just like them who are living through unimaginable circumstances.

There will be stalls and crafting available for kids attending - Please come and support so we can raise money for Gaza's families.

Witness the next generation of artists and activists sharing the stage and raising their voices. Please support them with your attendance. Show them young people can make a difference.
Be part of an event where music becomes action, and community becomes change.

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Week: Tragedies Tour, Come and hear stories of those who met sad, shocking and untimely ends. This tour traverses some of the older parts of the story where historic headstones mark the stories of lives lost too soon: accidents, murder, misadventure and those who fell by their own hand.
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day 1 hour before the tour starts by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 2 hours long.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
If you have purchased tickets for other people can you please pass our tour information on to them as well.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

description:
Art and AI: Brit Bunkley in Conversation with Megan Dunn, Art and AI: Brit Bunkley in Conversation with Megan Dunn
Artist and filmmaker Brit Bunkley discusses the pragmatics and politics of making art with AI. Join us for a discussion in the Gallery, with insights into the making of his latest work Archive, commissioned for Messengers.

--

Brit Bunkley is a New Zealand-based artist and videographer whose practice spans sculpture, installation, and digital media. A recipient of the US National Endowment for the Arts fellowship, two NY state grants, and the Rome Prize Fellowship, his work explores the intersection of physical and virtual spaces, often blending surreal imagery with themes of history, politics, and environmental concerns. He has exhibited at the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa and internationally at Rencontres Internationales Paris/Berlin, FILE São Paulo (including 2025), and the Athens Digital Arts Festival. Recent exhibitions include Visions in the Nunnery, London (2022), Cybersculpture 2024 at Collège des Bernardins, Paris, and The Torrance Art Museum, LA (2025). In 2024, he won Best Art | Experimental Video/Film at the New York City Independent Film Festival. His work continues to evolve, embracing new technologies and alternative methodologies to challenge perceptions of reality and imagination.

Learn more here > https://citygallery.org.nz/events/art-and-ai-brit-bunkley-in-conversation-with-megan-dunn/

IMAGE Brit Bunkley, still from Archive, single channel video, 2025
